<figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/42518ed1-b6e0-4243-9846-f7680b700184.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Untitled #19, Magnificent Mile, IL\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ef53f07c-ef83-4a82-826d-10c63e219f5b.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Untitled #15, South Side Chicago, IL\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/98ff4361-cdb0-4c6b-bc5f-e84c97c13d4e.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Untitled #42, Central Los Angeles, CA\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a7485492-7bb0-4c4a-8a5c-5a9d4d53d727.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Untitled #44, Crenshaw Blvd, CA\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b164514e-3280-4951-8115-3d5ce1f2bd21.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Untitled #1, Co-Op City, NY\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a5d25740-ccc9-4268-b7e0-4c1e4ffb59e8.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Untitled #2, Co-Op City, NY\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a22c90ed-dcc4-431a-b9ca-dcba7da5bdc1.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Untitled #16, South Side Chicago, IL\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d4d0a87a-8d66-423b-8d6f-8d2c6a718a32.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Untitled #22, Berwyn, IL\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d998f35c-fd48-499d-ab16-839f217b2a14.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Untitled #25, Montgomery, AL\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4ad23990-d72b-4a00-b195-931990522c3e.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Untitled #35, North Minneapolis, MN\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n  </section> \n </hr></br>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 05 Jun 2020 12:52:18 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/4ad23990-d72b-4a00-b195-931990522c3e.jpg","linkMd5":"6678150e5011ba5eb255105532e77aec","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn8@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-48-410_156f0993e70f43f8.webp","destWidth":1124,"destHeight":2000,"sourceBytes":196477,"destBytes":112554,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/4ad23990-d72b-4a00-b195-931990522c3e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn8@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-48-410_156f0993e70f43f8.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d28e210c-c69f-422e-b432-410e61032a89.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn80@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-12-767_758feab0dbd38aed.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/2f45351d-5223-4fab-88d3-a0e54f792688.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn75@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-53-568_9d622035bb0b25f5.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3bc8fc28-b7f1-469d-95b0-901ecffd886a.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn48@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-16-607_9ea6c92b2517e035.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/42518ed1-b6e0-4243-9846-f7680b700184.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn39@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-03-863_e565530f3444c934.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ef53f07c-ef83-4a82-826d-10c63e219f5b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn76@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-06-563_30301fe7a6ef02c6.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/98ff4361-cdb0-4c6b-bc5f-e84c97c13d4e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-59-225_499519b704d82c98.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a7485492-7bb0-4c4a-8a5c-5a9d4d53d727.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn12@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-56-981_db4f9132cd663e67.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b164514e-3280-4951-8115-3d5ce1f2bd21.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn19@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-52-651_989e7febc1351f3f.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a5d25740-ccc9-4268-b7e0-4c1e4ffb59e8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn80@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-06-102_8113ead44853f870.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a22c90ed-dcc4-431a-b9ca-dcba7da5bdc1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn83@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-02-450_5ca21061630237cf.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d4d0a87a-8d66-423b-8d6f-8d2c6a718a32.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn92@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-04-339_08173c53d6165e2c.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d998f35c-fd48-499d-ab16-839f217b2a14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn24@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-58-376_27da57b8592d2f6e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4ad23990-d72b-4a00-b195-931990522c3e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn64@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-55-187_aa9a616adf5c484e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066815},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Summer Camp","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/mark-steinmetz-summer-camp","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Summer Camp</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Mark Steinmetz</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/3d5f68e2-0a29-4092-82ff-83340a218d4b.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  In this beautiful monograph, Mark Steinmetz distills the timeless adventure of American summer camp into a series of tender observations on the nature of adolescence.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<div class=\"article-incut -book-incut\"> \n <div class=\"article-incut -book-incut\"> \n  <div class=\"picture\"> \n   <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/books/18717-summer-camp\"></a> \n  </div> \n  <div class=\"title\">\n   Summer Camp\n   <br> </br>\n  </div> \n  <div class=\"author\">\n   by Mark Steinmetz\n   <br> </br>\n  </div> \n  <div class=\"publisher\">\n   Publisher: Nazraeli Press\n   <br>ISBN: 978-1-59005-513-7<br> </br></br>\n  </div> \n </div> \n</div> \n<p>Mark Steinmetz’ <em>Summer Camp </em>is a journey that starts with a road trip by bus out of town, into the woods, and arrives in lake country where camp life awaits. The call to adventure promises bunk beds, communal dining, activities in the woods, swimming in the lake, and camp fires at night. For children who are just beginning to navigate the world on their own, camp life presents an alternate world for them to explore. </p> \n<p><em>Summer Camp</em> was made between 1986 and 1997 at camps in North Carolina, Massachusets, Wisconsin, Illinois, and Georgia. The project marks a departure from the earlier photographs Steinmetz had been making on the streets of LA and New York; his interest had turned towards making a coherent body of work by focusing on a particular subject for a longer period of time, an approach that continued in all his subsequent work.<br> </br></p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the book “Summer Camp” © Mark Steinmetz\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/mark-steinmetz-summer-camp#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>During the early years working on <em>Summer Camp</em>, he also photographed little league baseball players in the spring and carnival crowds in the fall. All three bodies of work examined a specific subject matter at a specific time of year, and, as in the case of <em>Summer Camp</em> and little league baseball, a specific age. Although the work was made over two decades, his approach draws out elements that withstand generational or topical change: moments of thoughtfulness and affection; expressions of humor and playfulness; the quiet of rest found in solitude.<br> </br></p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the book “Summer Camp” © Mark Steinmetz\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/mark-steinmetz-summer-camp#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Steinmetz initially gained access to various camps by working as staff. In some places he taught photography, collecting items in the woods with the children and then returning to the camps’ darkrooms to make photograms. Other years, he was hired as a camp photographer for promotional material, official publications, portraiture and so on. The work was shot on both 35mm and medium format film and maintains a visual coherence reflected in the tonality and technical approach to the subject matter. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the book “Summer Camp” © Mark Steinmetz\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/mark-steinmetz-summer-camp#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>With the timelessness of his black and white photographs, Steinmetz captures the physicality and emotional vulnerability of adolescence. A child is still small in the world, the emotions poignant, less constrained by time<em>.</em> In the small, private world of summer camp, the securities of home are replaced by the rustic setting of cabins with bunk beds and screen doors, while flashlights replace reading lamps and firelight replaces television. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the book “Summer Camp” © Mark Steinmetz\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/mark-steinmetz-summer-camp#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The sequencing of the book travels through a typical weekend of camp experiences, but the distinction between the different summer camps is never apparent. Here are children playing in the lake; there they relax in the afternoon, reading, drying off, spending moments alone; over here gathered around the breakfast table, dewy-eyed and still dreaming. In the end, <em>Summer Camp </em>finishes with the perennial event of any camp retreat: bonfires and candlelight rituals. The final image of the book is of a bus waiting to leave the next morning. Children embrace in the shared emotional experiences and new found friendships made at camp. </p>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/tomas-fernandez-do-north-cold-heartbreak-on-the-road\">Do North: Cold Heartbreak on the Road</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/matjaz-krivic-digging-the-future\">Digging the Future</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/ash-shinya-kawaoto-scrap-and-build\">Scrap and Build</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/jt-white-neverland-my-korea\">Neverland: My Korea</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/mankichi-shinshi-elimination-method\">Elimination Method</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/paul-moakley-on-the-speed-of-the-real\">On the Speed of the Real</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e53e20af-9b18-4d0d-9925-c28d002fe073.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/cfe2f46e-a851-4a2c-81be-7d923a9302bb.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/47880e68-4c11-430c-bdea-d1d23d37562a.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a12d0f0c-bc0b-442d-ae6c-9eeee2912049.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/90150f35-5aeb-4fd9-9e49-67b3a12f5168.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/11d63d0e-0aa4-4dd4-b069-a284e6076cca.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5cbf1e11-9c21-473c-a591-28aa2a8d9c19.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e717b6dd-08d1-4728-a14a-f094ff4b4191.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 20 Apr 2020 11:28:03 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/3d5f68e2-0a29-4092-82ff-83340a218d4b.jpg","linkMd5":"2f099ae8989ab056c6e290c9ffa0a031","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn4@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-47-631_8b04780573ce84d3.webp","destWidth":1045,"destHeight":1859,"sourceBytes":255448,"destBytes":118204,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/3d5f68e2-0a29-4092-82ff-83340a218d4b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn4@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-47-631_8b04780573ce84d3.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/6fbbd6d2-37bd-4134-a2bd-3005cf7a6374.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn60@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-02-306_c4085eca990bd96d.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/6ce5aef3-b1f1-4db4-9ddb-6dff2423dadf.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn24@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-52-883_1264d1cc7cbb7ef4.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/54108be3-400a-4299-9479-78905547e4e6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn68@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-05-197_5275f649f3930bf2.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/76cebd83-c90f-492e-b781-8b3ec50888a4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn16@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-52-001_9bc28499c8cef599.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e53e20af-9b18-4d0d-9925-c28d002fe073.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn32@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-53-141_5a558be47c51e342.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/cfe2f46e-a851-4a2c-81be-7d923a9302bb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn60@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-52-132_cac2be193f645aab.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/47880e68-4c11-430c-bdea-d1d23d37562a.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn4@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-52-003_b9fd7c7dd10c494a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a12d0f0c-bc0b-442d-ae6c-9eeee2912049.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn72@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-59-914_737d9cd962d7a482.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a77ec4d8-e676-47c1-905c-51b499d487f7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn80@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-09-691_71b3f7b3804f6ecd.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/90150f35-5aeb-4fd9-9e49-67b3a12f5168.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn68@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-07-742_478aa728bed83d51.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/11d63d0e-0aa4-4dd4-b069-a284e6076cca.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn43@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-56-596_bd8cfbb0940a09e9.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3d5f68e2-0a29-4092-82ff-83340a218d4b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn100@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-13-236_2c61b8dc1ccfc8eb.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5cbf1e11-9c21-473c-a591-28aa2a8d9c19.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn40@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-09-891_acadb32c7fe50d45.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e717b6dd-08d1-4728-a14a-f094ff4b4191.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn47@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-10-455_a9c403444b976b40.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066820},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Vistas","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/brea-souders-vistas","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Vistas</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Brea Souders</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/5a1863c3-3d24-4b6f-ad62-2b6685265ef5.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  What is at stake now that we can travel the world through a screen? In her hand-colored photographs, sourced from virtual tours of national parks hosted on Google, Brea Souders invokes the romanticism and tradition of landscape photography to question its status in the present.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>It’s been a long time since we’ve needed to leave our homes to explore the world. Longer still since ‘Explorer’ has been a valid occupation. We’ve mapped the Earth down to its dirt. The internet is our vessel now. We can ‘go’ anywhere, ‘see’ anyplace. For travels through American landscapes, we’ve swapped the once-required horse-driven wagon and months of dangerous journey for a few keystrokes on our computers; a flick of the wrist, really. </p> \n<p>In order to voyage through Brea Souders’ <em>Vistas</em>, we must first understand how her pictures were made. The artist culls anonymous shadow selfies from 360-degree photographs of U.S. national parks found on Google. The image-stitching algorithms, as magnificent a technology as they are, have difficulty in knowing how to handle the shadows left on the ground by camera operators, leaving fragmented artifacts of human presence amid their techno-mediated views of the natural world. Souders takes these views, prints them, and applies watercolors to form resemblances of hand-colored travel postcards of an older time. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Vistas” © Brea Souders\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/brea-souders-vistas#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>What results is a kind of picture that nimbly enters into numerous conversations old and new. In the history of Western art, the landscape picture is something of a vessel that carries within it the cultural and social values of its maker’s time. During the Renaissance, landscape rendering was cloaked in biblical narrative, a foil upon which depictions of mythology could perform. As the world moved toward the modern era, the landscape picture went through its own phases of romanticism, realism, impressionism, cubism, following along in the changes of its larger social contexts. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Vistas” © Brea Souders\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/brea-souders-vistas#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The lines of artistic tradition and definition in our current age are no longer so cleanly delineated. We live in a world of fragmentation, speed, and mass plurality of cultural expression. While the changes of physical land are measured in ages and eons, the changes to how we <em>represent</em> land now shift from second to second. It moves in all directions all at once, and in unpredictable ways. Landscape is a mirror for reflections of the day; reflections that are mired in ever-complicating social, ecological, and technological conditions. So the question comes now of what Souders’ <em>Vistas</em> carry within their frames. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Vistas” © Brea Souders\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/brea-souders-vistas#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The perspectival space in Souders’ images places our viewing of these fragmented figures as sights of our own shadows. From one picture to the next we enter into these spaces and take part in the artist’s game of association. In one scene we might be a cowboy. In another, a Victorian gentlewoman. We become adventurers and explorers, but we also become angels and demons, and sometimes outright monstrosities. There is a primitive signature in these grounded silhouettes, like contemporary cave drawings stamped onto ground and left as evidence for our speculation. The pictures illustrate evidence of their own makings, shadows of their original authors out in the natural world. But when we look at these pictures, we inevitably see ourselves, costumed, performing, taking on fantastical identities rooted in archetypal imagination. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Vistas” © Brea Souders\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/brea-souders-vistas#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Souders’ hand-coloring recalls a form of photography born in the late 19th century that had a particular ambition to circumvent the natural limitations of B&amp;W’s illusion of reality. Color makes photographs more real, more present, and more in and of our world. In the context of Souders’ work, it’s only ironic that our growing dependence and assimilation into virtual space brings us further from the natural world, turning <em>Vistas</em> into a tug-of-war between what we once were as humans, and what we are now. Photography <em>has</em> changed us, the internet <em>is</em> changing us. And Souders’ work helps to illustrate just how so. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Vistas” © Brea Souders\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/brea-souders-vistas#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Within the simple structure of Souders’ pictures, there lie countless threads to untangle. Though beyond interpretation, what might be more valuable is to consider the various questions that <em>Vistas</em> poses to us: </p> \n<p>Where are we now positioned in relation to the old traditions of American landscape photography? What was asked of landscape photographs in the 19th century, and what is asked of them today? How are we ourselves positioned in relation to the world within the omnipotent virtual realm? How has our relationship to the natural world changed in the last one-hundred and fifty years, or in the past five years for that matter? What ancient stories can we still connect to? What aspects of us, as humans, can never change? As wireless technology has placed all the world’s knowledge within the air that we breathe, what has this condition done to our curiosity, our imagination? Who are we on the internet, and what is the nature of an identity that becomes networked, fragmented across platforms, monitored, and mined for information? And how much further will we venture into the virtual world? What frontiers are left to explore in a digitized reality, and what will we leave behind in this journey? </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Vistas” © Brea Souders\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/brea-souders-vistas#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Our photographic age is changing rapidly, excitingly even, and as technological shifts have churned us into a consistent state of upheaval, past photographic traditions must adapt rapidly to keep pace. Brea Souders’ <em>Vistas</em> represents a new kind of American landscape photograph, and a necessary one. Her pictures acknowledge the past if only to better consider the present. We don’t need more photographic documents of the landscape; it’s all been mapped and accounted for. What we need in this moment are thoughtfully considered reflections of what the land is now, and how our relationships to it are changing. The subject of Souders’ pictures is us. Me and you now staring into our screens, maybe wishing we were someplace else. </p> \n<hr> \n <p><br> </br></p>\n <p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n <ul>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/michael-lange-wald-landscapes-of-memory\">WALD: Landscapes of Memory</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/kim-llerena-american-blues\">American Blues</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/lensculture-editors-photobooks-2017-23-curators-pick-their-favorites\">Photobooks 2017: 23 Curators Pick Their Favorites</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/jim-vecchi-memoria-scaduta\">Memoria Scaduta</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/claudius-schulze-state-of-nature\">State of Nature</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/vladimir-vyatkin-soldiers-on-duty-the-duty-of-photographers\">Soldiers on Duty, The Duty of Photographers</a></li>\n </ul>\n <section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n  <figure>\n   <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/514d07c2-b408-4b68-8024-fc70d2dbece4.jpg\" />\n   <figcaption>\n    Untitled from the series \"Vistas\"\n   </figcaption>\n  </figure>\n  <figure>\n   <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/2da07093-5723-41f0-884c-f6add3e5268d.jpg\" />\n   <figcaption>\n    Untitled from the series
