ttps://photos.lensculture.com/large/c5dcce8d-e0a2-4745-8892-2f3bbc867fab.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn51@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-06-446_b1cb6299d62e7ec6.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1b845200-fadf-4914-bf2c-8591c5a8d356.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn88@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-04-210_a44507188a218c13.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b2b9e7fd-ff51-4528-b191-a6602af785ae.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn64@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-08-566_d3660f25e239dcdc.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f0f51f6c-4a4d-4b03-bf66-fe36200ca191.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn8@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-00-900_bc87fc09719d6a8a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/cef98eae-94f5-4245-9e26-bea972ff9eb0.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn68@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-56-385_b8eaed85b480b850.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ccac728f-cc6e-4578-9b1f-3bfdb7d13ff5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn87@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-55-268_cfc88ecb841fb9f4.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/74c2d3e3-0307-46b8-9237-0061f825518f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn79@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-06-147_b8f73b9e5c68e87e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7ddf84e9-3275-49af-bcd5-ad1b8bee5bd7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn44@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-11-353_8579874072740765.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e69db387-6e34-43a0-8962-2842e07c4f72.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn55@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-58-040_b38372b08fac145e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ef03cce9-e0d9-4a64-b649-6688aa090ffa.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn44@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-10-436_191b1c7607b354e2.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d400c2c7-f420-43ef-a560-0292b5afc0f4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn28@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-08-363_29eda7d6e3674d4f.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066818},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Cross Road Blues","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/oli-kellett-cross-road-blues","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Cross Road Blues</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Oli Kellett</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/31f1729d-7361-402f-b65a-e390efd08d38.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  This light-soaked street photography spotlights passersby as main characters in a classic theatrical performance.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>The pervasive beauty of street photography lies in its ability to frame our disregarded surroundings as centre stage during a lively performance. Everyday passersby become the lead and supporting roles in a relatable screenplay about daily life, freezing interesting candid moments into a set of narrative stills that might have otherwise gone overlooked. For photographer Oli Kellett, this genre is pushed a step further in his series <i>Cross Road Blues</i>, where vibrant pockets of natural light poke through surrounding architecture to spotlight his subjects, as though they are delivering a crucial set of lines during a play. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Cross Road Blues (Hubbard St, Chicago) © Oli Kellett\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/oli-kellett-cross-road-blues#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p> The binding context in each of Kellett’s images is their setting at a crossroads – a familiar place and metaphor for the tension we encounter throughout life. “We live in an era of fake news, political polarization and algorithmic echo chambers,” Kellett explains. “Our experience of the world is fractured as we live out multiple identities on and offline. But crossroads are a democratic place; we all have to wait.”<br> <br> Kellett’s images harness the incredible power of ambient light. As it passes through buildings, dancing across the street below, each subject appears in a contemplative state, whether alone or huddled together with a group of other people waiting to cross. Kellett reflects, “On average, we will spend five years ‘waiting’ during our lifetime. Being held at a ‘DON’T WALK’ sign allows us a few seconds, and occasionally minutes, to just be with ourselves and remember who we are.” </br></br></p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Cross Road Blues (Figueroa St, LA) © Oli Kellett\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/oli-kellett-cross-road-blues#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>While Kellett’s images stand as striking compositions on their own, he hopes that as people spend time with the photographs, they absorb the metaphorical weight of the visuals, contemplating our own existence in a fast-paced, modern world. “At this time of uncertainty and change in America’s history, I’m looking for a moment where individuals are dwarfed by what surrounds them, appearing lost but searching for something,” he explains. “They then go on their way, whichever direction that may be.” </p>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/barbican-art-gallery-constructing-worlds-photography-and-architecture-in-the-modern-age\">Constructing Worlds: Photography and Architecture in the Modern Age</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/jason-tannen-noir-city\">Noir City</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/shira-gold-shock\">Shock</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/fuku-heavy-light-recent-photography-and-video-from-japan\">Heavy Light: Recent Photography and Video from Japan</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/sebastien-tixier-allanngorpoq-being-transformed\">Allanngorpoq: Being Transformed</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/marta-azevedo-black-faces\">Black Faces</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/31f1729d-7361-402f-b65a-e390efd08d38.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Cross Road Blues (Grand Ave, Chicago)\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/35ef9a37-4d0c-4fb3-9b36-a41ec15dcd6f.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Cross Road Blues (Hubbard St, Chicago)\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b3beb10a-e531-4435-a8e5-15030925e78c.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Cross Road Blues (Louisiana St, Houston)\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a421d389-7609-4118-9ad6-bfed05857d93.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Cross Road Blues (Peachtree St, Atlanta)\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 02 Jul 2020 11:35:46 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/31f1729d-7361-402f-b65a-e390efd08d38.jpg","linkMd5":"f6d68c805d582eb4f48cafe83e4adac0","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn7@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-47-659_18bec4e8f2765600.webp","destWidth":900,"destHeight":1600,"sourceBytes":207461,"destBytes":104852,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/31f1729d-7361-402f-b65a-e390efd08d38.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn7@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-47-659_18bec4e8f2765600.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/31f1729d-7361-402f-b65a-e390efd08d38.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn16@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-53-194_b3f674d900f5fab9.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/35ef9a37-4d0c-4fb3-9b36-a41ec15dcd6f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn52@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-01-460_8a469f42217febf0.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b3beb10a-e531-4435-a8e5-15030925e78c.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn79@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-55-944_af456bc89062dfa9.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a421d389-7609-4118-9ad6-bfed05857d93.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn20@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-08-838_a78f91b10331a972.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066813},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Don’t Lie to Me","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/paulo-coqueiro-don-t-lie-to-me","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Don’t Lie to Me</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Paulo Coqueiro</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/45aa26bd-d496-4ee1-970f-6f39d902aafb.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Through layers of mind-bending work, Brazilian artist Paulo Coqueiro weaves a photo-based approach to writing — revealing mysteries and mistruths surrounding the disappearance of photojournalist Tito Ferraz.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>“Remember, I am lying to you.” Politically-entrenched photojournalist Tito Ferraz went missing from his home in December, 2016. Over the course of several months, the outspoken photographer communicated across his network of 5000 Facebook friends, dropping breadcrumbs which would ultimately end in his sudden and dramatic disappearance. A threatening letter arrives. His apartment is broken into. Hard drives are destroyed. Evidence is collected. Everything gets documented through forensic-style photographs. Flyers go up through his community in Bahia, Brazil demanding answers and justice. What happened to Tito Ferraz? </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Most research indicates that Tito Ferraz was born on August 2 1969 in the countryside of Bahia. © Paulo Coqueiro\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/paulo-coqueiro-don-t-lie-to-me#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>But the more pressing question is, <em>who </em>is Tito Ferraz? On July 7, 2020, I met mastermind and artist, Paulo Coqueiro, through Skype after earlier communications via email and WhatsApp messaging. He appeared on my mobile phone in near monochrome—wearing a black t-shirt, ebony-rimmed glasses, a salt and pepper beard, sitting in a room of alabaster walls with a smooth, white air-conditioner hanging high beside him. Save for a few books on a distant shelf, everything surrounding him was either black or white which is exactly what I needed. My head had been swirling in the gray. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Police discover that the photographs of Tito’s face are montages. © Paulo Coqueiro\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/paulo-coqueiro-don-t-lie-to-me#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Tito Ferraz is not real. During a two-year project, <em>Não Minta Para Mim</em> (<em>Don’t Lie to Me</em>), Coqueiro created this fictional character, pressing brilliantly deep into questions surrounding the implied truthfulness of a documentary approach to photography. “I was interested in the power of images to forge truths; how it’s possible to write using photographs.” </p> \n<p>Coqueiro took this a step further by meticulously crafting a fake Facebook account. He built a friend list of photographers, curators and others within the art world for a more believable profile, entering into a handful of virtual conversations with unsuspecting ‘friends’ where he often directed the exchange towards questions on fiction in photography. He would invite them for coffee, book launches, exhibitions—but Ferraz always came up with some sort of an excuse, explaining how they had just missed each other in his apology the next day, sent through Facebook Messenger. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>The technical police report points to fraud in photographs published by Tito Ferraz on Facebook. Some were made in places other than those identified in their posts; others were constructed from montages. © Paulo Coqueiro\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/paulo-coqueiro-don-t-lie-to-me#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Coqueiro being the one orchestrating these missed connections would, himself, visit the meeting places and take photographs to post to Ferraz’s profile for yet another layer of legitimacy. I lean in closely to listen, trying to keep up with the fluid movement between ‘he’ and ‘me’ as he maintains a clear distinction between character and reality. At times, those two words were the only thread I had to keep fact and fiction from getting tangled up in my own understanding as he shared an image of a newspaper clipping or spoke of a police investigation. Why do we default to believing in truths despite knowing the messenger has been feeding us lies? The story folds you into it. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Photographer and expert Paulo Coqueiro was hired to try to recover the information from Tito’s hard drive. © Paulo Coqueiro\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/paulo-coqueiro-don-t-lie-to-me#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>In the chapter following Ferraz’s disappearance a hard drive is recovered containing the portraits of forty-one people which Coqueiro has bound into a book. He has also created a series of short films, one believable enough to have me scratching my head once again: “Is Ferraz real?” He records forty-one people who have befriended the fake Facebook account and interviews them as witnesses of Ferraz’s existence (none of them knew about the fictional character).<br><br> </br></br></p> \n<blockquote>\n “I would not say I use the character to lie, but to demonstrate the fragility of an alleged documentary truth. Or how credulous we are in the face of photographic images.” \n</blockquote> \n<p>Coqueiro released a portrait of Ferraz in the style of a police sketch, crafted from various facial features of each of the photographers he interviewed, having taken their photos while visiting their homes and studios. When they gaze into this likeness of Tito Ferraz, they unknowingly look at fragments of themselves. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>An investigation was opened to investigate the disappearance of photographer Tito Ferraz. © Paulo Coqueiro\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/paulo-coqueiro-don-t-lie-to-me#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>In a striking reversal of roles between the rebellious photojournalist and Coqueiro’s act of fiction, <em>Don’t Lie to Me</em> became viewed as a political threat. Mere hours before the opening of the <em>Winds of Time</em> exhibit at Lianzhou Foto Festival in 2018, censors confiscated some of the work without explanation. Weeks earlier, by coincidence, renowned photographer Lu Guang went missing after stirring up dust by speaking out on controversial issues in China. It would be a year before he re-emerged from police detention, punished for showing that which does not want to be seen. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Tito’s self-portrait consists of several layers portrait of the interviewed photographers he spoke to. © Paulo Coqueiro\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/paulo-coqueiro-don-t-lie-to-me#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>I, myself, posted a photo to a public Facebook page earlier this year after a virtual colleague asked me to take a selfie holding a ‘Where is Kajol?’ sign. Bangladeshi journalist, Safiqul Islam Kajol went missing under similar, mysterious circumstances and was discovered nearly two months later in police custody. He stands accused of “engaging in extortion by obtaining information illegally and publishing false, intimidating, and defamatory information via Facebook and Messenger,” as reported by the Dhaka Tribune.<br><br>Deceit can reveal a great many truths: Tito Ferraz has not yet been found. </br></br></p> \n<hr> \n <div> \n  <br> </br>\n </div>\n <p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n <ul>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/laura-pannack-youth-without-age-life-without-death-chapter-1\">Youth Without Age, Life Without Death: Chapter 1</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/mary-frey-domestic-rituals-and-real-life-dramas\">Domestic Rituals and Real Life Dramas</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/francis-hodgson-on-photography-and-storytelling-2\">On Photography and Storytelling</a></li>\n  <li><a Weapons</a></li>\n </ul>\n <section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n  <figure>\n   <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/8c3902ef-870c-41a9-8f04-47c95f3614cc.jpg\" />\n  </figure>\n  <figure>\n +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/45aa26bd-d496-4ee1-970f-6f39d902aafb.jpg","linkMd5":"a875b1f7cc5cf388d478583682131e17","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn68@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-46-973_0d52add04608385a.webp","destWidth":751,"destHeight":501,"sourceBytes":325753,"destBytes":76892,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/45aa26bd-d496-4ee1-970f-6f39d902aafb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn68@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-46-973_0d52add04608385a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/8c3902ef-870c-41a9-8f04-47c95f3614cc.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn28@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-53-432_335ac1f22bd7fe34.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/fa48c75e-013f-440b-8907-c8a79721894b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn23@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-02-004_b068c6e51557d323.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/080eb59c-7018-418d-a1fd-5ff543897c21.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn83@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-10-635_dfef39a7bd46d99b.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/0e3815cc-5a03-483f-a02e-d46b39ff7ca2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn95@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-57-715_7ee260369afc3a3e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/45aa26bd-d496-4ee1-970f-6f39d902aafb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn27@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-02-100_ac1ba84a5ab07f05.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9f359afa-982a-4024-8c54-46d0b733e1d3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn19@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-58-099_02e712aa025c447c.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b7bd8e9f-f918-48a1-ad32-f0841c4f52e0.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn60@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-16-173_b81090ae1c9674b8.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c9b1f87a-26f3-40aa-be27-83674828f29a.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn63@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-07-148_4efbbe9c8d359835.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f4761ec2-5296-40ae-b0eb-8505344448ab.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-14-713_82b684d692e8398e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e3ab39d9-7900-4353-9402-909f2ba48686.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn24@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-11-171_5ca744b2e2b3a553.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066809},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Hiding from Baba Yaga","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/nanna-heitmann-hiding-from-baba-yaga","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Hiding from Baba Yaga</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Nanna Heitmann</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/f212ccfd-9a4d-493b-9ec0-f9e470e52ffd.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Nanna&nbsp;Heitmann combines elements of traditional documentary road trip photography with elements of Russian art and folklore in her depictions of an eclectic mix of individuals, interiors and landscapes.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>German photographer Nanna Heitmann grew up hearing Russian fairy tales from her Russian mother and grandmother. A popular recurring character in these stories was Baba Yaga, a dangerous witch with an appetite for children who lived in a small hut in the middle of the woods. In one story, the witch takes a girl known as Vasilisa the Beautiful as her prisoner. However, with the help of a black cat, Vasilisa escapes. As the girl runs from the witch, she drops a magical towel and comb behind her. A deep, broad river emerges from the towel and a thick forest from the comb, so thick Baba Yaga cannot find her. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Hiding from Baba Yaga” © Nanna Heitmann\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/nanna-heitmann-hiding-from-baba-yaga#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>For her series, <em>Hiding from Baba Yaga</em>, Heitmann returned to her mother’s country of origin, to visit the remote region of her childhood fairy tales. She was delighted to find it reminded her of Ivan Bilibin’s illustrations of Vasilisa’s fable. Using this story as a starting point for exploration, she traced the Yenisei River downstream in a Russian Jeep packed with camping equipment, documenting life along its banks. Following the longest rivers in the world from the Tuva Republic northward through Siberia took Heitmann through the wilderness of the Siberian taiga, exposing her to the locals living in social isolation on the outskirts modern Slavic society. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Hiding from Baba Yaga” © Nanna Heitmann\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/nanna-heitmann-hiding-from-baba-yaga#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Like Vasilisa hiding from Baba Yaga in a forest of her own creation, Heitmann’s subjects are sheltered by the isolation and harsh climate of the woods surrounding the Yenisei River. Since the collapse of the Soviet Union, this remote area has lost its infrastructure; residences have no access to goods, technologies, or government services, so the region tends to attract people hiding from society or seeking new realities—escaped criminals, recluses, and Eastern Orthodox Old Believers. Heitmann’s environmental portraits reveal how these people shape and are shaped by their surroundings. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Hiding from Baba Yaga” © Nanna Heitmann\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/nanna-heitmann-hiding-from-baba-yaga#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Viewers may draw parallels between <em>Hiding from Baba Yaga</em> and <em>Sleeping by the Mississippi</em>, Alec Soth’s photographic journey along the neglected banks of his country’s longest river. However, Heitmann’s work also references distinctly Russian concepts and esthetics. Her wanderlust-based process echoes that of late-nineteenth-century Russian painters, such as Ivan Shishkin. Like Shishkin, her use of a light palette in the depiction of poverty and suffering reveals the beauty of resilient rural Russian folk culture. Her gentle eye conveys their dignity and humanity, allowing the viewer to consider them with curiosity and empathy. Ultimately, Heitmann combines elements of traditional documentary road trip photography with elements of Russian art and folklore, in her depictions of the eclectic mix of individuals, interiors, landscapes she encountered on her journey. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Hiding from Baba Yaga” © Nanna Heitmann\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/nanna-heitmann-hiding-from-baba-yaga#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><br> </br></p>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/junku-nishimura-a-nocturnal-visitor\">A Nocturnal Visitor</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/blink-network-on-the-ground-at-the-center-after-the-quake\">On the Ground, At the Center, After the Quake</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/rie-yamada-familie-werden\">Familie Werden</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/giacomo-brunelli-new-york-noir\">New York Noir</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/sara-angelucci-arboretum\">Arboretum</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/jean-vincent-simonet-in-bloom\">In Bloom</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f5837b00-6bfb-4452-affd-cc01c7588b8b.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/04820033-cd9f-482c-af2d-1eb15ddb7def.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7127934a-7d62-42f2-a384-9a0a9f75fa2b.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 11 May 2020 10:19:28 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/f212ccfd-9a4d-493b-9ec0-f9e470e52ffd.jpg","linkMd5":"a837a368110ddb4dc79765e531746460","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn39@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-48-447_00d23db6a2bc26f7.webp","destWidth":1124,"destHeight":2000,"sourceBytes":293337,"destBytes":131628,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/f212ccfd-9a4d-493b-9ec0-f9e470e52ffd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn39@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-48-447_00d23db6a2bc26f7.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f5837b00-6bfb-4452-affd-cc01c7588b8b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn20@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-05-124_fbb485f7da2c5a49.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/04820033-cd9f-482c-af2d-1eb15ddb7def.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn36@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-13-170_baaf6bc342f24a24.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f212ccfd-9a4d-493b-9ec0-f9e470e52ffd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn28@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-12-467_e735f923b81cc2cf.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/821fcdbc-3b9b-4e0e-afce-08f86b80337b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn15@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-16-237_51ba930e9fe47f26.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ab1c3144-a4cc-4bcc-9e62-adcb20c2980e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn43@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-55-414_7c75dcaa672e2f3f.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7127934a-7d62-42f2-a384-9a0a9f75fa2b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn28@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-53-415_290a38d08ea90a86.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066817},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Deana Lawson — Aperture Monograph","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/deana-lawson-deana-lawson-aperture-monograph","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Deana Lawson — Aperture Monograph</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Deana Lawson</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/971a7f46-ab06-4a07-81f0-32cbcb1f14b3.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  These&nbsp;photographs contain multitudes — references to African diaspora, complex emotions, unspoken dreams, dignity, pride, love, visible scars, the trappings of household circumstance, the tenderness of generations.&nbsp;\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Deana Lawson is nothing short of a force, and the photographer’s monograph published by Aperture (2018) is a testament to her power as one of the great artists of our generation. Her photographs contain multitudes — references to the African diaspora, complex emotions, unspoken dreams, dignity, pride, love, visible scars, the trappings of household circumstance, and the tenderness of generations. The beauty is in the details around the edges as much as it’s in the heroic quality of the subjects at its center. </p> \n<p>At first glance, the book is simultaneously regal and unassuming – its deep burgundy cover is silky and luscious, albeit visually minimal, featuring no cues for information aside from the photographer’s full name inlaid on its front in gold. This measured simplicity continues onto the pages bound within, which, in addition to a selection of 40 color images, feature two important pieces of writing. The first is an essay by Zadie Smith titled “Through the Portal: Locating the Magnificent,” a poetic introduction that vividly contextualizes the work, and the second is an extensive conversation between Lawson and fellow artist Athur Jafa, presented for readers to ponder on the monograph’s final pages — a thoughtful conclusion to direct engagement with each image. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>© Deana Lawson\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/deana-lawson-deana-lawson-aperture-monograph#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Embracing the black body as the central feature in her work, Lawson upholds domestic scenarios as magical environments, emboldening her subjects to be comfortable in their own skin as they pose in front of her camera. Unlike the potentially voyeuristic images that often result from photographing nude bodies, each of Lawson’s photographs seem to reflect the photographer just as much as they reflect their central figures. In front of Lawson’s lens, there is no encouragement to quiet down or play it coy. Instead, the individuals own their space and skin, dominating it regardless of the oppression that faces them when they step outside of the house.<br> </br></p> \n<blockquote>\n “Outside a Lawson portrait you might be working three jobs, just keeping your head above water, struggling. But inside her frame you are beautiful, imperious, unbroken, unfallen.”Zadie Smith \n</blockquote> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>© Deana Lawson\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/deana-lawson-deana-lawson-aperture-monograph#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>From backyards to bedrooms, everyday spaces are transformed into striking backdrops, made crisp and theatrical through Lawson’s choice of medium- and large-format processes. This fine line between normalcy and drama is what defines Lawson’s work as something seminal and immediately recognizable. While each image stands powerful on its own, it’s wonderful to encounter them sequenced in conversation with one another, with interjections of other snapshots and archival photography that flesh out the artist’s inspiration for her timeless series.<br> </br></p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>© Deana Lawson\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/deana-lawson-deana-lawson-aperture-monograph#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Translating the power of Lawson’s photographs to the confined pages of a book is no easy task, but the monograph does it just right, allowing each image to speak for itself in an endless stream of plates that feature no extensive captions or explanations. The index of details are listed at the back for reference, so that the reader is not distracted from directly engaging with the visuals before them, finding new and familiar details in each frame. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>© Deana Lawson\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/deana-lawson-deana-lawson-aperture-monograph#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>And while we never actually see an image of the photographer, we feel her presence in each piece, and again when her words are presented to us at the very end of the book. “Someone said that I’m ruthless when it comes to what I want,” Lawson explains in her conversation with Jafa. “Maybe that’s part of it: I have an image in mind that I have to make. It burns so deeply that I have to make it, and I don’t care what people are going to think.”<br><br> </br></br></p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>© Deana Lawson\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/deana-lawson-deana-lawson-aperture-monograph#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<div class=\"article-incut -book-incut\"> \n <div class=\"picture\"> \n  <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/books/18050-deana-lawson-an-aperture-monograph\"></a> \n </div> \n <div class=\"title\">\n  Deana Lawson: An Aperture Monograph\n  <br> </br>\n </div> \n <div class=\"author\">\n  by Photographs by Dean Lawson, Essay by Zadie Smith, Interview by Arthur Jafa\n  <br> </br>\n </div> \n <div class=\"publisher\">\n  Publisher: Aperture\n  <br>ISBN: 978-1-59711-422-6<br> </br></br>\n </div> \n</div>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a Editorial Portrait</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/birgit-puve-by-the-lake\">By the Lake</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/simona-bonanno-24-hours-90-years\">24 Hours, 90 Years</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/971a7f46-ab06-4a07-81f0-32cbcb1f14b3.jpg","linkMd5":"f43376132590c131b6a097da8f824aa8","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn23@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-48-436_3a3f8521c29f792f.webp","destWidth":892,"destHeight":1587,"sourceBytes":185256,"destBytes":90214,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/971a7f46-ab06-4a07-81f0-32cbcb1f14b3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn23@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-48-436_3a3f8521c29f792f.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4601c4d4-9814-4667-8e5c-593c954795a1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn84@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-02-509_ffa43d3276febccf.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/6791f7a6-2b8d-4021-afa0-876c824e69bc.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn35@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-06-164_a100f169ef99ad44.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7b35785f-f2d5-4fce-b129-aebb3d97b01d.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn7@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-53-979_807fad3c4ddfd8ed.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/6ca1b0d5-c40d-4d27-a567-fd5eb2f74365.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn63@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-17-480_d8cfcc268cf6d047.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/971a7f46-ab06-4a07-81f0-32cbcb1f14b3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn100@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-05-050_b573589bff9c5a69.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066815},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Afuera: Rooftops and Balconies in Times of Isolation","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/luis-cobelo-afuera-rooftops-and-balconies-in-times-of-isolation","description":"\n        <hgroup><h1>Afuera: Rooftops and Balconies in Times of Isolation</h1><h3 class=\"fl-author\">Luis Cobelo</h3></hgroup><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/284a9b5b-1edb-40ae-820c-df4c4319602f.jpg\"/><figcaption>Lovely short video — Bathed in the brilliant warm Spanish sun, the residents of Barcelona are limited to rooftops and balconies for solitary exercise and fresh air during the covid-19 lockdown.</figcaption></figure>\n\n<p><br>\n</p>\n<p>I was born to look.\n</p>\n<p>Our outside (<em>afuera</em>) was suspended and we retired without protest. We were afraid. Suddenly the deafening noise within us is louder and we crave the external one back, to distract from it.\n</p>\n<p>I look at a section of a city: Barcelona. It could have been anywhere. Without the strategic privileged position (a 180-degree view terrace) in which I find myself, I could not have done it. In fact, I never meant to, I just looked out the balcony and saw an older man walking on the roof, just like he would on the street, but without shop windows or people; only with himself. My immediate reaction was to make a video, not a photo. I was attending a unique, private, historical event. The man is doing well, he is not sitting on a couch all day.  He moves, he exercises. His thoughts maybe are in the future, longing for that <em>afuera</em>.\n</p>\n<p>I open my field of vision a little more and there they all were. I had a feeling that something was going to happen and I was there, with my looking machine. Life moved to rooftops and balconies. There is no precise time, although good weather lures them outside. Contemplation and confinement became a way of survival. People with balconies look out expecting to see something that is clearly empty, some kiss or hug each other, others just talk, quite a few do some kind of exercise, look at the horizon, play ball, sunbathe, take selfies…\n</p>\n<blockquote>I had a feeling that something was going to happen and I was there, with my looking machine. Life moved to rooftops and balconies.\n</blockquote>\n<p>No one sees me. I’m hidden, they don’t know that I exist. For the moment. I observe, with some nervousness: the sensation of being discovered is the excitement of a voyeur. The smartphone has become an extension of my body, it is what connects me to the world. A world in collective hysteria. So I prefer to come back to the roofs and the balconies around me. Where real people are just waiting with enormous resilience.\n</p>\n<p>That older man keeps walking on the roof. This vision has become the emotional thermometer of my confinement. If I see him, I feel good. Whenever the time to go out will come, who knows, the desired routine will return and he’ll go out again, watching people move, the cars, the noise of the city. Then, I will stop meddling.\n</p>\n<p>It will be weird, for everyone.\n</p>\n<p>—Luis Cobelo\n</p>\n<hr>\n<p><em><strong>Editor’s note:</strong> We discovered this new work (and many more excellent visual stories) on the great new site created by the visionaries behind the Cortona on the Move photo festival — Be sure to check out <a href=\"https://covid19visualproject.org/en/\">The Covid19 Visual Project</a>, and submit your own stories for consideration, too.</em><br>\n</p><p>Enjoy more great photography:</p><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/walid-raad-deutsche-borse-photography-prize-2007\">Deutsche Börse Photography Prize 2007</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/artur-urbanski-live-view-our-point-and-shoot-memories\">Live View: Our Point and Shoot Memories</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/thomas-meinicke-havana-cabs\">Havana Cabs</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/garry-winogrand-garry-winogrand-visions-from-the-street-portraits-of-america\">Garry Winogrand: Visions from the Street, Portraits of America</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/chino-otsuka-photo-album\">Photo Album</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/lensculture-design-call-for-entries-lensculture-art-photography-awards-2018-3\">Call for Entries! LensCulture Art Photography Awards 2018</a></li></ul><section class=\"fl-slideshow\"><figure><img ttps://photos.lensculture.com/large/4067aae2-f16a-41cf-a400-87b2fea7b6ed.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn12@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-12-710_c4c04b1297f403b5.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3a3bada4-82af-418c-9f7f-a596402232e7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn40@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-52-021_775586acbde5b631.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/22ee40c4-4ede-44cb-8205-61a253e94ce4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn32@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-07-957_0125c724b39a1c42.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a908e278-ad32-4a2d-a372-2dd200f9ce42.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn51@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-15-374_ad23b1f93a973b1c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066816},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"this archive has no legs","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/srinivas-kuruganti-this-archive-has-no-legs","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>this archive has no legs</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Srinivas Kuruganti</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/fe2a3577-acd4-4436-940c-4dec54b8268d.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Inviting strangers to go through his photographs, Srinivas Kuruganti’s five day experiment turned the personal public, exploring the fluidity of narrative and the boundaries of the archive.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>What happens when an archive is put in the hands of others? Over the phone from his apartment in New Delhi, photographer Srinivas Kuruganti gushes while describing the chaos, creativity and camaraderie that came together in his project <em>this archive has no legs; </em>a project realized within the framework of <em>Five Million Incidents</em>, 2019-2020, conceived by Goethe Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan, in collaboration with Raqs Media Collective.<span class=\"redactor-invisible-space\"> </span>The archive in question has its roots a couple of decades back. It was 1992 and he had just moved to the Lower East Village in New York City from the quieter town of Berkeley in California, leaving behind an engineering degree. “It was the 90s,” he declares, like it is self-explanatory, before launching into a flurry of lively descriptions that fill in the blanks. It was vibrant, packed with different communities of artists, mass public protests and concerts in the parks. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>“Untitled” from “39 East First Street” © Srinivas Kuruganti\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/srinivas-kuruganti-this-archive-has-no-legs#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a>\n<br> <p>It turned out to be fecund ground for Srinivas, who had already started taking photographs of his friends and surroundings while studying in California. “Looking back, I can’t remember thinking that I was taking these photographs with the aim of doing something with them,” he admits. “We—my roommate Peter and I—had cameras, so we just began to take photos of our friends. We would experiment, make portraits and take nudes of this tight community we’d formed, sometimes at our apartments, during protests and parties, or at picnics in Central Park. The process of making these sets of photographs from my time in New York was almost collaborative,” he adds. His only regret: “I didn’t photograph enough of the street over those many years.” </p> \n <div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n </div>“Untitled” from “39 East First Street” © Srinivas Kuruganti<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/srinivas-kuruganti-this-archive-has-no-legs#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> <p><br> </br></p> <p>These photographs might have remained tucked away among Srinivas’ three decades of archived material, that sit in ten metal waterproof trunks at a friend’s Bombay office, had it not been for the chance to house-sit for another friend in Goa while she was away. Using this solitude and space, the photographer began the daunting process of creating a system to catalogue his own sprawling body of work. Since his early days photographing his community of friends and their collective activities, he has turned his attention to building a documentary practice that focuses on environmental issues ranging from coal mining in Dhanbad, ship-breaking yards<span class=\"redactor-invisible-space\"></span> and industrial pollution. </p> \n <div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n </div>“Untitled” from “39 East First Street” © Srinivas Kuruganti<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/srinivas-kuruganti-this-archive-has-no-legs#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> <p><br> </br></p> <p>In bringing order to his archive of photographs, Srinivas was left with the feeling that he “wanted to make a book of these photographs from this time with little notes”. But in arranging, rearranging and arranging the images again, he felt that he was too close to the work. He’d find himself looking at them and thinking: “Oh wow, we really did all those things!” In order to find an objective eye in relation to this body of work, he decided to invite other people into the picture; to sift, select and stitch together a narrative from these photographs. Instead of keeping this intervention at the level of friends and practitioners alone, he devised <em>this archive has no legs</em>: an open invitation to anyone and everyone. </p> \n <div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n </div>Installation shot of “this archive has no legs” at “Five Million Incidents” 2019-2020, conceived by Goethe Institut / Max Mueller Bhavan in collaboration with Raqs Media Collective. © Srinivas Kuruganti<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/srinivas-kuruganti-this-archive-has-no-legs#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> <p>The project took place at the Max Mueller Bhavan in New Delhi over five days earlier this year, opening its doors to the public to go through Srinivas’ archives—physical prints of the photographs from his New York Days—and tack them on a wall to create their own flow. At the end of each day, the images still left upon the ‘edit wall’ would be printed and hand-bound into a book. “I didn’t want the viewers to be passive with regards to this work. I wanted to see how they would come up with an edit, or put it into a story. How would it be shown if it was treated just as visual material? I wanted to see it from the outside,” he says of his idea. </p> <p>The photographer was also present the whole time, open to interactions with those who had come into his space at the venue, but also to observe the choices made by those rifling through the photos and then putting their take up on the wall. While each collection changed, patterns soon emerged. “Every day the edits would change. And even though someone would remove or build upon the previous person’s work, something of the previous iterations was still up there. In that way, each person’s input always stayed behind,” he says. </p> \n <div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n </div>“Diptych 4, Day 1” from “this archive has no legs” © Srinivas Kuruganti<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/srinivas-kuruganti-this-archive-has-no-legs#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n <div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n </div>“Diptych 4, Day 2” from “this archive has no legs” © Srinivas Kuruganti<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/srinivas-kuruganti-this-archive-has-no-legs#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a><span class=\"redactor-invisible-space\"></span><br> <p>There are other little things that Srinivas spied on regarding the choices that people made vis-a-vis the images, which have helped him gain more clarity on the directions he’d like to take with his photobook of the work. “It isn’t like any of the images on the ‘edit wall’ or ‘bound books’ were chronological but I liked to see separate, disparate images being brought together. It is a good starting point to think the way I’d go about it. At that time, I didn’t agree with too many of the decisions but now, I’ve come around. I can see some meaning in their methods,” he offers. In noticing the many reasons behind the placement and purpose of these choices, he has been freed into settling on his own logic in arranging them. </p> <p>In terms of the visual material itself, Srinivas saw that people tended to lean towards the images that “aren’t quiet”. He found that viewers gravitated towards the “gritty”, both in terms of aesthetic—more contrasty black-and-whites, and content—more graphic, sexual images. For lack of a better word, Srinivas settles on “eye-candy” to describe these choices. Without passing judgment, he explains: “it is not wrong. It is just a different impulse.” Taking heed of these preferences has pushed him to think of the overall rhythm of the photobook, the many ways he can play with the different sections, punctuating the pace with the quiet and the dynamic images. </p> \n  <div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n  </div>“No Faces” from “this archive has no legs” © Srinivas Kuruganti<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/srinivas-kuruganti-this-archive-has-no-legs#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> <p><br> </br></p> <p>One of the interventions during the five days of <em>this archive has no legs</em> that has stood out in Srinivas’ mind is one he describes as “the one with hidden faces”. In this version, one of the viewers had arranged photos without prominently featuring any of his friends’ faces on the edit wall, instead focusing on shapes and shadows, tangents and textures, and other details. “At first, I was taken back by the choices because the people in photographs are so important to the work. This work is about my friends and the familiar places to us,” he says. </p> <p>But even then, he didn’t get clouded by this reason and made a record of this edit. Looking at it now, he’s had a change of heart. “I’ve come to see that the work isn’t about my friends alone. It is also about my early experimentations as a photographer where looking back I can see that I was interested in these things—in building a frame. And while I might have taken these photos instinctively, from a distance I can see the other elements that went into making the photograph more clearly,” he adds. </p> \n  <div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n  </div>“Untitled” from “39 East First Street” © Srinivas Kuruganti<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/srinivas-kuruganti-this-archive-has-no-legs#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> <p><br> </br></p> <p>The exercise of welcoming people to participate in his archive didn’t just allow for the viewers to peek into his past and place it in the contemporary; it also seems to have allowed Srinivas the distance and spark to put these photographs in a book. This gesture is by no means unfamiliar to the photographer: the impulse to ‘share’ his work seems to be a long-thread that runs through the three decades of his practice. Even in the early days, he would make double prints of each of his photographs: one for himself and the other one was for the person in the picture. “I’d like to think, this isn’t just me reliving those days. It is also them,” he says, hopefully. In opening up the relationship between photographer, poser and public, Srinivas allows each one of us to employ these images as touchstones to our memories of “those days” too. </p><p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n  <ul>\n   <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/cecilia-paredes-eternally-camouflaged\">Eternally Camouflaged</a></li>\n   <li><a &lt;br&gt;from the new South Africa</a></li>\n   <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/sharbendu-de-imagined-homeland\">Imagined Homeland</a></li>\n  </ul>\n  <section +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/fe2a3577-acd4-4436-940c-4dec54b8268d.jpg","linkMd5":"8dd8c2b391ee9ee63e4761cea52fa490","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn51@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-48-212_b126a7f405a8dc2f.webp","destWidth":803,"destHeight":574,"sourceBytes":675267,"destBytes":69762,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/fe2a3577-acd4-4436-940c-4dec54b8268d.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn51@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-48-212_b126a7f405a8dc2f.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/0944fdb8-f560-4d1b-b4a2-c5f5cd8ba20f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn43@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-14-885_d20d6eb23805285a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/22a5567d-21ed-47d6-94c5-6dc9f6770ca0.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn16@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-04-998_9c0fafcda4b4692b.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d8f3e563-9299-40fe-85b1-dacdc2eacb47.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn11@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-05-462_4cc1f28049fab54d.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/6126807c-8312-4fdf-b140-b7e6ae87ae7f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn97@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-51-633_d6d1d2a6548ed8b7.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/58bd7648-1821-4cd2-b814-8812088e82bc.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn68@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-07-042_35d1a36fa4536b4d.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9b01b08f-01a7-40a5-820c-598ca0e6af28.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn52@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-59-340_206fdbe41b85843e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d3dd6e4d-c316-4075-aeda-6c2f8d4deccd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn11@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-03-906_6e0f524177c114d5.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ece3e665-bba4-43e7-99c8-1dd816e2a305.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn44@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-13-709_e1a855bf05315050.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/fe2a3577-acd4-4436-940c-4dec54b8268d.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn27@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-15-857_9eca4f6f265b03e9.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066810},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"American Blues","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/kim-llerena-american-blues","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>American Blues</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Kim Llerena</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/d0667afc-bdae-4210-a844-d6cd06c6114e.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Kim Llerena’s “American Scrapbook” gives a fresh riff on the classic roadtrip, deftly collecting signs and symbols of the collective American sensibility as she drives through the landscape.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Imagine the twelve bar blues, a late night club in Memphis or loud in your headphones. The bass line is the same in nearly every song. Almost always, the first line of the lyrics is sung, then repeated. There is some counterpoint line, but then the first line comes again. There are guitar or organ licks thrown between what little makes up a melody. The chord progression is predictable. The sentiment—the idea—of every song is the same. <em>Somebody done wrong</em>. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Uvalde, TX © Kim Llerena\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/kim-llerena-american-blues#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>It would be easy to say the twelve bar blues, music so deeply American it always seems odd and nostalgic and sad to hear it somewhere else, is repetitive and under-imagined. But everyone knows that isn’t true. Given the form, there is a world of individual voice and expression. You would never confuse BB King with Albert King. You would never confuse Eric Clapton with Joe Bonamassa. They all work the same ground but the way they work it is as nuanced as an attentive kiss. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Austin, TX © Kim Llerena\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/kim-llerena-american-blues#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>I am thinking about this because I am looking at the images by Kim Llerena in a collection called <em>American Scrapbook.</em> At one level, I have seen every one of these images before. Her work is American landscape work. Mountains and desert and roadways. Dilapidated buildings. Abandoned storefronts. Odd signs. Odd things in people’s yards. Sometimes Route 66 type stuff. And it would be easy to say this collection is derivative. But, like some new voice playing a blues tune we’ve heard a thousand times, this series of images is a fresh take. Every image is enjoyable and new. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Jasper County, IA © Kim Llerena \n<p>In the text for her project, Llerena says, “…these images seek out iconography from various interconnected systems that direct our collective national consciousness—business, infrastructure, religion, climate, natural resources, domestic space, borders, racism, power, tourism, leisure, and more…In many images there is a sense that something is missing, whether physical or contextual, underscoring the incomplete narratives that photographs can often tell.” </p> \n<p>From my point of view, Llerena’s approach is ironic more than it is sad or nostalgic. There is an edge to nearly every shot, though some of her landscape images are simply loving. Some hint at decay, provoking a fine sense of wonder about what kind of stories might lurk in these landscapes. Yes, I’ve seen images of cars with their front ends stuck in the ground before. Yes, I’ve seen the blown out sign and the cornfield and the child’s toy before. But not quite this way. That’s the real strength here. Llerena makes the familiar and predictable fresh again. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Detroit, MI © Kim Llerena\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/kim-llerena-american-blues#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Llerena says, “Taken individually, each image tells the story of a very particular place—someone’s yard, a small town with a notable attraction, something that’s been built or dismantled. Viewed together, relationships between disparate places and structures emerge, highlighting…a shared American sensibility….” </p> \n<p>I know that American sensibility. Others have been singing that song for a long time. It’s a pleasure to hear again, all new. </p> \n<p><br> </br></p>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/marcus-lyon-exodus\">Exodus</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/brice-portolano-arctic-love-way-way-out-in-the-wilderness\">Arctic Love: Way, Way Out in the Wilderness</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dorothea-lange-words-and-pictures\">Words and Pictures</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/william-klein-william-klein-retrospective\">William Klein Retrospective</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/gideon-mendel-a-picture-of-what-is-to-come-our-drowning-world\">A Picture of What Is to Come: Our Drowning World</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dario-calmese-harlem-socialite-lana-turner\">Harlem Socialite, Lana Turner</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/96dbd449-25cf-49e7-85af-22f402696b1f.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Mead, NE\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ab1fef41-430f-45f5-b454-192a9c56c0b9.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   GlenRio, TX\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/54cd0773-c560-470b-999a-8afe5fd5c89e.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   New Orleans, LA\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c267c04d-268b-4063-8343-5a365b6f1ebd.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Spokane, WA\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f6dc05dd-8b80-4ebd-83c6-5b807bdb911a.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Calexico, CA\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/423ac648-e3d4-471c-b3dd-6662bb41ba4d.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Norton, KS\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b2c83397-b2bf-4f06-b601-fc16e5e18023.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Watauga County, NC\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d0667afc-bdae-4210-a844-d6cd06c6114e.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Shamrock, TX\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 03 Jul 2020 13:26:50 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/d0667afc-bdae-4210-a844-d6cd06c6114e.jpg","linkMd5":"2ac8763164edf4a93ad13b9a346f7355","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn4@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-48-603_a374c1896ca63c47.webp","destWidth":1124,"destHeight":2000,"sourceBytes":335654,"destBytes":232528,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/d0667afc-bdae-4210-a844-d6cd06c6114e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn4@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-48-603_a374c1896ca63c47.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/96dbd449-25cf-49e7-85af-22f402696b1f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn44@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-07-680_169aa44558d07ac2.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ab1fef41-430f-45f5-b454-192a9c56c0b9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn16@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-55-137_86bafeba024bb103.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/54cd0773-c560-470b-999a-8afe5fd5c89e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn64@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-02-432_c60db016030868db.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c267c04d-268b-4063-8343-5a365b6f1ebd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn100@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-01-894_9fc241962a8dab5d.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f6dc05dd-8b80-4ebd-83c6-5b807bdb911a.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn68@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-15-125_0049afa8f51aecfc.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/423ac648-e3d4-471c-b3dd-6662bb41ba4d.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn12@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-11-585_ee7452c417d77968.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b2c83397-b2bf-4f06-b601-fc16e5e18023.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn52@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-58-074_2fbae28cf6d9d22e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d0667afc-bdae-4210-a844-d6cd06c6114e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn40@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-10-320_3156b0bb38e72570.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066813},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"I’m Only Here To Leave","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/tommy-kha-i-m-only-here-to-leave","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>I’m Only Here To Leave</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Tommy Kha</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/b68bdfda-5b17-4614-b130-22cd67c21cf7.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  In a surreal play on self-portraiture, Tommy Kha creates 3-D masks of his face for his friends, family, and strangers to wear.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Tommy Kha’s self-portraits require a double-take. His on-going project, <em>I’m Only Here To Leave</em>, includes images of non-traditionally printed self-portrait objects staged within real-world settings. The photo-based artist—from Memphis, Tennessee, who now lives in Brooklyn, New York—explains, “I wanted to find a way of representing myself without literally photographing myself. So instead, I have been making photographs of photographs of my face and body as a way to control my representation.” In these images, the artist and others—family, friends, and strangers—can often be found wearing masks of Kha’s face or engaging with other props that blur the lines between the body and the photographed body. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Mine (II, or an Assembly), Memphis, TN 2015 © Tommy Kha\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/tommy-kha-i-m-only-here-to-leave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Kha started working on <em>I’m Only Here To Leave</em> in 2015, during a residency at LightWork. The earliest photographs in this body of work include cardboard cutouts of the artist’s face from his existing private archive of self-portraits. For other pictures, he created white cardboard stencils of these cutouts, making it appear as if he had literally cut himself out of his own work. More recently, he has worked with a fabricator to create hyper-realistic masks of his face and used temporary tattoos to give himself the appearance of having four eyes. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Unified (I), McCarren Park, Brooklyn, 2016 © Tommy Kha\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/tommy-kha-i-m-only-here-to-leave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>He travels between Memphis and Brooklyn, or wherever else his work takes him, with these photo-prosthetics in his bag, waiting for an opportunity to use them. “It’s a funny thing to do, but it lets me strike a balance between straight and staged photography by opening up more opportunities to stage these unreal things into real spaces.” This strategy may be part of what gives <em>I’m Only Here to Leave</em> its mix of familiar gentleness and unsettling strangeness. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Constellations (XI), Upper East Side, 2019 © Tommy Kha\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/tommy-kha-i-m-only-here-to-leave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Kha’s family are peppered throughout this series of images. Their presence references vernacular family photography and the idea of what it means to be represented in art. He explains, “As a queer Asian-American brought up in Memphis, I did not see myself represented in the media or the canon of Western Art. I think literally inserting myself into representations is part of my way of trying to resolve that.” It will be interesting to see how <em>I’m Only Here to Leave</em> unfolds, as Kha has no plans to stop working it. He views it less as a series than a set of images that are connected, along with the rest of his work. “Everything I do feels like part of one continuous lifelong exploration.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Constellations (XII), Whitehaven Memphis, 2019 © Tommy Kha\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/tommy-kha-i-m-only-here-to-leave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/kate-smuraga-nobody-important-no-one-else\">Nobody Important, No One Else</a></li>\n <li><a
