href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/shira-gold-shock\">Shock</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/argus-paul-estabrook-taking-to-heart\">Taking to Heart</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/pentti-sammallahti-here-far-away\">Here Far Away</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b68bdfda-5b17-4614-b130-22cd67c21cf7.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f07c0081-0fdf-4799-bc36-aca39cc1cb5a.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d3e4f638-1096-4775-a0db-367a1dec7e4e.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c6c4c1f0-393b-4dbb-96cb-91892fe4ec60.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/fde331c0-6ac0-486f-8025-ddd93f539c79.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/88853321-32b2-4a15-931b-e10f841a8edb.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1409a9f2-8565-4e3f-a169-58f835419bc9.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 19 May 2020 09:59:59 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/b68bdfda-5b17-4614-b130-22cd67c21cf7.jpg","linkMd5":"54be6c6bea026db1c67484a88c250b67","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn22@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-47-621_ca9a8b60ad03c894.webp","destWidth":900,"destHeight":1600,"sourceBytes":179404,"destBytes":90942,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/b68bdfda-5b17-4614-b130-22cd67c21cf7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn22@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-47-621_ca9a8b60ad03c894.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b68bdfda-5b17-4614-b130-22cd67c21cf7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn92@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-10-299_4aefb55b0297dc68.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f07c0081-0fdf-4799-bc36-aca39cc1cb5a.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn68@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-14-401_e189ae0b888084ae.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d3e4f638-1096-4775-a0db-367a1dec7e4e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn32@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-01-138_a2fb15154c475aea.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c6c4c1f0-393b-4dbb-96cb-91892fe4ec60.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn4@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-08-246_e9ed41b304de7b03.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/fde331c0-6ac0-486f-8025-ddd93f539c79.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn23@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-04-805_6a8a963b861bb2d1.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/88853321-32b2-4a15-931b-e10f841a8edb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn16@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-58-789_ea98160d1fd1cdfe.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1409a9f2-8565-4e3f-a169-58f835419bc9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn36@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-57-810_17c49e9f4dbef36b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066817},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Yerevan 1996/1997","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/ursula-schulz-dornburg-yerevan-1996-1997","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Yerevan 1996/1997</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Ursula Schulz-Dornburg</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/a505ba53-55b1-451a-b72c-429ae2bde324.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  First conceived as a visual letter to her daughter, Ursula Schulz-Dornburg’s recent book gives us an architectural portrait of a city in transition, photographed not long after the collapse of Communism.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Ursula Schulz-Dornburg’s small book of photographs made in the Armenian capital, <em>Yerevan 1996/1997</em>, is deceptively straightforward. With pictures pasted over the pages of an Armenian school exercise book, it was originally conceived and made as a gift for her daughter, who was studying architecture in Spain at the time. </p> \n<p>The beautiful facsimile of this book, published by MACK, preserves its original purpose and intimate context. A typed letter, from the artist to her daughter, reveals how the photographs were intended to show her “a kind of fascinating Soviet concrete mania that you would not find in Barcelona.” The pictures, taken with a small automated Ixus film camera, are more akin to architectural sketches, free from the formal rigour and strictures of much architectural photography, including much of Schulz-Dornburg’s own. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Yerevan 1996/1997” (MACK, 2019). Courtesy of Ursula Schulz-Dornburg and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/ursula-schulz-dornburg-yerevan-1996-1997#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The book is a record of a city and country at a time of transition, caught between its newly gained independence and its recent Soviet past. While the immediate reading and frame is as a response to Soviet architecture, there is also the fascination with more local and improvised buildings, including such temporary and precarious structures as the yellow tramcar that forms a bridge crossing a river. She has said how she was interested in how the Armenians kept their own identity during the Soviet times and had invented and adapted at a time when they had very little. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Yerevan 1996/1997” (MACK, 2019). Courtesy of Ursula Schulz-Dornburg and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/ursula-schulz-dornburg-yerevan-1996-1997#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The yellow tramcar photograph links with a photograph showing a young boy balancing on a tightrope, an anecdotal observation of local life set against the backdrop of Soviet-era high rises. In the context of the book, both are symbolic of the wider political uncertainties and precarities of Yerevan at this time of transition. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Yerevan 1996/1997” (MACK, 2019). Courtesy of Ursula Schulz-Dornburg and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/ursula-schulz-dornburg-yerevan-1996-1997#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p> Shedding light on the social and vernacular aspects of the city’s architecture and structures, Schulz-Dornburg ignores the grand Soviet buildings in Yerevan and concentrates instead on social housing and some of the more unusual buildings and structures encountered in the city. Quite a few photographs show a fascination with the brutalist structures of high rises, animated by circular windows, the colour of the local pink Tufu stone and the inclusion of details showing inhabitants chatting across balconies and washing hung to dry. The more unusual include the remains of pyramidal structures in a park, originally designed as places where two or three individuals could have a drink or meal, perfect for secret meetings in Soviet times. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Yerevan 1996/1997” (MACK, 2019). Courtesy of Ursula Schulz-Dornburg and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/ursula-schulz-dornburg-yerevan-1996-1997#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><em>Yerevan 1996/1997</em> begins with a photograph of the symbol of Armenian nationalism, Mount Ararat, which can be seen from the capital but is outside Armenia. Cyrillic signs and Armenian language collide in the pairing of photographs of a meat store and car repairers, pictures fascinated with vernacular signage and which also include portraits of their owners. One Soviet-era building is now a Travel Agents, its English-language sign, Air Tickets, a reminder that such former communist countries were now open to global tourism and capitalist ‘expansion’. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Yerevan 1996/1997” (MACK, 2019). Courtesy of Ursula Schulz-Dornburg and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/ursula-schulz-dornburg-yerevan-1996-1997#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The book is given an open-ended closure with its picture of a young well-dressed woman waiting in front of what would have once been a very dynamic and colorful bus stop. The waiting figure reiterates the sense of pervasive indeterminacy and uncertainty captured in this book at the time of its original making. The photograph also links to Schulz-Dornburg’s well-known project, <em>Bus Stops in Armenia</em>, a celebration, albeit in black and white, of the creativity and imaginings of their anonymous and unfeted architects, despite such a low-level and basic task of design. Such Communist structures have now even become a resource for contemporary architects, with one of the bus stops she photographed having been recreated by Herzog and de Meuron for a project in Burgos, Spain. </p> \n<p>Pasting photographs over the pages of an otherwise unused Armenian school exercise book could be seen to signal the way in which the structures of Soviet modernism were imposed on Armenian life. It certainly establishes a tension and dynamic but the architecture, and this seems to be the point of the book, is not always monumental or necessarily oppressive. And the focus is not just on Soviet-era buildings. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Yerevan 1996/1997” (MACK, 2019). Courtesy of Ursula Schulz-Dornburg and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/ursula-schulz-dornburg-yerevan-1996-1997#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Modernism held faith in the determination to change the world by aesthetics. With the end of modernism and the collapse of communism, modernist art is now more readily identified with capitalist investment than the ideals it may have once carried—Malevich, for example, is collected by Russian oligarchs. </p> \n<p>In what remains of Soviet-era architecture we reflect on the lost social ideals behind an aesthetic vision that was once integrated into everyday life. And death—as borne out by Schulz-Dornburg’s fascinating photographs of the colorful geometric structures found in the cemetery of Yerevan, furnishings intended for social gatherings in celebration of the life of the dead. These pictures also serve as an apt metaphor for her book as a whole, with its souvenirs gathered from the ruins of modernism and the socialist project. </p> \n<div> \n <div class=\"article-incut -book-incut\"> \n  <div class=\"picture\"> \n   <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/books/18881-yerevan-1996-1997\"></a> \n  </div> \n  <div class=\"title\">\n   Yerevan 1996/1997\n   <br> </br>\n  </div> \n  <div class=\"author\">\n   by Ursula Schulz-Dornburg\n   <br> </br>\n  </div> \n  <div class=\"publisher\">\n   Publisher: MACK\n   <br>ISBN: 978-1-912339-49-5<br> </br></br>\n  </div> \n </div> \n</div>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/peter-wegner-buildings-made-of-sky\">Buildings Made of Sky</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/peter-braunholz-topophilia\">Topophilia</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/thomas-heinser-uberblick-california-skies\">Überblick: California Skies</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/the-print-space-terra-firma-portrait-of-a-planet\">Terra Firma: Portrait of a Planet</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/multi-media-specialist-jabruson-kith-or-kin\">Kith or Kin?</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/kevin-osepa-mester-blouse\">Mester Blousé</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4f797127-5e51-4168-a90f-510c8f9ee644.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d96075d9-b74d-41fb-8a64-472228eb5c7a.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/592bd2cd-506d-4e54-bb1b-078746b9b44a.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a505ba53-55b1-451a-b72c-429ae2bde324.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 06 Aug 2020 08:42:09 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/a505ba53-55b1-451a-b72c-429ae2bde324.jpg","linkMd5":"571916602fcb595a756621957babb00e","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn79@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-47-998_982ff8f9835f749e.webp","destWidth":746,"destHeight":434,"sourceBytes":377621,"destBytes":46208,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/a505ba53-55b1-451a-b72c-429ae2bde324.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn79@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-47-998_982ff8f9835f749e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4f797127-5e51-4168-a90f-510c8f9ee644.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn55@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-57-371_3b6dd2b0b6dfedc3.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d96075d9-b74d-41fb-8a64-472228eb5c7a.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn39@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-13-685_f3c52382d0c6f4f5.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/592bd2cd-506d-4e54-bb1b-078746b9b44a.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn55@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-53-865_af12b3b926fd8f6a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a505ba53-55b1-451a-b72c-429ae2bde324.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn72@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-57-488_9b9e3503bbeab942.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066810},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"When Bodies Misbehave","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>When Bodies Misbehave</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">When Bodies</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/6f185a13-7cbf-40de-8d71-12d237718c13.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Can photography be used as a tool of healing? Here’s a look at how seven very different artists have responded to the experience of ill-health.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>“Everyone who is born holds dual citizenship in the kingdom of the well and the kingdom of the sick…sooner or later each of us is obliged, at least for a spell, to identify ourselves as citizens of that other place.” </p> \n<p>When Susan Sontag wrote <em>Illness as a Metaphor</em> in 1978—from which these incisive words are drawn—she was undergoing treatment for breast cancer, and wanted to dissect the social politics of the public healthcare system she had encountered along the way. Challenging the victim-blaming rhetoric that was often used to describe those suffering from disease or chronic illness, the essay delivers a swift and critical blow to medical discourse of the time. Some 40 years on, these same words opened <em>Misbehaving</em> <em>Bodies</em>, a 2019 exhibition of works by Jo Spence and Oreet Ashery at London’s Wellcome Collection. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>“Another Happy Day” from the series “Half-Light”, 2018 © Shahrzad Darafsheh\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Spence, like Sontag, sought a creative outlet when diagnosed with breast cancer, frustrated with the abrasive clinical scrutiny of medical professionals—from doctors and surgeons to hospital photographers. She kept an intimate photographic record throughout her hospital experience—through invasive procedures such as mammography and mastectomy—and found herself shaken by what came back from the lab. “I couldn’t believe that I had seen so much and already forgotten it. I had already disavowed what had happened to me…This points up one of the advantages of photographing one’s traumas—before they become sealed over.” </p> \n<p>Spence’s iconoclastic self-portraits are therapeutic exercises in self-reclamation, visualising her journey through the “other place” Sontag conjured. Tired of being reduced to the nameless status of ‘patient’, and of being told she was just the unfortunate victim of genetics, she demanded her body be seen as hers again. Reconfiguring cancer not as an enemy attacking externally, but as an intrinsic product of her own corporeal experience, Spence sought to maintain the autonomy of her body, crystallizing its various states in images. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>“Keramiek met aantekening” from the series “La Machine”, 2018 - present © Phelim Hoey\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Dutch artist Phelim Hoey is today preoccupied with similar concerns. Since being diagnosed with multiple sclerosis, Hoey has explored his condition through photography, film and sculpture. His ongoing project, <em>La Machine</em>, presents a series of visual experiments, combining the symbolic fragility of materials like porcelain with precariously-balanced still lives, each wrought with a pronounced tension. “For me, MS manifests itself primarily as pain, and whenever I feel a certain muscle spasm or sensation I automatically focus on it.” Measuring the body’s functioning is now a daily task which, in turn, his photographs reflect. “I use balance a lot in these pictures—some of them are based on traps used to catch wildlife, because it often feels like my body’s setting a trap for itself.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>“Candle” from the series “La Machine”, 2018 - present © Phelim Hoey\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Where Spence saw a marked difference between the artistic and the medical body, Hoey observes a distinction between the physical body and the ‘self’: “After my diagnosis, I realised that I don’t see my body as something that’s really ‘me’ anymore.” Deriving inspiration from the motion studies of Eadweard Muybridge helped Hoey further underline this separation: “I like this way of focusing on the body: completely isolated in a space with no point of reference, and with no sense of its proportions. Bodies become objects in this way.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>“Muybridge 2” from the series “La Machine”, 2018 - present © Phelim Hoey\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Hoey proffers that for those of us without visible illness or disability, the body is self-evident, facilitating a general autonomy of existence—the luxury of moving through society unchecked. For people <em>with</em> a visible health condition, who are perhaps used to being viewed in ways they cannot control, the photograph might offer a space to repossess how they are seen. In the hands of artists, with their added ability to construct the circumstances in which audiences access the work, the possibility of reclaiming the autonomy of self-image is further enhanced. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Bystander #14, 2016 © Mari Katayama \n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Japanese artist Mari Katayama explores similar ideas. Born with tibial hemimelia, a rare disease that prevents bones from growing in the lower limbs, Katayama had both her legs amputated at 9 years old. The artist also has a cleft left hand that she says resembles a crab’s pincer, hence the recurring presence of beach motifs throughout her photographs. For these images, Katayama makes body doubles, moulding and sewing limbs from leather skin, and styles herself and her prosthetic legs into a sort of living sculpture. </p> \n<p>As Katayama explained in an interview with <em>Dazed</em>, her interest lies not in the body itself, but in “the gap of the ‘experiences’ throughout” it: “You can’t separate my body from my work, but I’m not making art out of my disabilities.” What Katayama posits, it appears, is that it’s possible to inhabit a body, to experience the implications of its ill health, and to make work that transcends that experience. First and foremost, these images are about the performance of identity and the things that shape it. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>You’re mine #002, 2014 © Mari Katayama\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Elsewhere, Iranian artist Shahrzad Darafsheh’s <em>Half-Light</em> presents a quieter, more reflective engagement with her battle with cancer. In book form, the project functions as a visual diary, recording a slew of everyday scenes alongside the more painful junctures of her journey. “Regardless of the type of illness, travelling through the image is one of the major processes to go into the body, and I wanted to examine myself inside and out. Nothing could really reveal to me how my body is changing better than photography, and shooting everything around me as well as myself helps me in being able to talk about my perception of illness both directly and metaphorically.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>“Half-Light” from the series “Half-Light”, 2018 © Shahrzad Darafsheh \n<p>The ongoing<em> A</em> <em>Certain</em> <em>Distance</em> project by Canadian photographer Philip LePage also adopts a diaristic approach, chronicling the artist’s account of living with mental illness. Diagnosed with dysthymia—a persistent and chronic form of depression—LePage examines his experience of this disorder alongside a constellation of associated conditions. In searing, dream-like black and white prints, he captures fragments of everyday life—the people he spends his time with and the places he goes.<br> </br></p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “A Certain Distance”, 2015 © Philip LePage \n<p>LePage describes the dissociative detachment incurred by his illness as if someone else is living his life—as if he is “becoming a ghost” of himself. Something about this spectral quality of experiencing illness resonates particularly with photography. “Before I was open about my condition, recurring comments about my work always used to centre on the idea that it seemed detached and viewers couldn’t get a sense of my story, but because of my illness that detachment is an inextricable part of me. When I began talking about it in relation to my work, the pictures started making more sense.” </p> \n<p>Photography, it seems, offers artists like LePage a means to externalize parts of themselves that others may not understand. “You can’t take pictures of a broken mind, but you can show the pictures that mind makes, and maybe someone will recognize the symbols,” he says. While photography is undoubtedly a powerful tool with which to explore visible illness, it also maintains a capacity to represent the intangible—just as the body can misbehave in ways that aren’t immediately apparent. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “A Certain Distance”, 2015 © Philip LePage\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The work of Chinese photographer Shuwei Liu takes shape in similarly abstract forms, delivered in a spectrum of blues. Liu applied photography to process the impending decline of his vision, soon after floating crescents had appeared at the base of his corneas. Where English filmmaker Derek Jarman mused on the colour blue as “darkness made visible” as his own sight deteriorated, Liu considers blue “a space between the visible and invisible”, with photography offering a powerful tool for exploring that dichotomy. The milky, washed-out vision he was enduring is expressed in hazy images of foggy windows, eerily empty tunnels and moonlit landscapes. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “Visible Darkness”, 2015 – present © Shuwei Liu\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>When Spence grew tired of traditional medicine, she offered the following reason: “I have rejected a medical profession whose basic metaphors of disease are those of WAR: to cut, burn and chemically destroy the ‘problem’, to get rid of the ‘trouble’ (in my case a malignant tumour); to knife it out whilst not encouraging me to ask why it is there.” These metaphors are further probed in <em>Project ‘K’</em>, a photographic collaboration between Dutch artists Geert Broertjes and Lotte Bronsgeest<em>, </em>begun after Broertjes’ diagnosis with colon cancer in April 2019. </p> \n<p>“Shortly after I was diagnosed, Lotte asked if she could take a portrait of me— something pure, without the presence of poisonous medicine in my body,” Broertjes says. As his treatment unfolded, the artist took daily self-portraits to study the nuances in his outward appearance. Meanwhile, the duo subjected negatives and prints to the same procedures Broertjes’ body was enduring. To represent chemotherapy, his urine was used to soak film rolls; partially burned negatives became stand-ins for surgical procedures; whilst 4x5 film was irradiated at the hospital—the hovering, illuminated square in the middle of the film symbolising Broertjes’ tumour of the same size. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Project ‘K’”, 2019 – present © Geert Broertjes and Lotte Bronsgeest \n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>In <em>Project</em> <em>‘K’</em>, the notion of a space beyond this one—of Sontag’s “kingdom of the sick”—arises once again. As Broertjes explains, replacing the human body itself with photographic film generates “a sort of external visualization of the world you live in as a patient.” The artist also highlights the contradictory character of ‘treatment’—that what is designed to heal you also breaks you down. In response, the practice of destroying negatives served to further emphasise the violence of both illness and ‘recovery’ on the body. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Project ‘K’”, 2019 – present © Geert Broertjes and Lotte Bronsgeest \n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>A series of works by Kenyan-British artist Phoebe Boswell—brought together for <em>The Space Between Things</em>, a solo exhibition at London’s Autograph ABP—pose other pertinent questions. Why, when dealing with the experience of illness, must any account that isn’t ostensibly ‘strong’ be regarded as ‘weak’? And while there is much to be said for the therapeutic potential of art, why should creative explorations of ill or altered health always be redemptive and celebratory, or culminate in a ‘positive’ takeaway message? </p> \n<p>After sustaining a serious eye injury, Boswell suffered a difficult emotional period that eventually led to a heart attack. Subsequently, a chasm widened between the artist and her sense of self, with prior understandings of her body undermined by it failing beyond her control. “How was she supposed to live, now, with a ‘new’ body and an emotional self that could never return to the person she once knew and inhabited?” asked writer M. Neelika Jayawardane, in a recent text on Boswell’s work for <em>Aperture</em>. The answer for Boswell lay in creating a dialogue with her new self, mediated through a form of art-making that embraced vulnerability and pain. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Film still from “Ythlaf”, 2018 © Phoebe Boswell\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>In one video work, Boswell incorporated multiple-exposure self-portraits of medical scans, from full-body shots to close-up views of her organs. In another—<em>Ythlaf</em>—the artist floats in the waters off Zanzibar’s shoreline, her body drifting metaphorically in and out of the frame, at the whim of outside elements. Boswell’s reflections reinstate that, beyond expressions of resolve, there should also be space for more painful and affecting representations of the vicissitudes of living with ill health. </p> \n<p>Although the term ‘misbehaving’ seems to be a strangely insouciant one at first, it urges a critical consideration of the ‘norms’ from which the ill or suffering body deviates, as well as how society defines what we expect of our bodies. As Phelim Hoey reminds us, “society is ultimately for healthy people”—a feeling that connects the various accounts and conversations compiled here. For the lineage of photographers that, after Spence, have probed the capabilities and limits of their own misbehaving bodies, the medium maintains a transformative and emancipatory potential. Photography, ultimately, opens up a powerful space of rehearsal. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “Visible Darkness”, 2015 – present © Shuwei Liu\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/when-bodies-when-bodies-misbehave#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>“I begin to see beneath the surface of the image,” reads a small slice of text in Spence’s seminal project, <em>The Picture of Health?</em>. “…I can now begin the work of re-inventing myselves.” </p> \n<p><em>Editor’s note: T</em><em>his piece was written with the generous support of writer and editor George H. King.</em> </p> \n<hr> \n <div> \n  <em><br /></em> \n </div>\n <p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n <ul>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/jeff-cowen-photo-murals-that-float-in-space-and-time\">Photo murals that float &lt;br&gt;in space and time</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/lensculture-editors-best-of-december-deadlines-for-competitions-workshops-residencies-and-more\">Best of December: Deadlines for Competitions, Workshops, Residencies and More</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/irina-sadchikova-nata-sopromadze-broken-sea\">Broken Sea</a></li>\n  <li><a of Shepherds</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/julia-gunther-rainbow-girls\">Rainbow Girls</a></li>\n </ul>\n <section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n  <figure>\n   <img series \"Half-Light\", 2018\n   </figcaption>\n  </figure>\n  <figure>\n   <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/dfbf8134-8732-44f6-8be8-51b7aab533ab.jpg\" />\n   <figcaption>\n </section> \n</hr>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 24 Jul 2020 08:54:38 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/6f185a13-7cbf-40de-8d71-12d237718c13.jpg","linkMd5":"7b91bb23907b43e48bd3064612b8c573","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn96@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-46-941_38681d08b2a8bc58.webp","destWidth":639,"destHeight":531,"sourceBytes":27198,"destBytes":8110,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/6f185a13-7cbf-40de-8d71-12d237718c13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn96@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-46-941_38681d08b2a8bc58.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/6c60e5d9-d26c-4475-abfa-40d1cb70e391.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn20@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-08-917_e5f1c8ad717c809a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/14feae8c-014c-47de-be7b-6904d26587b0.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn35@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-11-948_d2191d481de32562.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a9ad9f1b-45b2-4e84-b65d-ff60df240a14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn35@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-53-292_f22c3709df58b159.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/dfbf8134-8732-44f6-8be8-51b7aab533ab.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-51-549_9f015c1cdb716f74.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/0dc23c3b-ab5c-4efe-a0a7-39a4a2296f9e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn63@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-51-521_158f7f5d6a80de88.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9f82814c-8a4b-4099-9b39-c3f389a630bd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn51@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-09-222_794d4adf3a08c4e1.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/6f185a13-7cbf-40de-8d71-12d237718c13.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn4@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-54-529_a0e5649ee8b22b5b.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c500871c-5c00-4b21-83d9-0389b480308c.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn91@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-01-313_2887ee4bcedeb891.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/703c23a3-b03e-436d-ad0e-68f41a35d23b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn83@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-17-090_83b9e4406dbae519.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d4ecb6a9-7c34-4067-bdd9-da74bb51a780.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn71@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-08-020_9b5b799b1fa59fff.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b4a5dc46-823e-4f37-806a-23f34185a894.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn60@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-53-787_7e22243800ca7cb2.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b2cc4a85-02e7-413a-ae48-b889413c4104.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn3@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-11-041_eae1fa812dd752e8.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a649d92e-5a63-4e42-b50a-752d403f4937.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn21@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-51-642_a18ca48fd8b61990.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d3df0da3-e7b0-4ba1-a67f-aad0b8fc2e98.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn19@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-58-034_ab5761a9b03e23ff.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3fd4002b-3829-4245-9ede-35b24899d821.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn88@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-07-452_61e36eb488a41909.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c3dc154f-3816-4cc6-8652-c7a89ddf2e7b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn12@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-07-204_87c8966b1ba31dad.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/30376500-942a-4ed5-8b54-2fdcc98f0015.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn100@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-06-296_218cf48b38e71ad6.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066812},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Sleep Creek","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dylan-hausthor-sleep-creek","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Sleep Creek</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Dylan Hausthor</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/3c93bd4d-5a4f-4ee1-93f5-07680639bb90.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  This experiment in shared authorship weaves together an enigmatic imaginary New England location out of spellbinding monochrome vignettes.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>By now, you’ve probably heard about Paul Guilmoth and Dylan Hausthor’s <em>Sleep Creek</em>, a photobook published in the winter of 2019 by Void, the Athens-based imprint specializing in dark visuals and photographic mythologies. <em>Sleep Creek</em> popped up on numerous end-of-the year book lists, and has been widely recognized in photography circles the world over, so much so that its popularity garnered its selection as Charcoal Book of the Month back in February. But what exactly is it about the New England grit, woven throughout each image in the book, that has captivated this global audience? </p> \n<p>Building a world from the ground up, saturated with original narratives, contexts and characters, is a common goal amongst artists working across all mediums. For those who use painting or sculpture to construct their alternate dimensions, there is a vast amount of space and freedom harnessed in the starting point of a blank canvas or hunk of clay. But when your medium of choice is photography, the possibilities for unique construction become tricky to navigate. </p> \n<p>As a practice whose history is deeply intertwined with realism, photography has been employed as evidence of events, people and places for nearly two hundred years. Despite this relationship to ‘real’ events, the photographs we find most captivating are often those that harness their own mythology, touching on referents that hastily reveal themselves, only to disappear just as quickly—a frenetic impact of emotion contained within the confines of a still image. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the book “Sleep Creek” © Dylan Hausthor &amp; Paul Guilmoth\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dylan-hausthor-sleep-creek#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><em>Sleep Creek</em> is the result of a years-long creative partnership between Hausthor and Guilmoth, who grew up in Vermont and New Hampshire respectively, and met while attending art school in Maine in 2011. The two immediately hit it off, and discovered their mutual love for presenting their work through book-making. After graduating from their BFA program, they rented a large house together on Peaks Island in Maine’s Casco Bay, converting the living room into a studio, and spent their days taking photographs of the isolated landmass. There, they founded Wilt Press, and published magazines, photobooks, zines and cassettes, enlarging the shadowy realms occupying their own work across different outlets. Sheltered in the confines of their drafty, peculiar home, the duo began constructing the world of Sleep Creek, leaning into the mythology of New England to find ways to construct a world of their own. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the book “Sleep Creek” © Dylan Hausthor &amp; Paul Guilmoth\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dylan-hausthor-sleep-creek#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>“Since we both grew up in New England, there is a very specific landscape that we are accustomed to interacting with on a daily basis, and there are very specific stories and feelings that come out of that landscape,” Hausthor explains. “It has something to do with the seasons, and this cyclical narrative that they perpetuate.” While their photographic project started out as a documentation of Peaks Island, the duo eventually broke that instinctive straight documentarian threshold, instead creating the world of Sleep Creek, a place containing equal parts fiction and reality. Guilmoth adds, “When you’re a photographer, you’re used to working with realism and with your roots, and you’re trained to make some sort of document, no matter what kind of picture you are making. It’s this relatable piece of content evidence, but how do you construct something new while paying homage to those experiences?” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the book “Sleep Creek” © Dylan Hausthor &amp; Paul Guilmoth\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dylan-hausthor-sleep-creek#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Publishing work that poses more questions than answers is precisely where Void has found their niche, and after seeing the work of Hausthor and Guilmoth, reaching out to the photographers to collaborate on a book was a no-brainer. The resulting work stays true to the eerie atmosphere of the photographs while situating itself amongst the larger narrative of Void’s projects. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Cover of “Sleep Creek” © Dylan Hausthor &amp; Paul Guilmoth\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dylan-hausthor-sleep-creek#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><em>Sleep Creek’s</em> cover is forest green, providing no allusion to the photographs contained within. Instead, viewers first encounter a golden, embossed goat resembling an old wood-block print, hinting at the manifestation of a dark fairy tale. Inspired by the photographers’ uncanny universe, the Void team sifted through old illustration books on witchcraft and the dark arts, finding visuals that enhanced the photographs’ twitching discomfort. The cover instigates more curiosity than clarification, as at first the goat doesn’t necessarily lean towards good or evil—it could be a harmless rural marker, but it could also be a nod to Black Phillip (as Brad Feuerhelm points out in his <a href=\"https://americansuburbx.com/2020/01/hausthor-guimoth-sleep-creek-gauze-eyed-gothic.html\">review of the book</a> on <em>American Suburb X</em>). </p> \n<p>Flipping the book over and looking at its back cover, readers encounter another embossed image, this time more explicit in its dark origins: flailing figures in the shallows of a river bank, enraptured in some sort of ritualistic reverence or baptismal wading. While hinting at the context of a ‘creek’, the twisting bodies also drive the timelessness of the photographs home, an indiscernible era that is just as much about the past as it is about the present. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the book “Sleep Creek” © Dylan Hausthor &amp; Paul Guilmoth\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dylan-hausthor-sleep-creek#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>After opening the book, the first page is blank, save for hand-written ellipses in brackets in the lower left corner. This elusive nod to a compiler’s hand informs us that whatever story is contained in the following pages isn’t necessarily the beginning or end of a concrete tale. Rather, it’s a continuation, a fragment, or a series of incomplete scenarios pieced together to create some sort of framework amidst the chaos. The small dots invite each reader to step into the journey laid out for them on the following pages, standing in as a wordless representation for “Once upon a time…” </p> \n<p>Turning the page, readers are met with a steady flow of Hausthor and Guilmoth’s monochrome photographs, sequenced to a glitchy beat that feels like watching a film through blinking eyelids. Each image makes you feel like it’s revealing something you’re supposed to know—some crucial detail or piece of evidence that you try to hold onto while processing each subsequent photograph. “We like when photographs, even though they are still images, contain a beginning, middle and overall plot,” explains Hausthor. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Spread from “Sleep Creek” © Dylan Hausthor &amp; Paul Guilmoth\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dylan-hausthor-sleep-creek#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>“Sure, you can create a visual storyboard that maps out a distinct narrative, but there’s something about capturing it all at once, in one image, and then bringing all of those moments together. When I see Paul’s images, I interpret all of his components—his beginning, middle and plot—and I build on it to create our overarching story. That’s why photography is so interesting to us: these aren’t moving images, but somehow they each contain a narrative. How much can we pack into one frame?” </p> \n<p>There is documentation of their surroundings: thickets and groves illuminated by a flash in the night, spiderwebs reflecting silver, bats coursing through the night and animals caught in peculiar circumstances. But there are also people, seemingly caught in candid creeping. While the work is made by both photographers, there is no indication of who exactly took which photograph. Hausthor and Guilmoth work in a similar manner, prioritizing the absence of horizons and stark magnesium flare lighting, presenting countless references to natural elements like fire, water, ice and wind. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the book “Sleep Creek” © Dylan Hausthor &amp; Paul Guilmoth\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dylan-hausthor-sleep-creek#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The world of <em>Sleep Creek</em> is shown to us in the context of dusk and night time, inspired by eeriness of gothic New England lore. But it’s also a rumination on how we come to construct any place, tapping into the limitless possibilities of story, myth and character-building that highlights the partnership between fiction and evidence in photography. Coursing through the photographs, we feel like we’re bearing witness to things that were only meant to happen in the dark of night, never meant to be recorded and seen. </p> \n<p>As they shift into making more images, Hausthor and Guilmoth hope that <em>Sleep Creek</em> stands the test of time, not only as a collective work, but also as individual images. “I like the idea of people flipping through this book, trying to figure out what’s real to them,”Guilmoth reflects. “I think that’s an interesting subjective experience, and I like the idea that we prompt questions in people and make them think about their own surroundings.” Hausthor quips, “I want people to feel the same magic in these photographs ten years from now as they might feel today.” The praise that the book has received so far is indeed a testament to its potential for that lasting magic. </p> \n<div class=\"article-incut -book-incut\"> \n <div class=\"picture\"> \n  <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/books/17620-sleep-creek\"></a> \n </div> \n <div class=\"title\">\n  Sleep Creek\n  <br> </br>\n </div> \n <div class=\"author\">\n  by Dylan Hausthor &amp; Paul Guilmoth\n  <br> </br>\n </div> \n <div class=\"publisher\">\n  Publisher: Void Photo\n  <br>ISBN: 978-618-84341-5-8<br> </br></br>\n </div> \n</div> \n<hr> \n <p><br> </br></p>\n <p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n <ul>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/marta-berens-fairytale\">Fairytale</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/kenta-nakamura-offerings\">Offerings</a></li>\n  <li><a Heroes</a></li>\n </ul>\n <section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n  <figure>\n   <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/24109198-5926-4e22-a968-9a708cc94633.jpg\" />\n  </figure>\n  <figure>\n +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/3c93bd4d-5a4f-4ee1-93f5-07680639bb90.jpg","linkMd5":"18bc7bf61c23c062f33a650241e81346","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn87@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-47-616_a8c12613f79c69d0.webp","destWidth":540,"destHeight":960,"sourceBytes":130034,"destBytes":97112,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/3c93bd4d-5a4f-4ee1-93f5-07680639bb90.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn87@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-47-616_a8c12613f79c69d0.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/24109198-5926-4e22-a968-9a708cc94633.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn80@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-07-766_fcee7a595b7786ea.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1fa4f87c-0545-4337-bedf-3f35b10e3698.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn92@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-52-864_ece2de51d055f10f.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d91b6155-18db-4c4b-b9d6-5b374669ac49.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn36@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-09-780_c8ccfb30bbf9db61.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c005bc81-c19d-49b8-92b1-8f8296c8d637.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn60@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-52-206_09fd6a34d6b8ffd5.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5099dfba-d590-4651-952f-28a9e504fdb8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn11@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-04-601_caf289bde7edcbec.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3c93bd4d-5a4f-4ee1-93f5-07680639bb90.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn71@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-56-312_f58eff976b7c3384.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3546b57e-012a-4363-8481-df511673d73b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn20@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-03-674_5895f7b5bf59d963.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b40b4939-7c5d-45f4-9e3c-11570316d10e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn80@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-10-085_f982b319b8da62b8.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4c89609e-0160-47de-a606-ac1dac65f771.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn47@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-57-867_1a3d30b7b74c28f5.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a4f27d4e-a689-42e4-bfb4-79d4dcf19d74.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn36@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-14-067_42d321caa9619b09.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066818},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Tokyo Connection: Ihiro Hayami","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/ihiro-hayami-tokyo-connection-ihiro-hayami","description":"\n        <hgroup><h1>Tokyo Connection: Ihiro Hayami</h1><h3 class=\"fl-author\">Ihiro Hayami</h3></hgroup><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/0f17482c-da01-4a15-a0c9-3fd46d8c1447.jpg\"/><figcaption>The founder of the T3 International Photo Festival in Tokyo, and a juror for LensCulture’s Street Photography Awards, talks about creating opportunities for photographers around the globe.</figcaption></figure><p><i>Ihiro Hayami aims to connect photographers with appreciative audiences all over the world. From his early beginnings as editor-in-chief at a photography magazine in Tokyo, to directing Ring Cube photo gallery in Ginza, to managing a leading photography school, and founding the T3 International Photo Festival in Tokyo, he has always focused on both local and international photography communities.</i><br>\n</p>\n<p><i>Each stage of his career followed a quest to solve large-scale problems as he built bridges for photographers where language and cultural barriers may have otherwise restricted opportunities for exposure and collaboration. He credits his own success to a community of friends who have supported him along the way.</i>\n</p>\n<p><i>We’re thrilled that Hayami is returning as a juror for the <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/photo-competitions/street-photography-awards-2020\">LensCulture Street Photography Awards</a> in 2020. In this interview, he speaks with Amy Parrish about his influences, interests, and perspective on the state of street photography moving forward.</i>\n</p>\n<hr>\n<p><strong>Amy Parrish: One can read a lot about your accomplishments online but it’s a bit more challenging to get to the heart of an experience. I’m really curious about your personal journey.</strong>\n</p>\n<p>Ihiro Hayami: To start from the very beginning of the beginning—my father is a professional photographer. Ever since I was born, I have been surrounded by photographs. They say, ‘like father like son’ but I wasn’t interested in photography until after I graduated from college.\n</p>\n<p>First, I wanted to be a graphic designer but I realized I wasn’t the best kid in the class, and I felt that if I wasn’t the best kid in the class, how am I going to be the best in the world? I’m the kind of guy that if I want to do a thing, I want to be in the top five.\n</p>\n<p>After a stint selling ad space for a photography magazine, I realized I loved to sell things and I thought maybe I could use that to help photographers: those who were good at making work but not good at selling. Since I can speak English, I also thought I could serve as a bridge between Japanese photographers and other countries. This seemed like an idea that I could be good at.\n</p>\n<p><strong>AP: I can see the connection between building international bridges and supporting photographers, but starting a large-scale photography festival is still quite a leap. How did that come into being?</strong>\n</p>\n<p>IH: I had been working as the Chief Editor for PHaT PHOTO magazine. Around this time the publishing business, around the world, was going down. I wanted to create an alternative for a struggling magazine industry that could actually help photographers because that was at the core of what I wanted to do. I thought maybe a photography festival could be the solution. Festivals can be thematic like a magazine issue, re-introducing new photographers in different settings. It brought together all of my experiences in sales, as a gallery director, and editor-in-chief together in a new way.\n</p>\n<p><strong>AP: What was your strategy for achieving what others may have seen as insurmountable?</strong>\n</p>\n<p>IH: In putting together an international festival, I reached out to colleagues who had experience. Everybody helped me with my ideas. I consulted Inri and RongRong, co-founders of the Jimei x Arles Photo Festival in China, and also with my friend, Sam Barzilay, of United Photo Industries and a founder of Photoville in New York. I was in talks with Himeno-san (<i>Kimi Himeno</i>) of Akaaka Publishing, a well-established Japanese photo publisher. I’m lucky to have a lot of great friends who have helped me with what I wanted to do. That’s my talent. Other people are the best part of me.\n</p>\n<p><strong>AP: And there are so many people working in this industry. I imagine you’ve looked through the work of hundreds, if not thousands, of photographers around the globe. What advice do you have for photographers putting together a portfolio of work that captures your attention?</strong>\n</p>\n<p>IH: Edit tight. Be critical. Everyone on a judging panel has seen a lot of great photography. Erik Vroons from GUP Magazine once said to me it’s like being a food critic and I totally agree. You’re always eating great food all the time, so great food becomes your baseline standard. For photography competitions, in order to stand out, you really have to be critical about your work in terms of preparing a portfolio and really push yourself. You have to become objective about your work. It has to be the best of you. If I see one image below-the-bar as part of a larger portfolio then I might think, maybe that photographer isn’t as good as I thought.\n</p>\n<p><strong>AP: Photographers are often advised to search for their unique voice or style. Curators seem to have their own stylistic preferences as well, and I understand your work at Ring Cube gallery had something special in how you brought disparate works into the same space together. Can you put into words some of the traits that draw you into a photograph?</strong>\n</p>\n<p>IH: The very first photograph that I purchased was from Sohei Nishino’s <i>Diorama Map</i>. The images that I tend to be attracted to have a very strong visual style or visual narrative/story. Plus, with Nishino’s work, there are layers of time compressed into the image. For me, it could be the subject/object photographed, or the way they are photographed, or the amount of time that a photographer spends (in research, communications, whatever) to create the image. Being able to see these elements come together in an image is truly a privilege.\n</p>\n<p><strong>AP: I’m inspired by your playful description of always aiming for the top five. In your opinion, who are the top street photographers of all time?</strong>\n</p>\n<p>IH: My fav top five street photographers have no surprises in names: Daido Moriyama, William Klein, Saul Leiter, Garry Winogrand, and Henri Cartier-Bresson.\n</p>\n<p><strong>AP: All classics! One of our entrants posed a question about how the genre has been shifting recently. They noted growing tensions for street photographers in certain parts of the world where societal norms demand more privacy for people sharing public spaces. It reminds me of your own experience maneuvering through a changing photo publishing industry. What’s your perspective on the future of street photography?</strong>\n</p>\n<p>IH: It’s important to acknowledge the world of photography is constantly changing, as most things in life. But the bright side is that photography is not a traditional art form where you have to follow somebody’s style and then refine it. You can invent your own way of making pictures. Restriction really forces you to re-think or re-construct the way you shoot, which can turn into something amazing you may have never discovered if you didn’t have to work around a problem that you encountered. The future of street photography is wide open, and really up to the photographers living today.\n</p><p>Enjoy more great photography:</p><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/jordi-casanas-barcelona-punctum\">Barcelona Punctum</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/meg-hewitt-tokyo-is-yours\">Tokyo is Yours</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/mirko-saviane-b-uranus-inside-an-island-in-the-venetian-lagoon\">B-Uranus: Inside an Island in the Venetian Lagoon</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/cesar-ordonez-tokyo-blur-2\">Tokyo Blur</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/fuku-heavy-light-recent-photography-and-video-from-japan\">Heavy Light: Recent Photography and Video from Japan</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/jean-de-pomereu-sans-nom\">Sans Nom</a></li></ul><section class=\"fl-slideshow\"><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1c28f3c2-0872-4846-b008-a9398be4bf14.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img
