tablecloth\n   </figcaption>\n  </figure>\n </section> \n</hr>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 22 Jul 2020 07:46:23 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/48cccb95-ce69-4414-9bf7-7778edd17c12.jpg","linkMd5":"90d2166ba010156f945eeac7dedbd97d","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-48-052_01160efe8e19d0cf.webp","destWidth":632,"destHeight":474,"sourceBytes":50801,"destBytes":20320,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/48cccb95-ce69-4414-9bf7-7778edd17c12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn99@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-48-052_01160efe8e19d0cf.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/bad2accd-ce09-4118-9b87-6d4e9dbe78e3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn8@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-07-508_f95ec49ab989c16e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/48cccb95-ce69-4414-9bf7-7778edd17c12.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn28@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-56-405_cd7a353287fe3d0a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9de3cc8b-7605-4305-9811-e473e17788e6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn23@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-06-371_800e96ac95384752.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a0c87f8c-8506-40bd-a679-59a66d9b4f1e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn4@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-03-425_59ba2a99ced1389b.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d0366d73-0827-42fa-b58a-c336900e0fc6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn3@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-00-813_eac9875f1711ad86.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066812},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Pseudologia","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/rebecca-horne-pseudologia","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Pseudologia</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Rebecca Horne</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/aa3fdafa-b966-498d-848d-4bc18882793d.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Rebecca Horne arranges everyday objects into illusion-filled still lifes and tableaux, creating worlds of unexpected visual relationships.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>‘Pseudologia fantastica’ is a psychological term used to describe someone who weaves quasi-delusional tales into their own personal narrative. In many ways, it is an idea somewhat synonymous with art-making. Photo-based artist Rebecca Horne borrowed from this term for her upcoming publication, <em>Pseudologia, </em>which will accompany her exhibit, <em>Buried Intentions,</em> at Galerie Confluence in Nantes, France this fall. She explains, “I don’t actually think of an artist as a liar, so much as someone who makes things up and lives, at least part of the time, in an alternate reality of their own creation. I like that the <em>pseudo</em> can refer to the <em>almost</em> or <em>nearly</em> quality of the photos, which in this book are iterative, building on each other, and dependent on their relationships.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div> © Rebecca Horne\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/rebecca-horne-pseudologia#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The images in this softcover artist book catalog the “mini-performances, temporary sculptures, and unscientific experiments” she stages for her camera. She explains, “I’m often chasing a singular image, one that perfectly describes an idea. However, I began to realize that the photographs I made on the way to making the standalone pictures felt more vibrant. So I started an exploration of these looser, more active images, organizing, shooting, and creating bridges between them. I welcomed the iteration over finality.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div> © Rebecca Horne\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/rebecca-horne-pseudologia#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>These looser photographs explore iterations of shapes like a sphere, or its opposite: a hole. In the image <em>Lunar Calendar</em>, she cut paper and paper plates into the shapes of moon phases. She then arranges the pieces to reference a moon phase chart, drawing visual similarities between household objects and astronomical phenomena. The viewer immediately recognizes a paper plate as both itself and the moon, offering the photographic image as an analogy, rather than an indexical representation of reality. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div> © Rebecca Horne \n<p>By borrowing the visual language of scientific photography and re-presenting it within an impossible world of her own creation, Horne draws on photography’s assumed relationship to truth, playing with our inclination to believe what we see as a tool to shake our sense of reality. “My dad was an archaeologist, and I think that perhaps some of my impulses come from going on digs with him as a kid. I have noticed how anthropologists try to reconstruct a culture from the smallest fragments of evidence. It’s imperfect, and, at times, it seems like they’re making things up in order to recreate lost worlds. Nonetheless, those fragments are important,” she states. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>© Rebecca Horne\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/rebecca-horne-pseudologia#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>In <em>Pseudologia</em>, the slippages between the three-dimensional everyday objects pictured and the concepts they simulate on the two-dimensional photographic plane, suggests the world we experience comes as much from the inside-out as the outside-in. What we perceive in the physical world has its origin in the world of our imagination. </p> \n<p><em>Editor’s note: You can pre-order </em>Pseudologia<em> through Horne’s </em><a href=\"https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/rebeccahorne/pseudologia/\"><em>Kickstarter campaign</em></a><em>.</em> </p>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/thierry-konarzewski-after-the-future\">After the Future</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/isamu-sawa-without-water\">Without Water</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/arja-hyytiainen-notes\">notes</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/vee-speers-the-birthday-party\">The Birthday Party</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/yoshiki-hase-ena\">Ena</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/gesche-wurfel-what-remains-of-the-day-71-years-after-the-end-of-world-war-ii\">What Remains of the Day: 71 Years After the End of World War II</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4e551d75-5a14-4474-b76d-7dd1fccb6953.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e43445ba-a738-4139-ae7d-658fce41a977.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Torn\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5a81c3c2-8ddf-4930-b65b-5686256ff4d6.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/99b3b8f0-67dd-40b2-968d-047fd14e9ea6.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e16295f8-dcfe-4832-ab6c-d74acba10d2f.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/368d5aff-65af-45fa-b83c-442b7359e9ae.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f25c8f55-34cc-4c79-918d-9508168d2c7f.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5e3b0533-b743-4153-8d49-f482569d10d6.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1a423c8d-3eab-49db-97ef-e2e2e1da76e7.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d09ddbbf-b89c-434d-9207-8edf10cdaef7.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/aa3fdafa-b966-498d-848d-4bc18882793d.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9df929cb-e7f6-476f-b6dc-2de45cddb969.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 26 Jun 2020 11:45:18 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/aa3fdafa-b966-498d-848d-4bc18882793d.jpg","linkMd5":"48df6538ba2323ff1ecc47f8cea6a35a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn48@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-47-579_f84dc62f9d1459fc.webp","destWidth":812,"destHeight":586,"sourceBytes":58771,"destBytes":19026,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/aa3fdafa-b966-498d-848d-4bc18882793d.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn48@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-47-579_f84dc62f9d1459fc.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4e551d75-5a14-4474-b76d-7dd1fccb6953.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn63@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-06-405_8d043d98021d72f0.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e43445ba-a738-4139-ae7d-658fce41a977.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn39@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-05-510_c698067dce828edc.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5a81c3c2-8ddf-4930-b65b-5686256ff4d6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn52@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-02-870_fc2e59bd8313323c.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/99b3b8f0-67dd-40b2-968d-047fd14e9ea6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn24@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-56-304_721dd1e681669847.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e16295f8-dcfe-4832-ab6c-d74acba10d2f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn15@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-02-246_fc61eceb7313cff7.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/368d5aff-65af-45fa-b83c-442b7359e9ae.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn72@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-03-388_d47cb3abb5c869a8.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f25c8f55-34cc-4c79-918d-9508168d2c7f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn3@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-13-630_58da6e1fff63ee61.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5e3b0533-b743-4153-8d49-f482569d10d6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn19@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-55-103_3877d840117fe22a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1a423c8d-3eab-49db-97ef-e2e2e1da76e7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn99@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-10-278_33dfc2bef7dcf895.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d09ddbbf-b89c-434d-9207-8edf10cdaef7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn52@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-11-777_3159479c68f27c7e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/aa3fdafa-b966-498d-848d-4bc18882793d.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn59@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-13-839_f8815d51b455f362.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9df929cb-e7f6-476f-b6dc-2de45cddb969.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn99@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-11-526_301c3da1d73a2f79.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066813},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Where Blue Birds Fly","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/homayra-adiba-where-blue-birds-fly","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Where Blue Birds Fly</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Homayra Adiba</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/f53ef36e-cd54-41e9-b135-73791535022f.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Homayra Adiba captures the hushed, ephemeral moments of everyday life that unfold across the rooftops of Bangladesh’s city of Dhaka.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p><em>Blue is a shape shifting, mood altering, atmospheric color. It can be filled with as much melancholia as nostalgia, as much serenity as ecstasy. In Homayra Adiba’s photographic series, </em>Where Blue Birds Fly<em>, a blue light suffuses the images, seeping into corners, illuminating quiet moments. </em> </p> \n<p><em>There is an essay in Rebecca Solnit’s book </em>A Field Guide To Getting Lost<em> entitled “</em>The Blue of Distance”<em>. It begins with the lines, “</em><em>The world is blue at its edges and in its depths. This blue is the light that got lost.” Adiba’s work is infused with this particular blue. A blue of longing for spaces, horizons, rooftops. It is a blue that speaks to separation, connection, and memory. The artist’s own connection to these rooftops touches each of these images, viewed from afar, asking questions about how we keep places within ourselves once we move away. </em> </p> \n<p><em>Plants grow, women gather, children fly kites, fireworks explode, life unfolds upon these spaces. Throughout the series we see the sprawl of the city, growing upwards and outwards. The rooftop then is perhaps a conduit to escape, an outdoor room to grow, a way to lay claim to a bit of sky. It is a space where past and present overlap, where the future can be felt in the sky opening up to possibility. In this interview for LensCulture, Magali Duzant speaks to Adiba about dipping into her childhood memories, life lived on the city of Dhaka’s rooftops and the thorny concept of ‘home’. </em> </p> \n<p><em></em> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Where Blue Birds Fly” © Homayra Adiba\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/homayra-adiba-where-blue-birds-fly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<p><strong>Magali Duzant: As a starting point, I’m wondering how you found your way to photography? </strong> </p> \n<p>Homayra Adiba: I would like to think of myself as a storyteller. Photography happens to be one of those mediums I fell in love with. When I was little, one of my aunts gathered all the cousins in the living room. She gave us each a sheet of paper and asked us to write down what we wanted to be when we are older. I vividly remember that she read my paper loudly in front of the audience! Not because I wanted to be an astronaut but because I wrote: “If lord (Allah) wishes!”<br><br>Soon enough, I understood that my chances of becoming an astronaut were slim. If you are from Dhaka, being a doctor or an engineer is the only option you get from family. Anything else would turn you into a black sheep. I was a black sheep. I couldn’t set my mind for either of those. I wanted to be something else but l had no idea what! And then it was time to go to college. I went for a degree in graphic design and multimedia. My parents were not very happy about it. Honestly, I wasn’t sure either. But that path eventually led me to photography. </br></br></p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Where Blue Birds Fly” © Homayra Adiba\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/homayra-adiba-where-blue-birds-fly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><br>I soon went to my parents to tell them I wanted to go for photography and that wasn’t easy. I had already dropped out of graphic design school. They had lost faith in me. But thank goodness for cinema, I could steal enough convincing dialogue to get them to let me transfer to a photography school! They had one condition. If I go for photography, I will be on my own. I took the challenge and applied to Pathshala South Asian Media Institute. I worked hard and got a scholarship there, which supported my education. Pathshala had opened a new world of photography for me, it was a proud transition in my life. </br></p> \n<p><strong>MD: Once you started photographing in earnest how did this body of work, <em>Where Blue Birds Fly,</em> begin?<br /></strong><br>HA: I always like to wander in the past, in memories. I like to live there. Everybody says you need to live for the future. But there I was, living in the past. Those days gave me hope to live for the future. </br></p> \n<p>This work started in my second year at Pathshala under the course of documentary. It was a weekly assignment about space. I thought to myself, ‘space’. That’s funny! Where the heck would I find a piece of space in Dhaka city? A city where on the public bus I had to tolerate the warm breath of my fellow passenger. Sometimes they would sleep on my shoulder! A city consisting of 18 million citizens! Is there really any space? I was thinking all of this on a late afternoon sitting on my rooftop. I thought, <em>oh well</em>. That’s a space. </p> \n<p>I started photographing rooftops. Initially it was just for that assignment. Those photographs were different than how the work turned out today. When the assignment was over, I kept taking pictures of different rooftops. Rooftops were bringing my childhood back. It was always so peaceful to end a hectic day on top of a rooftop; looking at the city, at the sunset, as the birds returned to their nests. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Where Blue Birds Fly” © Homayra Adiba\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/homayra-adiba-where-blue-birds-fly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>MD: When your work was first brought to my attention I was captivated by the color you use. The tinge of the photographs feels almost as if we are viewing these images through the fog of memory, there is a blue light that feels both familiar and otherworldly. Can you talk about the palette of your photographs and how it might connect to greater themes in the work?</strong> </p> \n<p>HA: Over time, <em>Where Blue Birds Fly</em> directed me towards many narratives, multiple meanings, and observations. But truly it’s a work where I relived my memories. I grew up in a joint family. A red old building in Dhaka where my cousins and I grew up. The rooftop was the place where we met. Even today, all the memories are as alive as if I were still 10 years old. Plabon (one of my cousins) used to play detective, he would spend hours trying to find out how that piece of pearl ended up on the rooftop. My uncle gave me lessons about trees and how they function there. My uncle, mejho mama, is a poet. He used to play flute on the rooftop. Till this day, that melody tinkles in my ears when I watch the city from a rooftop! I never heard anything like that after he became paralyzed. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Where Blue Birds Fly” © Homayra Adiba\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/homayra-adiba-where-blue-birds-fly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>One afternoon, he was very upset—one mango tree wasn’t producing any fruit for a couple of years; that mango tree was big for a rooftop tree. He worked so hard on it. I went to the tree and started scratching it, beating it, asking for mangos! I was mad, because uncle was dear to me. Uncle later sat me down and informed me about trees having life, emotions. He taught me about the scientist Sir Jagadish Chandra Bose who was also Bengali and who used his own invention, the <a href=\"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Crescograph\">Cresco graph</a> to measure plant response to different stimulation and thereby scientifically proved parallelism between animal and plants. </p> \n<p>He told me: “You have to be patient, for we don’t know when nature will take its place.” He asked me to apologize to the tree. I went and asked for forgiveness. You see, I learned trees had life on top of a rooftop. A year later, there were mangoes on that tree. My cousins and I would fly kites, count stars, sing a song there. When it rained, my mother and I would go there, and it’s a little cinematic, but we actually used to sing while being washed by raindrops! </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Where Blue Birds Fly” © Homayra Adiba\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/homayra-adiba-where-blue-birds-fly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>MD: Can you tell me a bit more about the specific rooftops you visited?</strong><br><br>HA: Our apartment was on the top floor, the rooftop had a garden planted by my father. He had a lot of pigeons; they would circle above the building before sunset. My father used to sit there, watching them, letting the day pass. The rooftop was a ritual, a place we city kids used to plan our picnics,where we would all meet when there was a power cut. I knew each person in my family a little intimately there. I watched crows schooling from my rooftop. I received my first love letter, from a strange teenage boy from the next building, on the rooftop. As if under the sky you become more open. When you can look down at the city, you want to slow down and rest. Even on my friend’s rooftop, we made many memories. You can just go there and sit you know? For however long you want. </br></br></p> \n<p>As it turns out, every rooftop had its own story—even the abandoned one. It told me about those people who don’t visit. The rooftops of office buildings were funny; so abandoned that it seems no one ever stepped foot there. Like, the moon landing! As if I was the first. In three years, I have been to many rooftops in Dhaka city. As a photographer, I even noticed that if you show up, randomly and ask for an entrance, people do welcome you to their rooftop! They would start conversations, little things to introduce their very own place. “See, from here you can see the new flyover or from here you can see the Mosque. You should come during this time to watch the fireworks!” Some of the old buildings were made in a way, where if you wanted to get to the rooftop you had to make your way through their bedrooms; those are the best kinds. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Where Blue Birds Fly” © Homayra Adiba\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/homayra-adiba-where-blue-birds-fly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>MD: Did you usually shoot at the same time of day?</strong><br><br>HA: I wanted to keep this feeling of nostalgia in my images. Most of them are taken in the evening, before sunset. That’s usually the time you would find me playing on my rooftop back in the 90s. I don’t know why exactly, but till this day I feel melancholic when the day is coming to an end. That time of the day when the sun is setting, everyone is heading towards home… even the crows go back to their nests. I feel both sadness and relief. Another day ends, tomorrow will be a new day. </br></br></p> \n<p>Like my childhood, the ‘rooftop generation’ is fading. The city is growing fast, now we have more high-rise apartments and less time to spare. In a three year span of working on this project, I could vividly feel how some kids in Dhaka city had never spent a moment on their rooftop. How they might not have a hint of how to improvise a polyethylene bag and turn it into a balloon when you are bored! Do teenage boys still pass small letters to the girls next door and secretly meet on the rooftop? </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Where Blue Birds Fly” © Homayra Adiba\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/homayra-adiba-where-blue-birds-fly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>MD: There is a lovely social aspect to the images—you are meeting neighbors, discovering other’s personal spaces, a communal feeling through image making emerges. In your biography you write about the idea of home being rooted in your photography and you mention that you moved to Michigan in 2016.Has this transition made its way into your imagery? </strong><br><br>HA: When I started working on my documentaries, I thought I had all the ideas one needs about home. For me, home was there. Where my land is, where my family is, where my friends are. Little did I know that ‘home’ might bring a different meaning to my life! A meaning, that seemed absurd in the beginning, and for a long time after. I was very determined, when I moved to the USA, that soon enough I would come back to my land, my home. And I did, within two months of moving, I actually came back to Dhaka. But home wasn’t there anymore. The city was the same, but someone else was waiting for their family on the top floor of that red old building. My family was in Michigan. And my friends were all busy. <br><br>It’s a strange feeling, when you are in a different land, the weather is different, the people are, the language is, the roads, even the trees! And you are not really a tourist there. I felt like a tropical tree in Michigan… with no roots. Displaced. I am not from here. I don’t have a clue! How is it to be someone from here? Never in my life had I felt so alien. But once I returned back to Dhaka, I felt the same. Disconnected. As if, there wasn’t a little bit of home left for the city to offer me. I became, what I felt at that time, homeless. </br></br></br></br></p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Where Blue Birds Fly” © Homayra Adiba\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/homayra-adiba-where-blue-birds-fly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>It felt like forever that, as a storyteller, I had lost my story. No place to call home. No past to wander around. Sure, I had a present, but no clue what I was supposed to do with it. Not that I had plans of moving to a different country! So I really had no idea what I could do here. My family, including myself, had to survive here first. The first couple years were just working at a minimum wage job, paying rent and for what? I felt trapped really. Broken and lost. In those times of misery I would look at snow and think, how mesmerizing! Would you give up everything to watch a snowy night? I tried being friends with the trees here. Like my uncle taught me. And they did help me. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From the series “Where Blue Birds Fly” © Homayra Adiba\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/homayra-adiba-where-blue-birds-fly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>MD: Do you see or feel a difference in your work or working methods? </strong> </p> \n<p>HA: The more I try to understand the definition of ‘home’, and the new meaning it offers me, I am not sure if I like any of them but they are all true. I even googled the definition of ‘home’: “A place where one lives permanently, especially as a member of a family.”<br><br>A year back, I realized I know one or two things about this place. I know one or two people. I have one or two memories. I have taken one or two pictures. I have learned one or two new things here. </br></br></p> \n<p>For now, this may be home. I live in a not so busy but not so quiet area in Michigan. I like it here. The neighbors are nice, the geese are a little aggressive… deer here are dear and squirrels are always asking for more food! The kids do play outside still. Everyone loves a sunny day and no one likes the snow. These are the things I take pictures of. In the transition, when my family and I had to survive first, I didn’t always have the opportunity to take pictures. But this lack of opportunity made my mind explore different media. Linocut and print and recycled paper making are two of those I am practicing beside photography recently. </p> \n<p>My way of working has changed from photography and text to mixed media. I am still experimenting with all these resources and I’m spending time with my ongoing stories to understand what does it mean and how does it feel to exist? </p>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/camille-michel-on-the-shores-of-a-melting-ice-country\">On the Shores of a Melting Ice Country</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/w-scott-olsen-nostalgia-and-wonder-in-the-portraits-of-beowulf-sheehan\">Nostalgia and Wonder in the Portraits of Beowulf Sheehan</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/davide-monteleone-spasibo-the-chechen-compromise\">Spasibo, the Chechen Compromise</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f53ef36e-cd54-41e9-b135-73791535022f.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 28 Apr 2020 18:59:16 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/f53ef36e-cd54-41e9-b135-73791535022f.jpg","linkMd5":"b82fa7922148be1ed5a648844799fd7a","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn40@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-48-545_8192beeec7863c40.webp","destWidth":899,"destHeight":1599,"sourceBytes":306149,"destBytes":192358,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/f53ef36e-cd54-41e9-b135-73791535022f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn40@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-48-545_8192beeec7863c40.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ef22ac79-acf2-463a-8ee9-a6361477ef29.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn11@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-09-556_b0d8938cac11e795.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/2ab01817-e850-45c3-8631-7d8a9c509f5b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn68@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-08-710_e813db3d47cec560.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c1ce9bd1-1f0b-4a6e-b65a-863c6f4829d1.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn36@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-15-999_2dcdaebf311a2836.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5fe37495-a22a-4b8b-9038-00bc963bace9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn31@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-55-847_93eb7966ca0c232a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/207ab718-acea-461d-8730-931ac96744c7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn80@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-11-114_ee61d8885fb23c9a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1eb72ac4-46a8-491a-8d64-054226f49086.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn100@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-16-652_2e26e7638424106f.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/416fb85a-0c37-4ecb-a293-92cd0db39dfd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn100@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-05-877_b5344b2b38bd67f8.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f53ef36e-cd54-41e9-b135-73791535022f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn68@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-14-019_5e5bbdeb15fa597c.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066819},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"From ‘Apple’ to ‘Anomaly’","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/trevor-paglen-from-apple-to-anomaly","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>From ‘Apple’ to ‘Anomaly’</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Trevor Paglen</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/7d1feeaa-3a88-48d9-a5f1-45f53b629a7e.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Trevor Paglen’s spectacular display of images used for training Artificial Intelligence machines revealed the darker sides of non-human vision.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Trevor Paglen’s recent installation of some 30,000 color photographs in the Barbican’s Curve Gallery, <i>From ‘Apple’ to ‘Anomaly’</i>, took its cue from René Magritte’s 1964 painting <i>Ceci</i> <i>n’est pas une pomme</i>, which dismantled the assumed relation between word, image and thing. Magritte’s awareness of the arbitrary nature of the sign has currency in light of the ways in which Artificial Intelligence (AI) machines are now trained to ‘see’ the world.<br> </br></p> \n<blockquote>\n We began with the relative innocence of descriptive labels and images—“apple”, “apple tree”, “fruit”— but soon the categories and images identified with them demonstrated the more insidious side of this process— “alcoholic”, “debtor”, “drug addict”, “homeless”, “racist”. \n</blockquote> \n<p>Set apart from the mass of photographs and displayed on its own wall, Paglen presented a framed reproduction of Magritte’s painting as it would be labelled for AI networks, with bounding box annotations identifying what is represented within the picture — “a large white sign”, “black and white sign”, “a large green leaf”, “red and green apple”. Here, the process of labelling in its dumb literality remains blind to the joke of the painting itself and a pointer to the inherent problems of AI vision that we were shown through the spectacle of photographs arrayed along the Barbican’s curved wall. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>The Treachery of Object Recognition, 2019 © Trevor Paglen, Courtesy of the Artist, Metro Pictures, New York, Altman Siegel, San Francisco \n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/trevor-paglen-from-apple-to-anomaly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The photographs are taken from ImageNet, a database with currently more than 14 million images and over 21,000 categories and one of the main sources for training AI machine-learning technologies to facially recognize people and things. AI networks are taught to see the world as a result of being fed vast amounts of visual information sorted into various groupings known as “training sets”. The point of Paglen’s installation was to show us the mendacity at the heart of technological developments — the dominant value systems that get encoded within them. Nouns are not always neutral or innocent, images are treacherous, and how we identify images and things contains inherent prejudices and value judgments. We began with the relative innocence of descriptive labels and images—“apple”, “apple tree”, “fruit”— but soon the categories and images identified with them demonstrated the more insidious side of this process— “alcoholic”, “debtor”, “drug addict”, “homeless”, “racist”. The final category “anomaly” included people, many in disguise, masked and in costumes, their identity and classification uncertain. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Trevor Paglen: From ‘Apple’ to ‘Anomaly’ Installation view, The Curve, Barbican, 26 September 2019 – 16 February 2020 © Tim P. Whitby / Getty Images\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/trevor-paglen-from-apple-to-anomaly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Paglen’s earlier <i>Limit Telephotography</i> series, photographs of distant secret military bases, as well as his photographs of classified satellites and spacecraft in the earth’s orbit, often resulted in a distinctive formal aesthetic, abstract and diffused images, with their referents having to be signaled through a captioning text. In contrast, here we dwell with people’s social media images, the aesthetic of on-line vernacular photography, uncopyrighted populist images that ImageNet scraped from Google, Flickr, Facebook and Bing. </p> \n<p>Paglen showed us images that have been unethically appropriated and used without the permission of those who took them. The work, then, also raises issues about the loss of privacy and control of images posted on line. These images are not hidden or secret, they are common, testimony to how much of the life-world we now photograph— crazy, dizzying clusters and swarms of images, an absurdist visual encyclopedia, ranging from pictures of the sun, sky, dust storms, spy satellites (a clear in-joke), to spam (tins of), false teeth, pizza and banana boats. We know these images, they are not unfamiliar, in many ways they are numbingly banal. The point is however we are not meant to see them like this. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Trevor Paglen: From ‘Apple’ to ‘Anomaly’ Installation view, The Curve, Barbican, 26 September 2019 – 16 February 2020 © Tim P. Whitby / Getty Images\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/trevor-paglen-from-apple-to-anomaly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>What Paglen showed is a sampling of the images and labels that AI machines are fed in order to begin to visually make sense of the world. And the problem arises when it is pictures of people that are labelled and classified, when assumptions are made about how they look and their behavior. But while Paglen’s spectacular display alerted us to the problems in the process of developing AI training, it still remained silent about an important human dimension and paradox integral to ImageNet—AI machine vision is based on the intensive labor of piecemeal online workers looking at and tagging images. ImageNet’s current database required fifty thousand low-paid workers, all employed using Amazon’s crowdsourcing labor platform, Amazon Mechanical Turk. </p> \n<p>— Mark Durden </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Trevor Paglen: From ‘Apple’ to ‘Anomaly’ Installation view, The Curve, Barbican, 26 September 2019 – 16 February 2020 © Tim P. Whitby / Getty Images\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/trevor-paglen-from-apple-to-anomaly#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dina-litovsky-bachelorette\">Bachelorette</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/alexandra-polina-masks-myths-and-subjects\">Masks, Myths and Subjects</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/diane-ducruet-family-games\">Family Games</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/peter-leighton-before-the-great-unravelling\">Before the Great Unravelling</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/loren-nelson-under-wraps-buildings-in-transition-2\">Under Wraps: Buildings in Transition</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/jennifer-mcclure-laws-of-silence\">Laws of Silence</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/7d1feeaa-3a88-48d9-a5f1-45f53b629a7e.jpg","linkMd5":"8ff119e84607f0d3b31db8dabdfe2660","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn19@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-47-168_8d6e6a90fce0d4ea.webp","destWidth":1124,"destHeight":2000,"sourceBytes":906650,"destBytes":712052,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/7d1feeaa-3a88-48d9-a5f1-45f53b629a7e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn19@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-47-168_8d6e6a90fce0d4ea.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1a06c7bd-8880-45a1-b2ad-4f0b570624c6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn88@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-58-996_59e787093f65440a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/6e8f0d54-7889-44e2-bb47-969628d9c17e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn43@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-58-096_727653a7a0ca0a1e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/8139fa91-1d3c-4e25-ac13-507a33ab1a50.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn76@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-01-853_2b3dfc69ee7e8474.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/2958ba64-091b-4f07-b310-6e2dd53e6a07.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn91@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-51-556_fcaedb9afd72e38e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5728074a-c73b-402e-8d01-34baf086469f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn47@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-06-993_d1cda5ca541e7111.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7d1feeaa-3a88-48d9-a5f1-45f53b629a7e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn67@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-03-803_9429748fa405af8e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4e49dab3-9450-4467-9a08-c0d21ca701c3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn52@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-52-891_602cdedb51bf03d4.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/10aceed1-8eee-4490-89de-46245a11cf8c.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn28@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-59-893_4b7224564237e78d.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/233dc802-e4a5-4037-a2ac-2654d96b123b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn28@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-01-348_984ef457622bec6a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/966e6ed3-75e9-4120-9755-1e8312e6a894.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn28@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-57-183_1f44f5cbf9f8c0cd.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a1965501-26d4-450b-9c7f-17e201b305b7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn31@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-00-658_f455d4325df09377.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9f830487-c8b0-4c7c-a4f8-a1ec30e5bffa.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn100@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-59-514_68dee9ad483878cb.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066818},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"See Naples and Die","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/sam-gregg-see-naples-and-die","description":"\n        <hgroup><h1>See Naples and Die</h1><h3 class=\"fl-author\">Sam Gregg</h3></hgroup><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/39da0812-e620-4230-be6f-d52f1c95302f.jpg\"/><figcaption>These portraits of people who live in Naples feel as if they could have been made on the set of a movie — Each character comes to life in a single frame, and seemingly sets the stage for an intriguing narrative.</figcaption></figure><p><em>“See Naples and die.” </em><br>— Johann Wolfgang Von Goethe, Italian Journey, 1786.\n</p>\n<p>During the golden age of Spanish Bourbon rule, Naples was considered one of the most opulent and enchanting cities in the world. Many found it impossible to leave, only doing so upon dying.\n</p>\n<p>In a modern context, the phrase may be read as a tongue-in-cheek reference to the over-documented gang violence of the city. While outsiders may associate the phrase with the presence of the Camorra and glamorize the idea of violence and organized crime, they understand it solely through the lens of TV and film. To me, “See Naples and Die” bears a much more complex reading.\n</p>\n<blockquote>Over a year I was guided by the locals into the heart of this multi-layered city where eccentricity thrives, flamboyant clothing is paired with machismo, and gender politics is the opposite of the expected.\n</blockquote>\n<p>My project focuses on four of central Naples’ historically rich and contemporarily volatile areas – Forcella, Quartieri Spagnoli, Rione Sanità and Santa Lucia. Over a year I was guided by the locals into the heart of this multi-layered city where eccentricity thrives, flamboyant clothing is paired with machismo, and gender politics is the opposite of the expected. Here, where others seek easily identifiable caricatures such as ‘the brute boss’, I saw people filled with contradiction and the troubles and joys of everyday life.\n</p>\n<p>I was invited to share glimpses of their private lives, slowly coming to understand that to see Naples entirely would actually take a lifetime, perhaps giving new meaning to the phrase “See Naples and Die”. This project scratched the surface of my experiences and in many ways is the beginning of an on-going investigation into one of the world’s most vibrant and mysterious cities.\n</p>\n<p>— Sam Gregg\n</p>\n<p><em>Editor’s note: This project was selected as a Juror’s Pick for the <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/2020-lensculture-portrait-award-winners\">LensCulture Portrait Awards 2020</a>. We encourage you to <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/2020-lensculture-portrait-award-winners\">explore all of the winners and finalists</a> to discover a wide range of contemporary photographic portraits.</em>\n</p>\n<hr>\n<p><br>\n</p><p>Enjoy more great photography:</p><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/christian-berthelot-cesar\">CESAR</a></li><li><a Eastern Wood</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/andras-ladocsi-swallow\">Swallow</a></li><li><a Religions, One Roof</a></li></ul><section class=\"fl-slideshow\"><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/bcdde66c-5dac-409e-9a17-29f01b96c392.jpg\"/><figcaption>Luigi the Forcella Playboy, 2017</figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/39da0812-e620-4230-be6f-d52f1c95302f.jpg\"/><figcaption>Mary, The Spanish Quarter, 2018</figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d6f6d267-257f-41a9-89a5-532d7d6edf33.jpg\"/><figcaption>Nonna Bathed in Gold, The Spanish Quarter, 2018</figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/93da4bee-570a-4bea-83b7-cfecabe8a968.jpg\"/><figcaption>Alessandro, Rione Sanità, 2018</figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/92394404-f72f-4ec6-b08e-b786a0f56c7b.jpg\"/><figcaption>Mother & Daughter, Rione Sanità, 2019</figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f57b5ce4-6b0a-4950-a352-c3a4f421f4a3.jpg\"/><figcaption>Gennaro, Rione Sanità, 2019</figcaption></figure><figure><img 928e56.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5a461a05-0b5c-44a6-8766-4d74d71b38bb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn68@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-53-007_3544a05148446db7.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d0142126-0845-49a9-81ef-4a9fc257a94f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn12@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-54-597_07c9bde87f7c8fce.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066816},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Rare Bird: Self Portraits as Melodrama","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/kevin-moore-rare-bird-self-portraits-as-melodrama","description":"\n        <hgroup><h1>Rare Bird: Self Portraits as Melodrama</h1><h3 class=\"fl-author\">Kevin Moore</h3></hgroup><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/1d9f38f3-dedf-447a-8435-934e628a7f79.jpg\"/><figcaption>Self-portraits that reflect ideas of visibility and invisibility, what is acknowledged and what is not, gender, identity, and acceptance.</figcaption></figure><p>Inspired by film and femininity, my work explores character, narrative, and identity. Investigating self-portraiture, I ask viewers to consider their own responses to queerness as they see it. By utilizing my own identity and queer experience, I hope to engage the viewer in an unfamiliar set of circumstances.\n</p>\n<p>The photos ask: Can we live comfortably outside the norm? How do these characters challenge societal ideas of masculinity?\n</p>\n<p>Driven by emotion and intuition, I produce a melodrama that reflects ideas of visibility, and invisibility, what is acknowledged and what is not, questions that remain relevant in today’s politics.\n</p>\n<p>—Kevin Moore\n</p>\n<p><em>Editor’s note: This work is the 3rd Place, Series winner in the <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/2020-lensculture-portrait-award-winners\">LensCulture Portrait Awards 2020.</a> Be sure to check out <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/2020-lensculture-portrait-award-winners\">all of the winners and finalists</a>.</em>\n</p><p>Enjoy more great photography:</p><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/mona-hoobehfekr-iranian-makeup\">Iranian Makeup</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/nancy-lee-global-village\">Global Village</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/carlotta-cardana-the-red-road-picturing-modern-native-american-identity\">The Red Road: Picturing Modern Native American Identity</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/phillip-toledano-the-day-will-come-when-man-falls\">The Day Will Come: When Man Falls</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/bill-westheimer-the-manual-project-the-personalities-of-hands\">The Manual Project:&#60;br&#62;The Personalities of Hands</a></li><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/stephen-shames-bronx-boys\">Bronx Boys</a></li></ul><section class=\"fl-slideshow\"><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/082bb42a-9ac0-4f39-989a-2b89e992c04f.jpg\"/><figcaption>Untitled</figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d0dbf594-c326-4381-b007-8791353f4184.jpg\"/><figcaption>Untitled</figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/56d98055-beb0-453b-bc15-bdce01ce0beb.jpg\"/><figcaption>Untitled</figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c575cdb8-a190-48a8-92fe-eb5b5df03fe7.jpg\"/><figcaption>Untitled</figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9d09144e-1725-4c3a-b9af-60cdd78b4cad.jpg\"/><figcaption>Untitled</figcaption></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/21a0562d-76c0-418c-89ea-a04a0e5b044b.jpg\"/><figcaption>Untitled</figcaption></figure><figure><img ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 13 Apr 2020 17:01:55 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/1d9f38f3-dedf-447a-8435-934e628a7f79.jpg","linkMd5":"30965717b1a661d56ea3cc5a9924f204","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn92@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-47-602_80b29a5ad81f1da1.webp","destWidth":562,"destHeight":1000,"sourceBytes":179789,"destBytes":156240,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/1d9f38f3-dedf-447a-8435-934e628a7f79.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn92@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-47-602_80b29a5ad81f1da1.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1fefbd0b-1b99-4f81-b3ed-7053b3c870fb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn40@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-58-851_e6debf208e6e98a0.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e7cb545c-9942-441c-847c-9e408317e750.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn52@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-13-134_b426c13982632d32.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/082bb42a-9ac0-4f39-989a-2b89e992c04f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn88@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-07-679_2eb7eb4c4de6d4b4.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d0dbf594-c326-4381-b007-8791353f4184.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn40@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-00-042_f64a4d901e8150dc.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/56d98055-beb0-453b-bc15-bdce01ce0beb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn100@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-57-953_11062765d8df3360.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c575cdb8-a190-48a8-92fe-eb5b5df03fe7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn59@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-05-427_2fa85a4694c0cc66.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9d09144e-1725-4c3a-b9af-60cdd78b4cad.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn44@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-10-365_8482cdb527b9e783.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/21a0562d-76c0-418c-89ea-a04a0e5b044b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn48@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-00-260_7d137a0d993a1e1e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/06a4b21f-41bd-4dbb-8ca3-5397033a6198.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn96@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-56-626_b21c9fe9ad6b9819.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1d9f38f3-dedf-447a-8435-934e628a7f79.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn72@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-04-910_8dde1fdb9dd2298e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066820},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Making a Mess","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/karolina-wojtas-making-a-mess","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Making a Mess</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Karolina Wojtas</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/7136cf1a-e65c-44ba-a486-cf5ff72dc975.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Rebelling against the conservative conventions of schooling in Poland, Karolina Wojtas has given a carte blanche to her inner child, resulting in an explosion of mess, materials and experimentation.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p><em>While attending art school is seen as a rite of passage for artists working across all mediums, a common experience amongst art students is the feeling of limitation and lack of inspiration that the four walls of a classroom impose. Priority and praise is more often given to artists creating serious work built on classical themes, rather than peculiar, messy projects that lack boundaries and cohesion.</em><br> </br></p> \n<p><em>Against the odds, Karolina Wojtas has managed to transform her own experience of feeling stifled at school into a rebellious practice. The artist is no stranger to experimentation and pushing the limits of what we consider photography. Each of her images and exhibitions are built upon a foundation of impulse and chaos, perhaps better representing a genuine thought process than the clean limitations we see in traditional methods. Her series </em>abzgram <em>is a direct commentary on her educational experience, and in her project </em>We Can’t Live Without Each Other<em>, she speaks to the peculiar inner lives of siblings, and the tension that exists in the lifelong dynamic with her next of kin.</em> </p> \n<p><em>In this interview for LensCulture, <em>Wojtas</em> speaks to Cat Lachowskyj about the limitations of arts education, her creative process, and why she thinks it’s important to find beauty in the ugly and banal.</em> </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “Abzgram” © Karolina Wojtas\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/karolina-wojtas-making-a-mess#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>Cat Lachowskyj: When you started exploring your creativity, were you drawn to other mediums and forms, or were you always interested in photography? </strong> </p> \n<p>Karolina Wojtas: I decided that I wanted to be a photographer when I was 12 years old! To learn about art, I had to attend a specialized high school and gymnasium in my city, where we also learned how to work with other mediums like painting and sculpture. But yes, I have to say that I was always primarily focused on photography, and I hated learning about other techniques and mediums. That might have had more to do with the teachers—they didn’t give us any freedom, and they wanted us to conform to their own vision of art. </p> \n<p>Now, I try breaking the rules of straight photography by incorporating as many other mediums as I can. When it comes to photography, I’ve always done whatever I want, but when I revert back to something like painting, I still feel that sense of fear that I had during my time at art school. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “Abzgram” © Karolina Wojtas\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/karolina-wojtas-making-a-mess#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>CL: That’s sad to hear about education, especially for someone so young. I think that when we create things when we are younger, the beauty of those creations is that they don’t possess boundaries. Instead, we make things for the sake of making them, and that approach is still very present in your work. It’s probably why so many people are drawn to it: you create in ways that adults wish they still could, before they learned the rules. Tell me about your own mental state when you start making a project. What are the guidelines you give yourself, and how much planning is involved? How do you know when to start and stop?</strong> </p> \n<p>KW: Oh, I never know when it’s time to stop! None of my work is officially finished, because I’m always thinking about new photographs or objects that I need to create for an exhibition. I always try to prepare something new and different. Because of that, I don’t put my images in expensive frames. I prefer to create more temporary forms that I can modify. All of my projects are inspired by my surroundings—usually a banal thing that I see or experience each day. I photograph first, then read books, then photograph again. Once I have some images, I start reading more focused articles and sociology books to help me find other points of view. I also mix staged images with documents. </p> \n<p>That said, the most important thing is that I never stop working, and try not to think so much about those first steps. I always try to remain as present as possible. I don’t think I ever grew up from my childish approach—maybe my younger brother helped me with that. I am more childish than him. During family gatherings, I always sit with the children. They’re my best friends. They have these relentless, crazy ideas. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “We can’t live without each other” © Karolina Wojtas\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/karolina-wojtas-making-a-mess#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>CL: Aside from that early experience, how has your subsequent arts education affected your work?</strong> </p> \n<p>KW: At school, you’re taught to work on a single project, and it needs to be very serious. It’s very easy to feel afraid and feel blocked. At my school, there were some teachers who didn’t understand my work at all. Sometimes, I would start making work the way they wanted me to, but over time I realized that this way of working wasn’t for me. I started showing my own spontaneous work more and more, but the reaction wasn’t pleasant. I hope arts education continues to change, and that schools are equipped with more understanding lecturers. The most important people for me in art school were my peers—we created, cooked and spent so much time together. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “We can’t live without each other” © Karolina Wojtas\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/karolina-wojtas-making-a-mess#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>CL: In that same vein, <em>abzgram</em> is an interesting interpretation of the rigidity of education systems. You clearly drew from a repository of inspiration for the project, but when did you realize you wanted to make a photography project about these issues?</strong> </p> \n<p>KW: At some point, the Polish government decided to change the education system, and wanted to close down the gymnasium where I had taken art lessons as a child. They started reorganizing schools in my town, and decided to turn the gymnasium into a nursery. </p> \n<p>This irritated me, so I started doing research about the changes. Since my brother was in primary school, the changes hit close to home. And since things were changing so rapidly, many people were negatively affected. The school wasn’t prepared for the switch, affecting both the young students and teachers, who striked for almost three weeks. Schools were closed, and exams were executed in very strange ways. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “Abzgram” © Karolina Wojtas\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/karolina-wojtas-making-a-mess#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>So, it was—and still is—a strange time for education. Especially now with the pandemic, school is a nightmare. Teachers send a ton of homework to students and perform strange video-exams to prohibit cheating. TV at school used to be fun, but now the most boring, horrible, hellish version of school is viewed on our screens. </p> \n<p><strong>CL: Which of your personal experiences shaped the inspiration for the project? Do you have any specific memories that have gone into your work?</strong> </p> \n<p>KW: Themes surrounding schools have been on my mind for a long time. I hated high school, and the only nice thing about it was that I started photographing everything there: horribly messy rooms, strange places, and my friends at parties or having fun in the classroom. I always felt misunderstood throughout the education process, but I never had a definitive idea about what was wrong. The teachers were meant to be treated like God—like they could do anything. And the children were only meant to listen and be kind. </p> \n<p>I have lots of bad memories from school in Poland: teachers saying I was the worst writer, that they had never seen someone write as terribly as me. Now, I hate writing. It takes me days to force myself to answer an email. School is so important, because children spend so much of their time there, and teachers can very easily kill their freedom and creativity. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “We can’t live without each other” © Karolina Wojtas\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/karolina-wojtas-making-a-mess#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Similarly, groups of teenagers all start looking the same: the same shoes, the same shirts. School eliminates their creative thinking, and forces them to align with what the authors of books are perpetuating—not what they personally think or feel. Students who are able to quickly learn how to achieve good grades do so as a means of survival. They figure out which teacher never checks homework, or who they know will give a surprise exam. That information helps them pretend to be subordinate, which makes school a factory for producing a new mass of stupid citizens. The government creates a core curriculum, and sometimes schools feel like prisons—there are bars in the windows and doors. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “Abzgram” © Karolina Wojtas\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/karolina-wojtas-making-a-mess#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>CL: On top of the general visual chaos in your work, there’s an underlying tension coursing through your images. You often focus on subject matter that’s considered gross or ugly. Why are you drawn to this subject matter? </strong> </p> \n<p>KW: I live in a town where a Colosseum and pyramid were built! It’s so kitschy—we pretend we are rich, but the way we project that never looks good. I grew up in a time when it was fashionable to have glitter in your hair, wear frills, and own a red or green bag with matching shoes. This was the best outfit for formal occasions! I grew up around ugly things, but on the other hand, there is beauty in that ugliness. I love collecting strange materials, as well as bags and shoes. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “We can’t live without each other” © Karolina Wojtas\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/karolina-wojtas-making-a-mess#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>CL: Your younger brother seems to feature in your work a lot. In your series <em>We Can’t Live Without Each Other</em>, you take your viewers on a visceral journey through the unconditional love and tension that exists in sibling relationships. How did you approach making these visuals? Were there specific moments that inspired certain images?</strong><br> </br></p> \n<p>KW: I was an only child until I was 13 years old. Any time my parents asked me if I wanted siblings, I responded with something like, “I will find an axe, kill the kid and eat them.” But one day, my brother appeared, and our war with each other began. </p> \n<p>I use him as a model throughout this project, but in the past I always used to paint him blue, or put a sausage on his face. Last summer, while creating work for the Unseen ING Talent Award, I had to create a new project around the theme ‘Nature of Change.’ Our mentor was Adam Broomberg, and over a number of meetings, each of the artists discussed their projects. I thought about doing something with my brother, and remembered that when I was younger, I never wanted siblings. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled, from the series “Abzgram” © Karolina Wojtas\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/karolina-wojtas-making-a-mess#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Drawing from those memories, I began creating weird and scary torture scenarios. I found a ton of posts on the Internet made by children looking for advice on how to scare or harm their brothers and sisters. Sibling relationships are so strange—they are your closest family members, but are also sometimes your worst enemies, fighting over the love of your parents. But not to scare anyone: all of the images were staged. And I have an excellent relationship with my brother! </p> \n<p><strong>CL: How did this project inspire your subsequent work? What are you working on now? </strong> </p> \n<p>KW: Me and some friends resurrected our student gallery in the Lodz Film School’s dormitory. Because we are in quarantine, we host <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/accounts/login/?next=/palarniasztuki/\">one-day residencies</a> with different artists on Instagram. Right now we are focused on photography, but over time we will definitely be mixing mediums and techniques. I have to say, during this strange time, I’ve tried to make something, but most of the time I start and cannot finish. </p> \n<hr> \n <p><br><br> </br></br></p> \n <p><br><br> </br></br></p>\n \"We can't live without each other\"\n   </figcaption>\n  </figure>\n  <figure>\n   <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5b45aa58-2415-4f2d-aa0f-c8ca129dc8b8.jpg\" />\n   <figcaption>\n
