src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b9e84f54-7f8c-4dc0-aced-363d143136d4.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Minnesota.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/702256b1-13c3-4431-9d28-24abfc420692.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Minnesota.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ca26058a-2c80-439b-87bb-4c4a4d29ea06.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Minnesota.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5d2c34c8-5543-45e2-b21f-e227abd39661.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Arkansas.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/640045e6-a458-4ac1-bb97-ca5938741654.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Mississippi.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/726e0acf-66b6-4853-ace4-1dd10249b938.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Mississippi.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/03ef5f46-81c8-4377-99a9-28ceb2050c14.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Mississippi.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/22d7beaa-f9cd-4b86-a0e7-dd5b93409c5b.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   New Orleans.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/cfb7a01a-ed21-40b5-9c63-01c3b8b42519.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   New Orleans.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/29b930c2-f169-48d8-b395-e44e299d3d38.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   New Orleans.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Wed, 15 Apr 2020 17:47:22 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/5d2c34c8-5543-45e2-b21f-e227abd39661.jpg","linkMd5":"92058e6868cf3245e639e828d9257a11","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn72@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-47-770_cc0ba2eafa63e71d.webp","destWidth":910,"destHeight":1618,"sourceBytes":347009,"destBytes":268536,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/5d2c34c8-5543-45e2-b21f-e227abd39661.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn72@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-47-770_cc0ba2eafa63e71d.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c2280eca-4368-4b34-bb4f-e564bdc0dc26.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn60@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-16-204_e10f3fb552062d70.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/b9e84f54-7f8c-4dc0-aced-363d143136d4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn32@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-12-979_fb6753a0137c7404.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/702256b1-13c3-4431-9d28-24abfc420692.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn100@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-10-057_e41e5cb2ff640485.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ca26058a-2c80-439b-87bb-4c4a4d29ea06.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx29/cdn68@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-16-737_c3c0b207bd127ce5.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/5d2c34c8-5543-45e2-b21f-e227abd39661.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn63@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-11-139_d1e77ca26dc78f92.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/640045e6-a458-4ac1-bb97-ca5938741654.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn92@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-13-701_964d3a29aca728cc.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/726e0acf-66b6-4853-ace4-1dd10249b938.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn67@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-55-284_c66e217a17bc8bb0.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/03ef5f46-81c8-4377-99a9-28ceb2050c14.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn75@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-08-503_36f8b30662f48c05.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/22d7beaa-f9cd-4b86-a0e7-dd5b93409c5b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn100@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-54-410_b6b409b8768dc05c.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/cfb7a01a-ed21-40b5-9c63-01c3b8b42519.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn59@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-06-452_7873b87bd7ea731f.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/29b930c2-f169-48d8-b395-e44e299d3d38.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn96@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-05-853_f0010ab06a7f0a0b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066820},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Responding to Tragedy with Art and Hope","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/joana-choumali-responding-to-tragedy-with-art-and-hope","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Responding to Tragedy with Art and Hope</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Joana Choumali</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/055c7539-5a1c-4597-a51a-e4561e80aebe.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Ivorian artist Joana Choumali instinctively responded to a national tragedy four years ago by embroidering on a series of photographs she had made with her iPhone — the results are images of hope and healing.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Healing is a process. We mend our wounds, stitch by stitch, as time fuses the brokenness between. Multidisciplinary artist, Joana Choumali, takes this metaphor to heart in her award-winning series of embroidered photographs, <em>Ça</em> <em>Va Aller </em>(<em>It Will Be Fine</em>). Recognized as one of LensCulture’s 2014 Emerging Talents, Choumali was presented with the eighth Prix Pictet in November; an award symbolizing the theme of Hope<em>.</em> </p> \n<p><em></em> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Ça va aller”, 2019 © Joana Choumali\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/joana-choumali-responding-to-tragedy-with-art-and-hope#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>In early 2016 Choumali created abroad during her second residency awarded by the Ifitry Contemporary Art Center in Essaouira, Morocco. After an immersive experience of art-making, the memories of her return home to the Ivory Coast will forever be tainted by global events. On the same day she boarded her flight, airlines across the world were thrust into high alert when a trio of suicide bombers attacked Brussels Airport and a major metro station. Yet, for Choumali, the epicenter of another tremor struck much closer to home, a mere nine days before. </p> \n<p>On March 13, 2016, terrorists gunned down nineteen people, injuring at least 33 others, on the beaches of Grand Bassam, a resort town near her home in Abidjan where Choumali’s family often met for Sunday lunch. Upon her return, memories of this once-familiar landscape were drowned out by a tragic sense of loss. Choumali walked the shoreline and felt waves of sadness in the air. “The energy was different as if life was painfully running in a melancholic slow motion. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Ça va aller”, 2019 © Joana Choumali\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/joana-choumali-responding-to-tragedy-with-art-and-hope#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>”Where restaurants and beachfront hotels were once brimming with tourists, Choumali instinctively documented this new sense of hollowness in largely vacant spaces, using her smartphone, before participating in a psychiatric conference that encouraged residents to take advantage of free consultations at the General Hospital in Grand Bassam. “Except for the first week, people would hardly talk about their experience and the trauma. They would end the conversation with this very Ivorian expression: ‘Ça va aller’ (It will be okay).” A phrase of comfort concealed emotional avoidance. The complimentary services were intended to help people better cope with trauma born from this collective suffering. </p> \n<p>For Choumali, the process of healing emerged through creation. She never intended for the casual collection of smartphone images to come together in the way they did. This direction was born from intuition as she began piecing thoughts and emotions together during long periods of time spent at home or in waiting rooms where she, herself, was healing from illness. “I had this urge to express myself and to continue to work; to spend time with the pictures.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Ça va aller”, 2019 © Joana Choumali\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/joana-choumali-responding-to-tragedy-with-art-and-hope#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>What started in the privacy of her own room began to spill out and absorb other areas of her life. “I would take a canvas with me in a little bag and embroider from the hospital waiting room, in traffic, etc. I was stitching every day, all day.” Some pieces took several weeks to complete and the work continued over a period of three years.<br><br>Choumali describes herself as self-taught in the art of embroidery and found herself repeating the same stitch, suturing her photographs, “as if it was to repair a wound.” She shares fond memories of the N’zassa tradition, an artform symbolizing the unity of multiple cultures through assorted pieces of cloth bound together by thread. “I remember my maternal grandmother used to stitch all day, doing patchworks with little leftovers of wax fabrics. I was fascinated by her patience. I wondered why she would put so much effort in stitching with a needle and thread.” </br></br></p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Ça va aller”, 2019 © Joana Choumali\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/joana-choumali-responding-to-tragedy-with-art-and-hope#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>When Choumali asked her grandmother why she didn’t use the sewing machine for these patchworks as she did when making dresses, the response was merely silence and a soft smile. “Today I fully understand the effect of hand-stitching. I was able to allow myself to embroider on my images in an instinctive way, marking a turning point in my way of understanding/processing life through my art. My inner universe merges with the exterior; the photographs I had taken. This meditative approach allows me to discover another way of experiencing certain events in my life.” </p> \n<div> \n <div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n </div>Untitled from the series “Ça va aller”, 2019 © Joana Choumali\n <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/joana-choumali-responding-to-tragedy-with-art-and-hope#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n</div> \n<div>\n In one of her pieces, a man is wrapped in a red embrace like veins spreading outwards into threaded white air. Choumali interprets this as a breath of life. “These marks of vitality that hold and inhabit us all and push us to survive and heal ourselves.”\n <br> </br>\n</div> \n<p>In another, she photographs absence in the empty landscape and imagines it full of life once again. Now lush with vegetation, Choumali embroiders cocoa trees in golden thread. “The sky is filled with small, fluorescent yellow dots which represent all the thoughts, expectations, and interior hopes which will not be formulated but which exist inside of us.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled from the series “Ça va aller”, 2019 © Joana Choumali\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/joana-choumali-responding-to-tragedy-with-art-and-hope#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>When she returned from London after receiving the Prix Pictet, her family naturally gathered back together at the restaurant they used to frequent before the attacks. “That day I saw Grand Bassam again; the Grand Bassam I used to know.” She recalled her footsteps along deserted shores and streets in 2016 in surreal contrast. “It was as if the wound had healed.” Choumali now sees resilience, the healing power of time, and “this wonderful ability to recover from trauma.” </p> \n<p>“I realized that it’s not about denying the difficulty of a situation. The most important thing is to recognize it, to work on it, and take each step forward as a positive step; one day at a time.” </p> \n<div> \n <br> </br>\n</div>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/david-maisel-library-of-dust\">Library of Dust</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/olivia-maria-rubio-fluid-forms-oliva-maria-rubio-s-take-on-art-photography\">Fluid Forms: Oliva María Rubio’s Take on Art Photography</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/tadas-kazakevicius-between-two-shores\">Between Two Shores</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/guilherme-gerais-the-best-of-mr-chao-a-futurologist-collection\">The Best of Mr. Chao: A Futurologist Collection</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/panayotis-papadimitropoulos-meta-photographs\">Meta-photographs</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/sofie-amalie-klougart-reaching-europe\">Reaching Europe</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1f45ac8d-3e6f-47a3-8c13-5c43edf0e714.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/012332b9-1594-4051-a735-d48153add861.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/21d78522-68c7-4347-93a2-5bb82d58a2f8.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/26a20c69-b6c7-42f2-83b4-a1a1d8a36b06.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/055c7539-5a1c-4597-a51a-e4561e80aebe.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ce99bc2a-ed61-4b8a-a321-9a2df16ab244.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/90088237-9832-4b90-b534-b1fa1dea3e04.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3340e77e-313e-48bc-a145-a7dae246f14d.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 18 Jun 2020 17:02:51 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/055c7539-5a1c-4597-a51a-e4561e80aebe.jpg","linkMd5":"588c4d47b5d617b56d5274c42d1e8461","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn56@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-47-888_00f9de8cda5ce519.webp","destWidth":1124,"destHeight":1124,"sourceBytes":1648785,"destBytes":332288,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/055c7539-5a1c-4597-a51a-e4561e80aebe.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn56@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-47-888_00f9de8cda5ce519.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1f45ac8d-3e6f-47a3-8c13-5c43edf0e714.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn24@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-03-909_d13eb120ec6ddc5b.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/012332b9-1594-4051-a735-d48153add861.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn36@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-01-118_ab83bb3276c5c5b7.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/21d78522-68c7-4347-93a2-5bb82d58a2f8.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn16@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-07-094_d009679ff0ed6003.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/26a20c69-b6c7-42f2-83b4-a1a1d8a36b06.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn36@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-16-588_9d6f13eff3ac56f0.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/055c7539-5a1c-4597-a51a-e4561e80aebe.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn31@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-15-205_7b4042ded48cbba7.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ce99bc2a-ed61-4b8a-a321-9a2df16ab244.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn8@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-59-163_9f16ce86007f33cf.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/90088237-9832-4b90-b534-b1fa1dea3e04.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn12@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-58-634_efce0f5f5d25d7f6.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3340e77e-313e-48bc-a145-a7dae246f14d.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn12@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-52-817_172898ec555f357b.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066814},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Myth of a Woman","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/agnieszka-sosnowska-myth-of-a-woman","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Myth of a Woman</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Agnieszka Sosnowska</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/43014d6a-609e-4e04-b3c7-1fa7787db14e.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Agnieszka Sosnowska’s striking self-portraits chronicle rural life in the volatile landscape of her adopted homeland, East Iceland.&nbsp;\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p><em>How can we picture the somewhat invisible relationship we have with our surroundings? Charting daily life in the depths of rural Iceland,</em> Myth of a Woman<em> captures the often ungraspable feeling of living with nature. Agnieszka Sosnowska’s quiet and reflective photographs depict this isolated existence with elegance and tenderness. </em> </p> \n<p><em>Born in Warsaw, Sosnowska studied in the US before relocating to East Iceland in 2005. Photography, and in particular self-portraiture, helped her form an intimate bond with the wild and unpredictable new landscape she found herself in. A counter-image to the frenetic pace of urban existence, photographing this radically different way of life could have become a spectacle for viewers to fall for the mystique of faraway lands. Instead, Sosnowska’s photographs are thought-provoking, dipping between the beautiful and the rugged realities of farm life.</em> </p> \n<p><em></em><em>In this interview, Sosnowska speaks to Rachel Wolfe for LensCulture about the process of adapting to a new environment, her relationship to self-portraiture and the Icelandic myths she draws inspiration from.</em> </p> \n<p><em></em> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Ice Fishing. Kleppjárnsstaðir, Iceland. 2016. © Agnieszka Sosnowska\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/agnieszka-sosnowska-myth-of-a-woman#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>Rachel Wolfe: Your photographs convey a strong presence and understanding of your surroundings. In terms of your choice to emigrate to Iceland, do you think the desire to live closely with nature is often misunderstood?</strong><br> </br></p> \n<p>Agnieszka Sosnowska: I think it’s often romanticized. I read <em>Into the Wild</em> by Jon Krakauer while visiting Iceland. That book was a huge influence in my life. I questioned what I wanted out of it. I knew I wanted to be with nature, not to visit it. Before making the decision to move to the countryside in East Iceland, I would share my plan with fellow Icelanders. The response from many was: “You are very brave.” </p> \n<p>I believed that surviving New England winters had prepared me for anything. I was wrong. I thought I was tough. I was not. Winters in Iceland take on a whole other definition of: “Are you kidding, you can’t drive in this!” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>A Rinse. Krafla, Iceland.2019. © Agnieszka Sosnowska\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/agnieszka-sosnowska-myth-of-a-woman#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>RW: What was the process of adaptation like for you? </strong> </p> \n<p>AS: When you live as we do, you have to become self-reliant very quickly. If you are not, then you can’t do it. Years back our water-source dried up. It was a very dry summer. We were not the only farm with this problem. Getting water from a nearby stream the entire summer to wash dishes, cook, flush toilets and wash ourselves got old pretty quickly. My husband surveyed our land, found a new spring underground, and spent months digging a new water system. The project was immense. The distance he dug was 1km away from our farm. He laid the pipeline from the new spring to our farm and created better water pressure. I was so relieved he had the skills to do this himself. </p> \n<p>Currently we are in the process of replacing the roof of our farm. For years he has been acquiring the carpentry tools to work the wood himself instead of buying it straight from a hardware supplier. Living this way is both rewarding and exhausting. I think we both have a deep sense of pride when we accomplish a project. It is long, hard and often involves a lot disagreeing. I often say if you really want to test a relationship with anyone, build something together over a long period of time and see if you succeed. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Holding On. Hallormsstaður, Iceland. 2019. © Agnieszka Sosnowska\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/agnieszka-sosnowska-myth-of-a-woman#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>RW: You’ve described your move to Iceland as a choice you could have never planned. Can you speak more about this desire and sense of ‘not knowing’, and how it relates to your work?</strong> </p> \n<p>AS: In 2005, I married an Icelander and moved to a farm in the Eastern part of Iceland. This was not my plan. At the time, I had been living in Boston and working as a teacher. I have grown in three ways since moving to Iceland. </p> \n<p>The first was becoming a wife and learning to compromise. The second was coming into my own as a woman. I have found strength and support from Icelandic women. This encouraged me to become confident and celebrate who I am, rather than apologize for it. The third was to be in a constant dialogue with nature. Living in place with frequent earthquakes, crazy wind speeds and the occasional volcano eruption reminds a person just how small they really are. </p> \n<p>I met my Icelandic husband while on a three day visit to Iceland during Thanksgiving break. Iceland was not on my list of places to travel. My girlfriend’s daughter, who was turning sixteen, picked Iceland as the place she’d most like to visit for her birthday. I was asked to accompany them for the trip. </p> \n<p>At the hotel in Iceland my friend´s daughter picked the most expensive day tour to experience. A snow mobile ride on top of a glacier. I was terrified and completely out of my element. The tour guide arrived to the hotel lobby to pick up the group. Four years later I married the tour guide and moved to Iceland. Needless to say it was a good tour. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Floating, 2019. Silver Gelatin Print. 15 x 19 inches on 16 x 20 inch paper. © Agnieszka Sosnowska \n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/agnieszka-sosnowska-myth-of-a-woman#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>RW: Did you ever miss your previous life in the States? </strong> </p> \n<p>AS: My parents and I were born in Poland. We are first generation Americans. I emigrated to the United States at the age of four. Learning a new language, making a home, and adapting to a new culture far away from Boston has come with challenges and rewards. </p> \n<p>Being an immigrant is perhaps the most difficult transition any human being can go through. Many times I wanted to just give up and return to the States. There is comfort in the familiar. Today I’m glad I didn’t. I have a better quality of life in Iceland. I have created a life I never imagined. It is mine. </p> \n<p><strong>RW: Much of your work is self-portraiture. In what ways is the process of photographing other people different and similar to photographing yourself? Do you go through a process of preparation? </strong> </p> \n<p>AS: When I am photographing others, such as my students it becomes a ceremony. We set a date and a time to take pictures, we plan around an idea or a personal interest of theirs that we want to try to play with in the pictures. I then set a specific time frame that we’ll be working, between one and three hours. Often it’s what we’re doing together, rather than the picture itself, that becomes the end result. It’s the conversations that become a moment rather than the picture sometimes. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Seeing the Light. Fremrasel, 2018. © Agnieszka Sosnowska\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/agnieszka-sosnowska-myth-of-a-woman#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>When I photograph myself I am impulsive with the camera. I might take a few items from my farm that I want to play around with to tell a story. One such thing was a reindeer skin. I was with my husband for his first reindeer hunt. It was pretty epic. To pull a 250kg reindeer down from the top of a mountain is impossible and surreal. That reindeer skin was part of our wedding ceremony. We exchanged vows on it. Many years later I was running around the farm with the skin trying to make a nude self portrait. My husband would go crazy watching me do this because tanning the skin cost him a fortune. He didn’t want to see it destroyed and rightly so. What was I trying to communicate? I had no idea. </p> \n<p>I guess I was trying come to terms with a marriage that had nearly ended. We had been having problems. Perhaps by wrapping that skin around my skin I was searching for our union again. I was trying to connect with who we had become as a couple. When I put my myself in the front of the camera, I always ask, “What I am I trying to say?” “Is this genuine?” “How can I connect with my surroundings?” And most importantly: “What do I feel when I look at this picture?” </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Kveðja. Loðmundarfjörður,Iceland. 2018 © Agnieszka Sosnowska \n<p><strong>RW: Remembering and memory are two distinct areas your work always seems to touch on. Do you find the realm of the unseen informs to your photography? Are there other realms of creativity that you draw on to convey the experience of connecting with nature?</strong> </p> \n<p>AS: Myths surrounding women in Iceland hold truth in poetry and song. None other have gripped my curiosity more than “Móðir mín í kví, kví,” an Icelandic poem sung in East Iceland. This poem tells the tale of a woman haunted by the death of her newborn child. </p> \n<p>Throughout Iceland’s history women that bore children from circumstances that were not acceptable at the time would abandon the newborn to die in the wilderness. Perhpas they thought they would not be able to feed and care for the infant? Maybe they were shamed for the pregnancy? Maybe they were scared that their families, friends or society would dismiss them? </p> \n<p>When faced with such choices these women would leave their newborns out in the wilderness to die of exposure.“Móðir mín í kví, kví,” tells of a woman haunted by the voice of her abandoned child and driven to madness by her choice. I cannot imagine the grief that consumed such women. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Taking Root. Kleppjárnsstaðir, Iceland. 2018. © Agnieszka Sosnowska\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/agnieszka-sosnowska-myth-of-a-woman#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>RW: How does this history and context feed into your own work?</strong> </p> \n<p>AS: In my eyes the female spirit in Iceland encompasses strength and community. This strength has served as an inspiration in my life as an immigrant in this new land I now call my home. As a woman I am unable to bear children. This painful fact had affected my sensibility. In a way I connect with these Icelandic women and their sacrifices. </p> \n<p>To have the ability of motherhood taken away from you by means out of your control can be consuming. This is why I started making pictures for <em>Myth of a Woman</em>. These self portraits are my myths. They are love, hope, desperation, and awe. They are my truth. Other ways I create art and connect with nature is through gardening. I take great pleasure in growing, planting and weeding. </p> \n<p>My flowers and vegetables are a huge sense of pride.Often even more than picture making. Last summer we laid the foundation to a greenhouse we are building ourselves. Our goal is to finish it by the end of this summer. I cannot wait to stand inside it and know that we did it ourselves! </p> \n<p><em>Editor’s note: We first discovered the magic of Sosnowska’s work when she participated in the LensCulture Visual Storytelling Awards in 2015. Since then, she has kept our attention with a stream of new work, a few of which have garnered even more awards. This project, </em>Myth of a Woman<em>, earned special recognition as a special Juror’s Pick in the </em><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/2019-black-and-white-photography-award-winners\">LensCulture Black &amp; White Awards 2019</a><em>. You can see more of her work here in </em><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/agnieszka-sosnowska-in-my-backyard-iceland\">LensCulture</a><em>, and also later this year at </em><a href=\"https://photolondon.org/\">Photo London</a><em> from May 14 to 17, 2020 where it will be shown by Vision Neil Folberg Gallery, alongside the work of Beth Moon and Jennifer Schlesinger. </em> </p>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/frances-f-denny-let-virtue-be-your-guide\">Let Virtue Be Your Guide</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/joana-choumali-haabre-the-last-generation\">Hââbré, The Last Generation</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/patti-smith-land-250-polaroid-photographs\">Land 250 Polaroid Photographs</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/luca-meola-the-sands-of-dakar\">The Sands of Dakar</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/kishor-sharma-living-in-the-mist-the-last-nomads-of-nepal\">Living in the Mist: The Last Nomads of Nepal</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/lensculture-design-call-for-entries-lensculture-art-photography-awards-2018-3\">Call for Entries! LensCulture Art Photography Awards 2018</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3e3a07b4-29a7-4358-9dbe-adf4f90d1153.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   What the Hunter Left Behind. Borgafjörður, Iceland. 2019.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/43014d6a-609e-4e04-b3c7-1fa7787db14e.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Longbow Practice, 2018.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c51807b4-16e6-4901-93b4-67ac2374cfcc.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Midnight Swim. Landsendi, Iceland. 2011.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/fda8ca01-5957-466a-8e54-a8e689a0b4ae.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   A Passage. Jökuldalur, Iceland. 2019.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/0bcc5fff-67d5-44e4-bdb2-202bd79393b6.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Spinning the Wheels. Kleppjárnsstaðir, Iceland. 2018.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/175075d7-6eca-43e9-a291-c0d2d52a3dbb.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   My Reflection. Fremrasel, 2018.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/0ab2c2d0-e46e-4443-83a9-80cc35a42e00.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   The Delivery. Kleppjárnsstaðir, Iceland. 2018.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d0858a72-9adf-4914-b9ba-943a3fbe803e.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Holding On. Hallormsstaður, Iceland. 2019.\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Sat, 15 Aug 2020 09:55:48 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/43014d6a-609e-4e04-b3c7-1fa7787db14e.jpg","linkMd5":"390f69e8e198500aff2dfb816275aedb","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn87@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-47-080_5f1673e75cb562ed.webp","destWidth":633,"destHeight":1126,"sourceBytes":116829,"destBytes":91020,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/43014d6a-609e-4e04-b3c7-1fa7787db14e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn87@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-47-080_5f1673e75cb562ed.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3e3a07b4-29a7-4358-9dbe-adf4f90d1153.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn32@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-11-250_2c7957b290058010.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/43014d6a-609e-4e04-b3c7-1fa7787db14e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx14/cdn91@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-07-041_627be11ceba369d5.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c51807b4-16e6-4901-93b4-67ac2374cfcc.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn8@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-59-111_248c53f0129b8fa6.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/fda8ca01-5957-466a-8e54-a8e689a0b4ae.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn64@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-03-498_ebbfdd2c43326c7e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/0bcc5fff-67d5-44e4-bdb2-202bd79393b6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn16@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-08-794_a3d901ecd96ed680.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/175075d7-6eca-43e9-a291-c0d2d52a3dbb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn84@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-54-944_3315839827d8b1ad.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/0ab2c2d0-e46e-4443-83a9-80cc35a42e00.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn67@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-59-946_12227b423ec23654.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d0858a72-9adf-4914-b9ba-943a3fbe803e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn64@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-11-655_7a94a9a8980a9b1e.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066810},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Traveling Light","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/deborah-bay-traveling-light","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Traveling Light</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Deborah Bay</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/809787a1-31b0-4c68-8430-dbe9ccd2b829.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Transforming simple objects into vibrant and shimmering abstractions, Deborah Bay’s inspiring studies on light and color are a reminder of the magic of photography and what we can do with it.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>In 1665, a bubonic plague outbreak in England closed Cambridge University, forcing twenty-three-year-old Isaac Newton to return home. While waiting out the plague back at Woolsthorpe Manor, Newton pondered the nature of color and improvised experiments to test his theories. In one, he hung a prism in his bedroom until a sunbeam struck it at just the right angle, shattering light into a rainbow across his wall. These experiments eventually lead his treatise: <em>Opticks: or, A Treatise of the Reflexions, Refractions, Inflexions, and Colours of Light,</em> the earliest basis for our contemporary understanding of color. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Angles of Pi. Constructed photograph using lenses and prisms to explore the behavior of light and color. © Deborah Bay\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/deborah-bay-traveling-light#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Houston photographer and science enthusiast Deborah Bay plays with optics and light in tabletop setups reminiscent of Newton’s early experiments. For her series <em>Traveling Light</em>, she collected prisms and lenses to create abstract compositions comprising immaterial lines and shapes of color. “I’m not a scientist, but I’m intrigued by physical phenomena,” Bay explains. “It’s interesting to see the way that light interacts with these optical objects; a color will appear on one part of a lens, but light angling onto a different side will bring in other hues.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Angular Velocity. Constructed photograph using lenses and prisms to explore the behavior of light and color. © Deborah Bay\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/deborah-bay-traveling-light#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Bay’s delightful process is akin to an improvised game. “My approach is largely intuitive and not unlike that of a child playing,” she explains. “Sometimes, I go to the studio with an idea, and other times, I go with no particular plan. I create similar or complementary groupings of transparent or translucent objects. Every time I change my lighting, I get a new image.” This approach is reminiscent of Dada and Surrealist darkroom experiments, black and white photographic abstractions made from a love of improvisation and curiosity as well as unselfconscious explorations of the phenomenal world. </p> \n<p>A century after Dada’s and Surrealism’s first experimental inquiries, using chance procedures as an artistic investigation strategy remains a crucial element of many photographers’ practices. By working with small, often imperfect optical objects, Bay deliberately opens up her process to chance, allowing her to discover subtle phenomena she might never have seen otherwise. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Probability Theory. Constructed photograph using lenses and prisms to explore the behavior of light and color. © Deborah Bay\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/deborah-bay-traveling-light#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>“Often, when we look, we miss seeing so much. Because my elements are only 1 or 2 inches in diameter, I am never sure exactly how a photograph is going to look until after I have shot it. In my 40-inch prints, I can see subtle details that I never would never observe with my naked eye or take the time to appreciate, like the way light moves around the thin rim of a lens,” says Bay. <em>Traveling Light</em> suggests that we could always see more than our senses will allow. By unlocking these tiny rainbows for the viewers, Bay transforms her experimental impulses into an expansion of our own vision. </p>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/alain-laboile-reflexion-autour-du-bassin\">Réflexion autour du bassin</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/takashi-homma-the-narcissistic-city\">The Narcissistic City</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/julien-magre-on-the-road-dream-narrative\">On the Road, Dream Narrative</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/jill-booker-shards\">Shards</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/alex-webb-la-calle-on-the-streets-of-mexico\">La Calle: On the Streets of Mexico</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/barbara-peacock-american-bedroom\">American Bedroom</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/694b3f70-cd06-4cfb-995d-1908db8bb382.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Mondrian Dialectic\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/809787a1-31b0-4c68-8430-dbe9ccd2b829.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Triangle Theorem\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f7e13e1c-4ae2-42b6-8565-f11f84c4ea34.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   The Geometry Lesson\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c1a618c2-d56d-4645-a833-41422d690a37.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Reflections on the Square\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/97bd3e3b-bee2-4258-871f-71b6c69036c9.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Circular Domains\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a78aaeed-8761-4209-8177-6c4b59abc5d7.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Tangential Point\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/16b5036f-fa9f-4567-ba12-f835d1ce7b03.jpg\" />\n  <figcaption>\n   Circular Thinking II\n  </figcaption>\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Fri, 24 Apr 2020 17:16:39 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/809787a1-31b0-4c68-8430-dbe9ccd2b829.jpg","linkMd5":"5982fcd6f43006c5f3733dd6178bde18","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn60@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-48-187_0f584151b4ddbf7e.webp","destWidth":675,"destHeight":1200,"sourceBytes":62587,"destBytes":22644,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/809787a1-31b0-4c68-8430-dbe9ccd2b829.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx19/cdn60@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-48-187_0f584151b4ddbf7e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/694b3f70-cd06-4cfb-995d-1908db8bb382.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn71@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-09-836_ae5aac3837cd9ff2.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/809787a1-31b0-4c68-8430-dbe9ccd2b829.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn56@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-10-411_4c9026392652e5aa.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/f7e13e1c-4ae2-42b6-8565-f11f84c4ea34.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn20@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-51-929_8aa39a8df7d5e216.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c1a618c2-d56d-4645-a833-41422d690a37.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn48@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-14-823_7b2a8c5533e785e2.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/97bd3e3b-bee2-4258-871f-71b6c69036c9.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn84@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-08-791_6c2f048e20ff014c.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a78aaeed-8761-4209-8177-6c4b59abc5d7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx21/cdn59@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-55-513_046686f5fbd68ae1.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/16b5036f-fa9f-4567-ba12-f835d1ce7b03.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn31@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-52-981_b61d95e35ee9aa42.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066819},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Photos that Should Not be Possible","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/toby-binder-photos-that-should-not-be-possible","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Photos that Should Not be Possible</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Toby Binder</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/c5833a1a-d712-407e-818f-7fdbe6a9c1a5.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  In “Wee Muckers – Youth of Belfast”, Toby Binder captures the ebbs and flows of teenage life across the divided communities of Northern Ireland.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>For thirty blood-soaked years, one overriding narrative framed the photography of Northern Ireland: the Troubles. It was a felicitous term that allowed people on both sides of the armed conflict—and those who thought there was a position somewhere in the middle—to refer to the same violent hostilities without revealing their particular perspective. </p> \n<p>The grim reality behind the euphemism was a war between the British state, sometimes in collusion with loyalist paramilitaries, and an Irish Republican Army (IRA) demanding a united Ireland. Of the thousands that died, more were civilians than combatants. Massive social inequalities underlay the conflict that subsumed them and the bad news is that these disparities remain and continue to blight the lives of marginalised communities. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Wee Muckers – Youth of Belfast. Belfast, Shankill. Boy playing football in front of a Union Jack painted on the wall. © Toby Binder\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/toby-binder-photos-that-should-not-be-possible#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><span></span>Toby Binder’s photographs show the truth of words by journalist Lyra McKee (tragically killed at the scene of rioting last year) about people like herself who were “destined to never witness the horrors of war but to reap the spoils of peace.” But, she added: “The spoils just never seemed to reach us.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Wee Muckers – Youth of Belfast. Belfast, Carrick Hill. Scooter on barbed wire. © Toby Binder\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/toby-binder-photos-that-should-not-be-possible#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Binder, a German photographer, started work on the everyday life of young people in British working-class towns in 2004, initially in Scotland and then in England and also Northern Ireland. His first trip to Belfast was in 2006 but it was the Brexit referendum that galvanized an interest in returning. “Here the decision for or against Brexit ran tight along the sectarian lines. And there were different majorities of over 80% in a very confined space,” he explains. </p> \n<p>“The majority in Catholic-nationalist neighbourhoods voted to stay in the EU, most people in Protestant-loyalist neighbourhoods voted for Brexit. This referendum result made very clear how different the vision of Northern Ireland’s future is in these two camps and how deep the resentment of the past lies<em>.</em>” The result of his fresh interest are the images in <em>Wee Muckers - Youth of Belfast, </em> taken from different neighbourhoods of Belfast. Some of these communities are anxious to preserve an identity that is Protestant and part of the UK; others are nationalist and Catholic, looking to a united Ireland. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Wee Muckers – Youth of Belfast. Belfast, Shankill. Girls’ group at Woodvale Park. © Toby Binder\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/toby-binder-photos-that-should-not-be-possible#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Binder’s pictures—‘wee’ is an informal adjective for small or little while ‘muckers’ is a colloquial word for friends and companions—are in the recognizable tradition of street photography as a ‘theatre of life’. They are though quite different from, say, <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/helen-levitt-helen-levitt-new-york-streets-1938-to-1990s\">Helen Levitt’s photographs of children</a> on the sidewalks of poor neighbourhoods in New York. Levitt’s youngsters own the streets and their spontaneous playfulness kindle amusement but those in Binder’s pictures occupy contested territory and artless joy looks to be in short supply. There is one photograph of a girl running along the ground with unrehearsed glee but the heavy presence of police vehicles isolates her vitality. In a harsh, urban landscape, she becomes almost quixotic. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Wee Muckers – Youth of Belfast. Belfast, Carrick Hill. Rachel running past police vehicles on Stanhope Street. © Toby Binder\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/toby-binder-photos-that-should-not-be-possible#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The names of some of Belfast’s neighbourhoods act as shorthand for sectarian loyalties that divide the city. The girl running past the police vehicle is in Carrick Hill, a nationalist area, and in another photo, taken from behind a police line in the same area, a young boy on a bicycle stands as if questioning the restriction on his right to roam. In Belfast, confrontations with uniformed authority begin in childhood. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Wee Muckers – Youth of Belfast. Belfast, Carrick Hill. Brendan behind a police line on Trinity Street. © Toby Binder \n<p>In staunchly loyalist areas, like Sandy Row and Shankill (a murderous loyalist gang was known as the Shankill Butchers), pro-British insignia is photographed on walls. Although the pictures are divided by neighbourhood, what comes across strongly is what these muckers share: a social ecology defined not by religion or politics but class. The working-class youth, as Binder puts it “have much more in common than either side would like to admit.” Aware also that “young people actually always have a very good sense of whether one is honest with them”, he built up rapport by being open, sharing photographs from previous visits and getting to know some of them. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Wee Muckers – Youth of Belfast. Belfast, Shankill. Megan and Joshua. © Toby Binder\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/toby-binder-photos-that-should-not-be-possible#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>It is an indictment of those governing Northern Ireland to observe that so many of Toby Binder’s photographs could have been taken thirty or more years ago. And sad, as well, to feel that it is still possible to take such pictures. ‘Muck’ can also be used as a verb to mean messing around, without due consideration. The youngsters of Belfast, affected, as Binder says, “by unemployment, drug and gang crime and social disadvantage” have themselves been badly mucked around with. </p> \n<hr> \n <p><em>Editor’s note: Toby Binder was a top winner with this series in the <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/2020-lensculture-street-photography-award-winners\">LensCulture Street Photography Awards 2020</a>. See all of the award-winning photography <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/2020-lensculture-street-photography-award-winners\">here</a>.</em> </p> \n <hr> \n  <div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n  </div>Wee Muckers – Youth of Belfast. Belfast, Shankill. Emily. © Toby Binder\n  <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/toby-binder-photos-that-should-not-be-possible#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n  <p><br><br> </br></br></p>\n  <p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n  <ul>\n   <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/sasha-maslov-ukrainian-railroad-ladies\">Ukrainian Railroad Ladies</a></li>\n   <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/ditte-haarlov-johnsen-maputo-diary\">Maputo Diary</a></li>\n   <li><a 1960–75</a></li>\n  </ul>\n  <section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c5833a1a-d712-407e-818f-7fdbe6a9c1a5.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n Belfast\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4c2b1dd9-0cc2-46a5-872a-df4f2b2d3fa8.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Wee Muckers –&nbsp;Youth of Belfast\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7205980a-c792-471e-a04d-81e61a8c345a.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Wee Muckers –&nbsp;Youth of Belfast\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/25d14e32-e4e6-4274-8104-ccd9f579072a.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Wee Muckers –&nbsp;Youth of Belfast\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/94ebfe32-fb0b-4cbb-8fc2-2eb35a740d04.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Wee Muckers –&nbsp;Youth of Belfast\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/91677bf5-3ced-482d-8dd7-426981ac2c25.jpg\" />\n    <figcaption>\n     Wee Muckers –&nbsp;Youth of Belfast\n    </figcaption>\n   </figure>\n   <figure>\n    <img /photos.lensculture.com/large/46131f53-20d8-49bf-bfda-c1bd0baf7848.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn56@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-09-357_40857f0dac7ef202.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/13707064-3303-44a4-8638-de734dd7c112.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn92@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-15-106_96be8eb3690bfa51.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/051226bd-5877-4ac4-8f1d-a64ed7928c19.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn36@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-53-785_0ed0ad2b5e2baa4a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3a4e4731-00db-48f8-8afb-9085d4225235.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn7@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-52-287_ea79c216e773f918.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c46aa970-7c17-4e33-85ef-60c904c6920b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn32@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-07-711_56278407d551a72c.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/773ff3cb-25ad-48f6-8e1f-a0bb85fba41f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn88@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-04-995_da162ee04d421171.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/0095a357-98ea-4a0f-87ca-789a7837185a.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn55@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-16-235_1f33cb9e9f1cab1d.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066811},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"COVID-19 Resources for Photographers","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/lensculture-editors-covid-19-resources-for-photographers","description":"\n        <hgroup><h1>COVID-19 Resources for Photographers</h1><h3 class=\"fl-author\">LensCulture Editors</h3></hgroup><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/1b1e3c25-849b-4f50-a036-84e5089c8380.jpg\"/><figcaption>We’ve compiled a big list of resources available to the global photography community as we navigate uncertain times:  Find financial support, enroll in an online course, discover some new inspiration, or join a virtual community. Updated weekly.</figcaption></figure><p><i>The world as we knew it has paused for the moment, perhaps changed forever. As for many in the arts, the global pandemic is posing huge and unfolding challenges for the entire photography community, from individual practitioners, to collectives and agencies, as well as global institutions and organizations. </i><i>The COVID-19 situation impacts us all in different ways and there are certainly more uncertain times ahead, but one thing we know for sure: the global photography community is rallying to provide support.</i><br>\n</p>\n<p><i></i><i>We’ve curated a list of initiatives, ideas and resources currently available for image-makers to help navigate the coming months, whether that be financial support, professional development opportunities, or inspiring things to read and watch to fill extended time at home. </i><i>Pulling this list together was a heart-warming experience. Witnessing the scope of this massive collective response from organizations big and small has felt something like a virtual hug, one we wanted to extend to photographers around the world.</i>\n</p>\n<p><i></i><i>While not exhaustive, our hope is that you’ll find something in this list that helps, no matter your location or your situation. We’ll be updating weekly, if you have suggestions for new additions, please let us know by commenting on our <a href=\"https://www.facebook.com/lensculture\">Facebook</a> or <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/lensculture/\">Instagram</a> page.</i>\n</p>\n<p><i></i><i>— LensCulture Editors </i>\n</p>\n<p><i></i><i><strong>Last updated: 1 June 2020.</strong> Cover photo © Arash Ghannadzadeh, Paris</i>\n</p>\n<hr>\n<p><strong>NEW LISTINGS — Updated 1 June 2020:</strong>\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.noua.no/en/events\">Atelier NŌUA Online Events</a> <br></strong>Atelier NŌUA  is a Norwegian studio and arena for photo as contemporary art. ‘Once upon a time’ by contemporary photographers by Mathieu Asselin and Sergio Valenzuela Escobedo is an online education program that will explore issues within documentary photography today via lectures, seminars, courses and talks from 25 May — 14 August 14.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://covid19visualproject.org/en/open-call\">Covid-19 Visual Project</a><br></strong>The Covid-19 Visual Project is ongoing permanent archive on the coronavirus pandemic: effects, struggles, and glimmers of hope. Conceived and produced by Cortona On The Move in partnership with Intesa Sanpaolo.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLlAOLJLSY5DNsaFyxWTjXd3ZiAyd70ZLS&#38;feature=share\">Yale Photo Pop Up Lecture Series</a><br></strong>In a creative endeavor intended to make the most of one aspect of remote learning — the fact that many of us, well-known artists and creators included, are isolating at home — the graduate photography department at the Yale School of Art has initiated the “Yale Photo Pop Up Lecture Series. Hosted by Gregory Crewdson, guests include Nan Goldin, Sophie Calle, Tilda Swinton, Willam Eggleston, LaToya Ruby Frazier, and Cate Blanchett.\n</p>\n<hr>\n<p><strong>FINANCIAL RESOURCES, GRANTS &#38; FUNDING</strong>\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.artistrelief.org/\">Artist Relief</a><strong> (US only)<br></strong></strong>To support artists during the COVID-19 crisis, a coalition of national arts grant makers have come together to create an emergency initiative to offer financial and informational resources to artists across the United States. Funding cycles now open.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://jameelartscentre.org/whats-on/art-jameel-research-and-practice-platform/\">Art Jameel</a> (Middle East &#38; North Africa)<br></strong>Art Jameel has introduced a research and practice platform for independent practitioners intended primarily for those who work on a per-project basis and whose practices have been affected by program cancellations and project changes, locally or globally. Open to all practitioners based in the Middle East and North Africa region. Ongoing cycles of funding available.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://iwmf.submittable.com/submit/41e7f7ce-db40-4ff6-873f-e24450e27497/journalism-relief-fund-english\">International Women’s Media Foundation</a><br></strong>The IWMF’s <strong>Journalism Relief Fund</strong> is open to women-identifying journalists in dire straits. Journalists who have faced significant financial hardship, lost work, have been recently laid off or who urgently need assistance to avoid severe, irreversible outcomes are encouraged to apply.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.nationalgeographic.org/funding-opportunities/grants/what-we-fund/covid-19-emergency-fund/\">National Geographic Society</a> <br></strong>The National Geographic Society has launched <strong>The COVID-19 Emergency Fund for Journalists</strong>, assisting storytellers around the world who wish to cover the effects of COVID-19 within their own communities. The fund places special emphasis on delivering evidence-based information getting to those who need it, and local distribution models.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://pulitzercenter.org/coronavirus-news-collaboration-challenge\">The Pulitzer Center</a><br></strong>The Pulitzer Center on Crisis Reporting, a non-profit organization that supports independent global journalism, is seeking proposals that develop innovative approaches to reporting on the novel coronavirus crisis using collaboration among journalists and newsrooms across state lines or national borders. This opportunity is open to all newsrooms and independent journalists in the United States and abroad.\n</p>\n<hr>\n<p><strong>INSPIRATION, EDUCATION, COMMUNITY &#38; CREATIVE OPPORTUNITIES</strong>\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://angkor-photo.com/covid-19-resources-for-photographers/\">Angkor Photo Festival Resources for Photographers</a><br></strong>Southeast Asia’s longest-running international photography event, Angkor Photo Festival believes in supporting the vibrant and dynamic photographic community that has arisen in Asia. The team is constantly updating their <a href=\"https://angkor-photo.com/covid-19-resources-for-photographers/\">blog with COVID-19 related resources</a>.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"http://arabimagefoundation.com/index\">Arab Image Foundation</a><br></strong>Browse a wonderful digital collection of more than 25,000 images related to the Middle East, North Africa and the Arab diaspora via the Arab Image Foundation’s new digital platform.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/explore/tags/artistsupportpledge/\">Artist Support Pledge</a><br></strong>An initiative set up by the Sussex-based artist Matthew Burrows, which is offering a self-sustaining lifeline to an ever-expanding number of fellow artists across the world. The concept is simple: artists are invited to post pictures of their works for sale for £200 or less on Instagram using the hashtag <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/explore/tags/artistsupportpledge/\">#ArtistSupportPledge</a>. Every time an artist makes £1,000 in sales they then pledge to plough back £200 on purchasing the work of another artist using the hashtag.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://bensmithphoto.com/asmallvoice\">A Small Voice Podcast</a><br></strong>Hosted by Ben Smith, <a href=\"https://bensmithphoto.com/asmallvoice\">A Small Voice</a> is a free fortnightly podcast featuring in-depth, long-form interviews with a diverse range of world-class photographers. Enjoy conversations with Alys Tomlinson, Lua Ribeira, Carolyn Drake, Sohrab Hura, Anders Petersen, Mark Steinmetz, Todd Hido and many, many more (over 100 episodes!)\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://acca.melbourne/program/acca-open/\">Australian Centre for Contemporary Art (ACCA)</a> (Australia only)<br></strong><a href=\"https://acca.melbourne/program/acca-open/\">ACCA Open - Digital Commissions</a> is new open-call initiative, inviting Australian artists of all backgrounds, career levels and practices to share ambitious proposals for the production of new work to be presented digitally in August 2020. Three artists or collaborations will each be awarded an artist and production fee and offered the support of ACCA’s curatorial team to help realize their project.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/beyond_the_negative/\">Beyond the Negative</a><br></strong>Beyond the Negative has launched on instagram (<a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/beyond_the_negative/\">@beyond_the_negative</a>) as a platform designed to showcase the work of 50 artist/photographers who push the boundaries of the photographic medium. Some of those boundaries are technical; some are narrative. Each are image makers who reveal our world to us in new and inspiring ways.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.youtube.com/playlist?list=PLyvuS7237e79jFsQzyykhPoYKLhKZf_fS\">Create From Home</a><br></strong>Being stuck at home doesn’t mean you can’t create something remarkable! <i><strong>Create From Home</strong></i> is a video playlist from New York megastore B&#38;H Photo and covers everything from home photography, audio editing, and more.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.everydayprojects.org/covid19-guide-for-visual-journalists\">The Everyday Projects</a><br></strong>Looking for multiple perspectives on what’s happening in the world today? The Everyday Projects uses photography to challenge stereotypes that distort our understanding of the world. Check out <a href=\"https://www.everydayprojects.org/\">the community’s region-based Instagram accounts</a> to discover a new generations of storytellers all over the world. The team has also put together <a href=\"https://www.everydayprojects.org/covid19-guide-for-visual-journalists\">a comprehensive guide for visual journalists</a> during the pandemic.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.forhanna.com/project/visual-stories/\">Forhanna</a><br></strong>Forhanna is a not-for-profit production house from The Netherlands. Photography educator Marc Prüst is running a series of free 30 minute webinars about different aspects of visual storytelling - participate live or watch the recordings later.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://formatfestival.com/whats-on/massisolation/\">FORMAT International Photography Festival</a> <br></strong>FORMAT International Photography Festival (UK), in partnership with Ballarat International Foto Biennale (AUS) and Gallery of Photography Ireland, is creating a visual record of the COVID-19 crisis on Instagram called the <a href=\"https://formatfestival.com/whats-on/massisolation/\">Mass Isolation Project</a>. Photographers are invited to participate by tagging their images or sending submissions to the various regional accounts.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/homelife_stilllife/\">Home Life Still Life</a> <br></strong>A creative initiative encouraging photographers to create a still life image using materials found at home. Check out the work of other photographers and see their set-up behind-the-scenes, or submit an image of your own.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.icp.org/news/engage-with-icp-from-anywhere\">International Centre of Photography (ICP), New York</a><br></strong>ICP has <a href=\"https://www.icp.org/news/engage-with-icp-from-anywhere\">several initiatives running for photographers around the world</a>. Visit virtual galleries from home, take an online class, watch and attend curated public programs, and share your images and stories with <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/icp/\">ICP on Instagram</a> by using #ICPConcerned.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/isolationartschool/\">Isolation Art School</a><br></strong>Isolation Art School, an ‘art school for all, by all’, is freely available on Instagram. Free home-based projects for adults, children, experts or amateurs during the pandemic that have so far ranged from tips for making kitchen table sculptures to to fashioning a wearable elephantine sculpted head from twisted newspaper.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"http://lenscratch.com/\">Lenscratch</a> <br></strong>The COVID-19 pandemic is forcing the visual arts communities to find alternatives to traditional exhibition spaces. Through a new initiative called <strong><i>The Thesis Project</i>,</strong> Lenscratch will exhibit graduating MFA candidates in a series of new features during the first week of May.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/\">LensCulture</a><br></strong>If you’re reading this list, you’re already here — so take some time to look around! LensCulture is an amazing resource to discover a wide range of contemporary photography from cultures around the world. The free online archives feature more than 15 years of articles, interviews, book reviews, and lots of amazing photography.  <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/photography-free-guides\">Download our six free PDF guides</a> for pages of advice, inspiration and recommendations on specific topics, or check out <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/explore/award-winners/portrait-awards-2020\">our talented award-winners</a> for hours of photography inspiration.\n</p>\n<p><a href=\"http://www.magichourpodcast.org/\">Magic Hour Podcast</a><br><i>Magic Hour</i> is a podcast interview series with photographers and people involved in the medium. It was founded in 2016 and is hosted and produced by Jordan Weitzman. Conversations with photographers, publishers and editors such as Jason Fulford, Justine Kurland, Elle Perez, Jack Woody, Siobhan Bohnacker and many more.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.magnumphotos.com/theme/magnum-photos-on-covid-19/\">Magnum Photos</a><br></strong>Magnum Photos is publishing fascinating <a href=\"https://www.magnumphotos.com/theme/magnum-photos-on-covid-19/\">video conversations from quarantine</a> between members such as Alex Majoli and Mikhael Subotzky, and Newsha Tavakolian and Rafal Milach. The agency is also sharing <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/magnumphotos/\">new work from its members</a> on Instagram under the title<a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/magnumphotos/?hl=en\"> <i>Diary of a Pandemic</i></a>.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://play.acast.com/s/themessytruth\">The Messy Truth Podcast</a><br></strong>Photo Director Gem Fletcher explores contemporary photography. Photographers, commissioners and editors share their work and process, discussing everything from the impact of social media, representation, gaze, awards, mental health and more. These candid conversations unpack the future of visual culture and what it means to be a photographer today.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.moma.org/calendar/exhibitions/5079\">Museum of Modern Art, New York</a><br></strong>With the physical space temporarily closed, MoMa will soon be opening a series of virtual exhibitions, including <a href=\"https://www.moma.org/calendar/exhibitions/5079\">Dorothea Lange: Words and Pictures</a> on 30 April. The museum also offers a free online course called <a href=\"https://www.coursera.org/learn/photography\"><i>Seeing Through Photographs</i></a><i> </i>which aims to address the gap between seeing and truly understanding photographs<i>.</i>\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://phmuseum.com\">PH Museum</a><br></strong>Based in Italy, PH Museum has launched a number of initiatives in respond to the COVID-19 pandemic, including a selection of <a href=\"https://phmuseum.com/photobooks\">new photobook titles</a> for viewing and purchase, and <a href=\"https://phmuseum.com/news/opportunities-for-visual-journalists-affected-by-the-covid-19-crisis\">a list of grants and funding opportunities for visual journalists</a>. For inspiration, be sure to check out the museum’s<a href=\"https://phmuseum.com/exhibition/falling\"> stunning online exhibitions</a>. For professional development, <a href=\"https://phmuseum.com/education\">online mentoring with industry experts is available</a>.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://prcboston.org/prc-nights-online/\">Photographic Resource Centre, Boston</a><br></strong>PRC Nights, a long-standing tradition, continues online via Zoom during the COVID-19 pandemic. One a month, a guest photographer presents their work along with three PRC members for <a href=\"https://prcboston.org/prc-nights-online/\">a lively evening of conversation on rotating themes</a>.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://thephotographersgallery.org.uk\">The Photographers’s Gallery (TPG), London</a><br></strong>TPG offers various online initiatives for photographers looking for creative inspiration from home. <a href=\"https://thephotographersgallery.org.uk/content/screen-walks\">Screen Walks</a> is a new series of live-streamed artist or researcher-led explorations of online spaces. <a href=\"https://thephotographersgallery.org.uk/viewpoints\">Viewpoints</a> offers a curated and eclectic set of perspectives designed to provoke new thinking around photography’s role in contemporary culture. <a href=\"https://unthinking.photography/\">Unthinking Photography</a> is an online resource that explores photography’s increasingly automated, networked life.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"http://covid19.publicsource.xyz/\">Public Source</a><br></strong><a href=\"http://covid19.publicsource.xyz/\">COVID-19 Archive </a>is an ongoing project from Public Source featuring documentary photographers, journalist and writers from across the globe who are going to great lengths to record these events as they unfold. Submissions welcome.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://shop.selfpublishbehappy.com/collections/education\">Self Publish Be Happy</a><br></strong><i><a href=\"https://shop.selfpublishbehappy.com/collections/education\">How To Online Masterclasses</a></i> give you access to some of the world’s leading photography-industry professionals who will draw on their own work and long experience to explore theoretical and practical issues related to image, book and exhibition making. Each Masterclass will be an opportunity to go behind the scenes and learn how these experts work – and how to do it yourself.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://socialdocumentary.net/cms/pandemic-in-focus\">Social Documentary Network (SDN)</a><br></strong>SDN is seeking visual stories by photographers worldwide to present their work on both the COVID-19 crisis and the solutions on the SDN platform.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://stayathome.photography/\">Stay At Home</a><br></strong>This new initiative showcases <a href=\"https://stayathome.photography/\">engaging (wordless) photographic conversations between self-isolated photographers</a> all over the world. Photographers are welcome to apply to participate.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/workshowgrow/\">Work Show Grow</a><br></strong>Lead by UK-based photographer and educator Natasha Caruana, Work Show Grow is running <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/workshowgrow/\">a month-long program of free virtual events on Instagram</a> for photographers and visual artists called <i>The Interval.</i> Enjoy artist talks and live Q&#38;As, positive mental health activities, professional development and creative exercises, and more.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.womenphotograph.com/\">Women Photograph</a><br></strong>Women Photograph is a non-profit initiative that aims to elevate the voices of female visual journalists. Be sure to check out <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/wpthejournal/\">The Journal, </a>a collaborative project of 350+ Women Photograph members sharing stories, documenting private spaces and daily lives during the current pandemic.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://www.worldpressphoto.org/news/2020/supporting-visual-journalism-covid-19/39813\">World Press Photo</a><br></strong>The <a href=\"https://www.worldpressphoto.org/collection/photo-contest\">2020 World Press Photo Awards</a> have been announced, spend some time looking through the galleries of winners and finalists across the photography and digital storytelling categories. World Press has also published <a href=\"https://www.worldpressphoto.org/news/2020/supporting-visual-journalism-covid-19/39813\">a list of resources supporting visual journalism</a>.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"http://viiphoto.com/\">VII Interactive</a><br></strong>In this <a href=\"http://viiphoto.com/\">new education initiative by photo agency VII</a>, photographers can engage directly, online with a ‘live’ instructors and participate in a lectures, mentoring, medium and long-term masterclasses.<i> </i>Free and paid options available.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://access.bjpsubs.com/1854-presents-upcoming-talks/\">1854 &#38; British Journal of Photography</a><br></strong>1854 Presents is a new initiative that brings world-class photographers from the pages of the BJP magazine to the community via online artist talks, how-tos, Q&#38;As, and panel discussions that explore all the topics you want to hear about. <a href=\"https://access.bjpsubs.com/1854-presents-upcoming-talks/\">Upcoming talks</a> include Martin Parr and Simon Roberts. Catch up on past talks by <a href=\"https://access.bjpsubs.com/1854-presents-laura-pannack\">Laura Pannack</a> and <a href=\"https://access.bjpsubs.com/1854-presents-jack-latham\">Jack Latham</a>.\n</p>\n<p><strong><a href=\"https://collectordaily.com/2020-guggenheim-fellows-in-photography/\">2020 Guggenheim Fellows in Photography</a><br></strong>Collector Daily has put together <a href=\"https://collectordaily.com/2020-guggenheim-fellows-in-photography/\">a list of this year’s winners with links to their individual websites</a>. Consider this a wonderful portal to discover some of the best in contemporary photography today.\n</p><p>Enjoy more great photography:</p><ul><li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/sebastien-tixier-allanngorpoq-being-transformed\">Allanngorpoq: Being Transformed</a></li><li><a
