href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/mark-seliger-rolling-stone-to-christopher-street-30-years-of-portraits\">Rolling Stone to Christopher Street: 30 Years of Portraits</a></li></ul><section class=\"fl-slideshow\"><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d18c7584-6410-4b1e-8ba8-aa5c1ba10e52.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e39d25fc-15c0-4e82-b160-2225141c4fab.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1b1e3c25-849b-4f50-a036-84e5089c8380.jpg\"/></figure><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/705d9b00-762b-4e6b-b31b-b920337410b5.jpg\"/></figure></section>\n      ","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Mon, 01 Jun 2020 15:56:06 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/1b1e3c25-849b-4f50-a036-84e5089c8380.jpg","linkMd5":"5e144905d6fbb250f738f665e75d4368","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn75@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-47-779_7613a250fec6c227.webp","destWidth":749,"destHeight":1333,"sourceBytes":243356,"destBytes":185446,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/1b1e3c25-849b-4f50-a036-84e5089c8380.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx11/cdn75@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-47-779_7613a250fec6c227.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d18c7584-6410-4b1e-8ba8-aa5c1ba10e52.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn100@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-08-137_0f966399b0777fd7.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e39d25fc-15c0-4e82-b160-2225141c4fab.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn99@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-14-280_04380bea3f67485a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/1b1e3c25-849b-4f50-a036-84e5089c8380.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn40@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-17-166_1a95c61cda74fbfd.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/705d9b00-762b-4e6b-b31b-b920337410b5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx22/cdn4@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-56-184_f034e04f989b12f1.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066821},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Big Brother","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/louis-quail-big-brother","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Big Brother</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Louis Quail</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/48e4ae2f-2001-434e-9601-211ca9ccb1c2.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Over the course of six years, Louis Quail documented the ebbs and flows of his brother’s life to build a tender and honest portrayal of what it’s like to live with schizophrenia.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Justin Quail raises his binoculars to his eyes, scanning the trees in search of a sparrow he’s heard trilling in the branches. On the park bench beside him, his girlfriend Jackie smokes a cigarette, while his brother Louis circles them with his camera, making portraits of the two lovebirds out in the park on a clouded London afternoon. Once the sparrow is sighted, Justin adds its name to a notebook filled with bird lists, notes on bird songs, drawings of birds and the odd poem. Justin, now in his 50s, has been obsessively birdwatching since the age of nine. “Why do you think you’ve kept it up?” his brother asks. “…the birds that you see reflect the earth back inside of yourself, they reflect the earth back in you,” Justin replies. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled © Louis Quail\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/louis-quail-big-brother#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Justin and Jackie have both been diagnosed with schizophrenia. The photographs in<em> Big Brother</em> were made by Justin’s younger sibling Louis, who began documenting Justin’s life shortly after their mother—who was also diagnosed with schizophrenia—passed away. An estimated one in four people will struggle with mental health issues at some point in their lifetime, and for Louis the lack of public awareness and support for the mentally ill drove him to begin making the work. “I want Justin to be seen,” he writes, “I want to fight the ignorance and the stigma.” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Justin on his way to Kew Gardens strikes a pose, possibly in protest at the relentless gaze of my camera, although I only guess. Justin is idiosyncratic, something to be cherished and celebrated in a world of conformity. © Louis Quail\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/louis-quail-big-brother#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>In <em>Big Brother</em>, Louis Quail defies the reductive stigma surrounding Justin’s illness by creating an intimate portrait of his brother’s everyday experience. “Justin is no saint,” writes Louis, “but there is a lot more to him than his mental illness. It doesn’t define him.” In a series of chapters, each a title from one of Justin’s favorite songs, Louis uses text and image to document the different themes playing out in Justin’s life. In ‘Shine on You Crazy Diamond’, Justin meditates and paints landscapes. In ‘Holiday, It Could Be So Nice’, Justin and Jackie travel to Northern Ireland on vacation. In addition to Louis’ photographic observations, Justin’s voice is present throughout <em>Big Brother</em>: on pages and inserts of drawings, bird lists, and poetry excerpts, sitting alongside the images of him meditating, bird watching, or sharing a moment with Jackie. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Untitled © Justin Quail\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/louis-quail-big-brother#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Justin instinctively practices his hobbies, especially birdwatching, and for Louis they are the source of his resilience. “It’s hard to quantify the benefits that Justin’s hobby has in helping his illness,” writes Louis, “I see it as absolutely vital in maintaining his mental health and sense of well-being.” However, his condition brings about an oscillation between extreme highs and extreme lows—and Louis does not shy away from depictions of the debilitating depression and paranoia his brother endures. In a number of different sequences throughout the book Justin lays prone on a couch incapacitated by his anti-psychotic drugs, telling Louis, “I can’t do anything after a depo, they make me feel foggy, like wading through mud.” </p> \n<p>In a chapter titled ‘I Fought the Law and the Law Won,’ Louis takes the reader through the challenges presented to Justin and Jackie by the lack of social support. Jackie, who has given up on the increasingly overwhelmed social care workers, has a habit of turning to the police whenever a misunderstanding arises between the couple. As a result, a litany of minor offences are attached to Justin’s name such as criminal damage to a cigarette, breach of bail, common assault, assault by battery. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Jackie’s flat, East Sheen May 2012 © Louis Quail\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/louis-quail-big-brother#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The peaks and troughs of this intimate relationship point to a larger systemic failure. Louis believes that, “what we see are symptoms of a system that appears to be spiralling out of control. Resources that were once pumped into [social services] are now diverted to the Criminal Justice system.” The result is instead of the option to resolve their misunderstandings (and there are many) with the help of trained professionals, Justin and Jackie are now at the mercy of untrained police officers working in an unempathetic judicial system. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Jackie follows Justin as he searches for birds in a field near Tring, Hertfordshire. It’s a testament to the strength of the relationship that Jackie joins Justin on this trip as she is not really that interested in birds or walking in the countryside for that matter. © Louis Quail\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/louis-quail-big-brother#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>In spite of the challenges Justin and Jackie face, their resilience and love continue to bring them together. “At its heart,” writes Louis, “this is a love story.” After a lifetime of being the one supporting Justin, making this work also changed the relationship between brothers. “Justin trusted me with his story,” says Louis, “it was his gift to me; something powerful for a change.” Reflecting on Justin and Jackie’s relationship, Louis writes that, “if by accepting them we can accept ourselves, treat each health condition as is appropriate, and resist the ghettoization of the mentally ill, then we can improve our individual health as well as that of society.” </p> \n<div> \n <div class=\"article-incut -book-incut\"> \n  <div class=\"picture\"> \n   <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/books/18782-big-brother\"></a> \n  </div> \n  <div class=\"title\">\n   Big Brother\n   <br> </br>\n  </div> \n  <div class=\"author\">\n   by Louis Quail\n   <br> </br>\n  </div> \n  <div class=\"publisher\">\n   Publisher: Dewi Lewis Publishing\n   <br>ISBN: 978-1-911306-31-3<br> </br></br>\n  </div> \n </div> \n</div>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/alain-laboile-la-famille-chapter-2-color\">La Famille, Chapter 2 — Color</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/suzanne-opton-soldier\">Soldier</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/david-de-vleeschauwer-searching-for-a-human-side-in-north-korea\">Searching for a Human Side in North Korea</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/edoardo-delille-los-trumpistas-trump-s-latino-supporters\">Los Trumpistas: Trump&amp;#8217;s Latino Supporters</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/jeff-gusky-the-hidden-worlds-of-wwi\">The Hidden Worlds of WWI</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/paul-hart-poetry-of-place-rooted-in-the-english-landscape\">Poetry of Place: Rooted in the English Landscape</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/20685751-3aba-4d24-b3bd-bf58602e9516.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d6ddd2e8-b330-4f37-af8b-5a0601df6e9f.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/2013d5aa-2555-44eb-8e7a-5cda9358c3c4.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d2de0da9-62a0-4f63-b935-93f7d569acb0.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3d3425a9-5630-44c0-a197-33ba53845409.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9480b436-bcad-4862-b7ca-6eca3fa18095.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/acdfda22-44de-4868-bc50-ea58f5a4bfa7.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Thu, 04 Jun 2020 11:21:09 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/48e4ae2f-2001-434e-9601-211ca9ccb1c2.jpg","linkMd5":"8126de309e7ba60cbe82b2577d5ea6e7","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn64@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-47-582_84b6140b8768bb53.webp","destWidth":638,"destHeight":1134,"sourceBytes":133214,"destBytes":62286,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/48e4ae2f-2001-434e-9601-211ca9ccb1c2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn64@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-47-582_84b6140b8768bb53.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/20685751-3aba-4d24-b3bd-bf58602e9516.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn96@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-06-723_8be38f95ee5960ac.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/359fea41-727a-4a21-84c8-9f771c0b4f8a.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn92@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-08-063_2b0c4bdcbe8ac3b4.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d42524c3-3503-468f-b199-c1c3fe4e102a.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx7/cdn88@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-59-019_05c840662a77435a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/e102fd82-008b-4364-b22a-c26cc0e5ea55.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn60@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-12-920_71074390417897be.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/537ce1fe-9232-4e65-a62d-a79dabf8982b.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn71@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-00-717_935316cb7a83ac5c.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/48e4ae2f-2001-434e-9601-211ca9ccb1c2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn27@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-07-210_4f8dc09162d86136.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d6ddd2e8-b330-4f37-af8b-5a0601df6e9f.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn80@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-52-099_bde567b9e86d862d.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/2013d5aa-2555-44eb-8e7a-5cda9358c3c4.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx31/cdn71@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-06-552_c4431b13a0ed8ad9.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d2de0da9-62a0-4f63-b935-93f7d569acb0.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx3/cdn79@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-59-492_bfaca87b6561bfb2.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3d3425a9-5630-44c0-a197-33ba53845409.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx6/cdn92@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-54-932_718641b2c6e8f7f0.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c4203b4f-f362-4c02-9fcd-daab940e859c.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn80@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-58-124_c9eb4f3cf46cbd5c.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/8251afa0-cac7-4821-a7ca-23d7ac3579c5.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn84@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-51-948_51fddb9a75576ef7.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9480b436-bcad-4862-b7ca-6eca3fa18095.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx15/cdn71@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-56-491_152c6d84a4cad045.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/acdfda22-44de-4868-bc50-ea58f5a4bfa7.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn35@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-08-601_9201f54b593cf997.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066816},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Perfect Day","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/txema-salvans-perfect-day","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Perfect Day</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Txema Salvans</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/2508c7ee-fab4-49a6-9328-9426307198bc.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  Txema Salvans’ sun-soaked images of the Mediterranean capture the contradictions of contemporary existence, where holidaymakers lounge against the backdrop of a looming post-industrial landscape.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p><em>Spanish photographer Txema Salvans’ new book, </em>Perfect Day,<em> is a collection of bittersweet images that offer a surprisingly insightful view into the contradictions of our post-industrial civilization. Over the course of fifteen years, Salvans traversed the shores of the Mediterranean Sea photographing scenes of people relaxing, sunbathing, and carving out a small personal paradise amid the seemingly inescapable backdrop of the industrialized landscape.</em> </p> \n<p><em>The post-industrialized lifestyle lurks ever-present, both literally and figuratively, as a backdrop to the sun-washed moments of bliss captured in </em>Perfect Day<em>. All at once, the people in Salvans’ images become sympathetic punchlines, figures of stubborn insistence, and symbols of a contemporary condition where we see the pressures for individual productivity continually encroach upon our need for escape and leisure. In a simple visual gesture, Salvans offers us profound truths about the inescapability of societal expectations for the labor force. The demands of economic production, sharply alluded to in </em>Perfect Day<em> and ever-present in our own lives, simply cannot be quieted.</em> </p> \n<p><em>In our current moment, defined by a pandemic that has isolated us, the pictures perhaps ring even more relatable. We feel the longing for escape to any place outside our own dwellings and for those of us working from home, there is a continual blurring between times of work and leisure. In this interview, Salvans speaks to Gregory Eddi Jones for LensCulture about what photography means to him, making work on home turf and our faltering relationship to nature.</em> </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Perfect Day” (MACK, 2020). Courtesy of Txema Salvans and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/txema-salvans-perfect-day#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>Gregory Eddi Jones: To start, Txema, the work in your new book, <em>Perfect Day</em>, was made over the course of fifteen years. I’m curious, how did you get started with this project and what sustained your interest in this work for such a long period of time?</strong> </p> \n<p>Txema Salvans: Fifteen years? Why not? Nobody was waiting on my photos. I don’t have any scholarship or help, I have no excuses or I have them all. I can’t afford to publish a work to which I haven’t given everything, so I better do it right. That’s my commitment to myself, to you, and to photography. </p> \n<p>Photography is a state of mind that I cannot shake. It allows me to experience an intellectual pleasure, to observe the complexity of our species. It allows me to be alone, to wander and remain in a state of contemplation that at times frees me from the need to be the protagonist of my own life. And that is a great liberation. Like all artists, I try to find a personal voice, and probably because I studied science at university—I studied biology—I feel comfortable speaking about things that I can understand. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Perfect Day” (MACK, 2020). Courtesy of Txema Salvans and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/txema-salvans-perfect-day#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<p><strong>GEJ: Was focusing on your own surroundings an important factor in making this body of work?</strong> </p> \n<p>TS: I take photos about my own culture, people and landscapes. I have to have a physical connection with the landscapes and an emotional connection with the people. Being part of this reality helps me to be more critical and to go deeper into Spanish culture. So, for the last twenty years I have focused on a big project, taking photos all along the Spanish Mediterranean Coast. And more precisely, looking at how people spend their free time. As a photographer, I understood that I had to focus my point of view, otherwise the work could become too scattered. ‘Leisure’ allowed me to be a photographer every day; I didn’t need long journeys or anomalous situations to be able to work. </p> \n<p>I have become a ‘super specialist’ in a very specific subject, and for that reason, I believe that my work can transcend photography to become a document at the mercy of historians, ethnologists, architects, journalists. But the most difficult thing is to transcend the document, to be able to have your photos go beyond what the photograph shows. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<blockquote>\n “My photos are not only a document about the Mediterranean, the Spanish or holidays, they are above all a document about the human condition.” \n</blockquote> \n<p><strong>GEJ: There’s an underlying tension in the pictures that speaks to the relationships between work and leisure. It’s really interesting that some of the reasons your subjects seek out moments of leisure is to escape from the anxieties, and perhaps unnatural lifestyles, brought on by industrialization. To see the evidences of industrial development within the pictures provides the sense that it’s an inescapable condition, aside from the few privileged who have the means to visit a truly remote paradise.</strong> </p> \n<p>TS: Our existence is framed between the highly improbable event of being born and another inevitable event that is death. From that binary perspective, every second of life is a ‘perfect day’. But from an existentialist perspective, our existence resembles that of plankton: living organisms, with little or no ability to move without the mercy of waves and currents. For a society that values its individuals for their production capacity, doing nothing has become the holy grail of our free time, and considering that death is a proven fact, it’s a great paradox! </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Perfect Day” (MACK, 2020). Courtesy of Txema Salvans and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/txema-salvans-perfect-day#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>GEJ: It’s strange and funny to me how, given the book’s release amid this global pandemic, the title almost becomes sarcastic, or perhaps a statement of longing. And it’s noteworthy that the people in your images, appearing alone, sometimes lonely, fall in line with the current context of social distancing and isolation. I wonder: has the pandemic changed your own interpretation of these pictures you’ve made?</strong> </p> \n<p>TS: We could say that this pandemic is global thanks to one human invention, “the combustion engine” that facilitates human movement on a global scale. The paradox is that it is stopped by another human invention, “the vaccine”. We are a totally denaturalized species. We have stopped relating to life and our natural environment, and have begun to relate more to dead materials, like plastic. We are opportunistic animals, we have adapted. <em>Perfect Day</em> tells us about the incredible physical and emotional resilience of our species. In this resilience, paradoxically, lies the tragedy of the human being. Where other species surrender, we are able to endure a little longer. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Perfect Day” (MACK, 2020). Courtesy of Txema Salvans and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/txema-salvans-perfect-day#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>GEJ: The thing I like most about this work is that the sea is the actual object of desire for your subjects, but it is not included in any of the pictures. You photograph with your back to it. It might seem funny to say, but I can almost read these pictures as having been made by the sea, distant and impartial, looking back at humanity and considering both its ingenuities and its follies. It seems important to me that these pictures were made around the Mediterranean coastline. Can you talk a little about the significance you found in photographing scenes from the Mediterranean specifically, as opposed to any other body of water?</strong> </p> \n<p>TS: I love your idea! How the Mediterranean sees us! The Mediterranean is above all landscape, and has a positive representation in the collective unconscious. My photos show the current reality of much of this landscape. The future of a landscape depends on its complexity, on the interrelationship of flora, fauna, meteorology… even the dunes of a desert never stay still. Our species devastates, demolishes, forces, and violates the landscape until it is sterilized by adding cement. A landscape without a future is a dead landscape. We are heirs to the violence of those who preceded us, and the Mediterranean has been deeply wronged, yet we have adapted. We are bordering on dystopia. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Perfect Day” (MACK, 2020). Courtesy of Txema Salvans and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/txema-salvans-perfect-day#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>GEJ: One of the most notable characteristics of these pictures is the sense of humor that comes with your vibrant color palette, the formal playfulness of your compositions, and the calmness of your detached viewpoints. To a degree, I have the sense that you are photographing with a forgiving eye toward humanity. We are eating ourselves and destroying the world, but we really just can’t help it, can we?</strong> </p> \n<p>TS: If I had to draw a parallel with literature, I see myself as a theatre playwright: I stand off-stage, very much centered in the theatre hall, and I observe. My photography is classic, it doesn’t pretend to surprise by a technical display. Nor does it pretend to explain. I like the observer to have room for interpretation. Photography is polysemic, its readings don’t depend entirely on just what I try to say. The viewer, through their emotional experience, gives meaning to that image. My photographs make sense when they leave me and someone else fills them with meaning. </p> \n<p>In terms of my technique, one of the reasons why I use analog photography is because I like to follow my intuition. With analog photography you cannot correct the photo you just made; you just have to keep going. Keep yourself very focused on what you do and stop, at least, every time you change the film. Digital photography is much faster. You are always attentive to what goes on the screen, which is ultimately the photo. </p> \n<p>I appreciate the wait I was subjected to when I sent the photographic rolls to the laboratory. I like to look at the backlit negatives. In short, I like the rituals of analog photography. While it is true that photography exists as a consequence of a technological fact, that is the camera, this interface between the world and the artist makes me very uncomfortable. The camera discovers you and interrupts your thoughts. But at the same time, in the realms of aesthetics and form, it offers you a multitude of possibilities that you can use skillfully. The great paradox of working with a large format analog camera mounted on a tripod, is that it complicates the rituals that accompany the photographic act. The more visible I am, the more unnoticed I am too. </p> \n<p><strong></strong> </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>From “Perfect Day” (MACK, 2020). Courtesy of Txema Salvans and MACK.\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/txema-salvans-perfect-day#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p><strong>GEJ: Now that <em>Perfect Day</em> has been published, what new projects will you be turning your attention to?</strong> </p> \n<p>TS: I have several projects in progress, but the most advanced is the third and final part of my project <em>The Waiting Game</em>: a photo project consisting of three books. Each book deals with a very precise theme that at the same time alludes to three circumstances that define us as a species: sociability, self-awareness and our relationship with the physical environment. This trilogy focuses on a dystopian version of these circumstances. <em>The Waiting Game 3</em> is the project that closes the trilogy. </p> \n<p>The images are also taken again in the Spanish Mediterranean and once again follow the same working protocol. In this case, the relationship between man and dog is a theme that allows me to address the way in which man relates to his environment in a dystopian way. The subject of my work is the dog on a leash, chained to the walls or fences of factories, industrial estates, farms, properties. It is the dog that waits and protects, that is born and dies in the same place and that lives at the mercy of its owner. A human capable, as in many other facets of our relationship with the environment, of distancing themselves emotionally from their animal to the extent of cruelty. </p> \n<div class=\"article-incut -book-incut\"> \n <div class=\"picture\"> \n  <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/books/18885-perfect-day\"></a> \n </div> \n <div class=\"title\">\n  Perfect Day \n  <br> </br>\n </div> \n <div class=\"author\">\n  by Txema Salvans\n  <br> </br>\n </div> \n <div class=\"publisher\">\n  Publisher: MACK\n  <br>ISBN: 978-1-912339-68-6<br> </br></br>\n </div> \n</div> \n<div class=\"article-incut -book-incut\"> \n <div class=\"picture\"> \n </div> \n <div class=\"article-incut -book-incut\"> \n  <div class=\"picture\"> \n  </div> \n  <p><br> </br></p> \n </div> \n</div>\n<p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n<ul>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/martin-middlebrook-isolation-afghanistan\">Isolation: Afghanistan</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/zhang-kechun-between-the-mountains-and-water\">Between the Mountains and Water</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/lensculture-editors-the-best-of-lensculture-in-2014\">The Best of LensCulture in 2014</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/raymond-meeks-halfstory-halflife\">Halfstory Halflife</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/salma-abedin-prithi-mundane\">Mundane</a></li>\n <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/scarlett-coten-mectoub\">Mectoub</a></li>\n</ul>\n<section class=\"fl-slideshow\">\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/2508c7ee-fab4-49a6-9328-9426307198bc.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n <figure>\n  <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9d87e7ee-29ea-49b1-92e5-b2bd5789b418.jpg\" />\n </figure>\n</section>","descriptionType":"html","publishedDate":"Tue, 18 Aug 2020 10:19:57 +0000","feedId":13500,"bgimg":"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/2508c7ee-fab4-49a6-9328-9426307198bc.jpg","linkMd5":"8fdf9c645003e1ec9eade01b7f698fea","bgimgJsdelivr":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn28@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-49-051_248a783d43fddc31.webp","destWidth":375,"destHeight":250,"sourceBytes":152389,"destBytes":20780,"author":"","articleImgCdnMap":{"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/2508c7ee-fab4-49a6-9328-9426307198bc.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn28@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-37-49-051_248a783d43fddc31.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/2508c7ee-fab4-49a6-9328-9426307198bc.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx5oss/cdn87@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-52-624_2bfe802f0731e352.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/9d87e7ee-29ea-49b1-92e5-b2bd5789b418.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx16/cdn12@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-13-469_e3820760a4db77b4.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066809},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"to Hans","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/vivian-keulards-to-hans","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>to Hans</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Vivian Keulards</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/bc49768c-14c7-4e03-a426-48edd813a216.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  A quiet ode to a brother loved and lost, Vivian Keulards’ book “to Hans” finds a form to dwell on the human stories behind addiction, and the complex web it spins around those it touches.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>The first image in Dutch photographer Vivian Keulards’ book <em>to Hans</em> is an old archival one from her family album, depicting her and her older brother as small children in 1974. Standing in front of their house in the late-afternoon light they wear helmets and grin up into the camera, his arm around her, their small frames throwing long shadows across the lawn. The image is all washed out orange and warm tones, taken on Kodachrome or Polaroid SX-70, perhaps. Several blank pages later, the next photograph is markedly cooler and starker; part of a concrete-lined pond seen from above on a dark, grey day. Most of the images from here retain this palette. What follows are rainy reflections, shadowy doorways and beds unslept in at the first light of morning. Occasionally, there is a portrait with the face blanked out, or a still life staged for the camera. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Hans and Vivian (1971) – photo from the family’s archive. From the book “To Hans” © Vivian Keulards\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/vivian-keulards-to-hans#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>In <em>to Hans</em>, Keulards finds a way to speak for the first time about her brother’s addiction-related death after almost 15 years of her family keeping it—and his struggle leading up to it—under wraps. “It’s a personal story with a universal mission: to show the human story behind addiction,” she writes. Her brother’s illness became taboo, wrapped up in shame, but at some point, she says, she decided to “open up the curtains. With all the consequences. Good and bad…” This book has been the result. Hans, of course, had a personal trajectory of addiction—a story of how one vice replaced another until eventually something bigger than him took his life—but Keulards doesn’t tell us any of those specifics here. At least not directly. She tells us more in interviews and on her website, but it feels right to only try to read the book with what parts of him we’ve been given in the pages. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Spread from “to Hans” © Vivian Keulards\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/vivian-keulards-to-hans#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>It would be almost impossible to try to shrink down and crystallize a whole life, with all of its complexities and pains and joys, neatly into a set of images, but what we can do with photography—what is vital to do with photography—is to use it to feel around the edges of experiences and how they move us, to visualize them in ways other forms of language cannot, and that is what Keulards does with great sensitivity here. She refers to her process of making this book as a sort of organizing of thoughts and feelings, and we come to learn that it is not so much about Hans, but more about the presence and subsequent loss of him and how that eclipsed her own existence over the years; an exercise in how to make art about yourself through the impressions someone else has left on you. Throughout the sequence of the book, Keulards travels to the hotel in Berlin in which Hans died in 2005, confronts the space, opens the curtains and looks out of the windows, wondering what he saw or thought about in those last hours. Photographs detailing all of that journey are catalogued here. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Curtains hotel room. For years we kept the cause of his death and his struggle with addiction secret. It was a taboo. I decided to open up the curtains. With all the consequences. Mainly good ones and a few bad. From the book “to Hans” © Vivian Keulards\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/vivian-keulards-to-hans#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>The book also features several images of parts of a body—her body it seems—close-up, in relief, like fragments of a statue, broken up and sliced across pages, submerged in water, her hands pulling at her own skin. In one image that folds out towards the end of the book we see her back arched forwards with rose thorns placed all the way along her spine, appearing creature-like with protective spikes. These pictures specifically work like small reminders throughout the sequence that bodies are worn, and can be worn away, by the things that happen to us and the people we love. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Rose thorns on back. As a child when I had nightmares my scary dreams always ended between my shoulder blades: biting, scratching, a knife… Looking back and working on my feelings I grew rose thorns to protect myself. I became strong and dare to stand for what I believe in. From the book “to Hans” © Vivian Keulards \n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/vivian-keulards-to-hans#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>In his accompanying essay to the book, <em>Looking into the sun</em>, Ralf Mohren writes about his own experience of being an alcoholic. “Why me but not her?” asks the writer regarding his own addiction and his sister’s lack of. Keulards’ question, in pictures, is the exact opposite: why him and not me? Mohren refers to himself as a puzzle, and that stuck with me, reminding me of my own father, who suffered with alcoholism throughout my childhood. It made me think of space, and how an addicted person’s mood can shape a whole room, their anger or sadness or joy swelling up and filling every crack and crevice, and every pocket of time in the day. “It eats away at you from within. Destroys you. Devours you alive,” continues Mohren, “Oh, and it devours all those around you too…” </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Horse. This was the beginning of my quest, in 2013. I was uncomfortable and not feeling well. Hans died in 2005. This was 8 years later. I knew it was time for me to start healing. For two years I have been living under a rock, visited a therapist and excluded dear people from my life. I looked back to everything that happened in my life. Not easy, but for the better now. From the book “to Hans” © Vivian Keulards\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/vivian-keulards-to-hans#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>All of the images in <em>to Hans</em> work like puzzle pieces, scattered out across pages, with endless white space between them. Keulards has made it our job as the viewer to sit and spend time with the book and piece the story together. Her use of Japanese binding places us next to her as she “opens the curtains.” There are surface images we can see clear as day—inside the room, as it were—and then gauzy, ghostly ones printed on the underside of the folds, inaccessible for a proper look, symbolizing what’s beyond the curtain. Those pictures haunt the visible ones, and the dichotomy between them reminds us of what’s said and what’s not said; what’s on the surface and presented, and what lingers in the lacunae beneath. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>Bell boy. Visiting the Berlin hotel, he was the first person to welcome us. Unintentionally he gave me the shivers, not knowing the real reason for my visit. \n<br>Spread from “to Hans” © Vivian Keulards<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/vivian-keulards-to-hans#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> <p>The whole time I was writing about Keulards’ book, I was thinking about a literary meditation the American poet and essayist Anne Boyer wrote on her diagnosis with cancer in <em>The New Yorker</em> last year. In it, she talks at length about the state of illness, or ‘being ill’ and its slow spread into all parts of her life, and details the moment she told her daughter that her genetic test had come back negative, meaning that she doesn’t have to worry that she is predisposed to getting it too. Her daughter’s response floored her: “You forget,” she answers, “that I still have the curse of living in the world that made you sick.” </p> <p>These powerful words work here with Keulards too, because addiction is an illness, and in some ways it feels like that is what she’s saying. “The cause then: something in the genes, predisposition, upbringing. Or not. Just a series of switches in the wrong position. We don’t know exactly,” Mohren says eventually. “It’s not a huge disaster. What’s more important is how we deal with it. And when I say ‘we’, I mean every one of us.” Punctuating the edit with more family pictures, Keulards makes it clear that Hans’ life—in all its beauty—affected hers in good ways, regardless of its tragic end. </p> \n <div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n </div>Forest. My quest was hard and scary, but necessary to order my thoughts and feelings. I wanted answers to my life questions. With this project I stand for what I believe in. Sharing pain is healing. I believe in the good of people. I share this personal project for a bigger purpose: showing the human being behind addiction. From the book “to Hans” © Vivian Keulards<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/vivian-keulards-to-hans#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> <p>When I was 9 or 10 or 11 years old—I don’t remember the exact year—my father turned yellow. I remember thinking how fitting it was that it was Autumn and he’d turned with the leaves. It was alcohol-related jaundice, I found out later, but at the time I wondered if it was possible that bodies could turn different colors based on the things we’d done—as if our emotional temperatures could color our outward appearances. How odd that he’d turned yellow then, I thought, before I really understood. Of all the colors, red would surely have seemed more fitting. I don’t know why Keulards chose yellow for the cover of <em>to Hans</em>—it’s one of the only design choices she doesn’t explain—but in many ways it works as the color most associated with the ripple-effects of addiction.To me, at least, but I’d imagine to others whose lives have been altered by the presence of a person addicted too. “Addiction doesn’t exclude anyone…No race, no orientation, not your background, not the color of your hair. Not if you have yellowed or snow-white teeth…” writes Mohren. Somewhere on the way to mustard but not quite, the yellow of Keulards’ cover has parts of a xerox-quality gridded image of Hans printed upon it. It makes his face the brightest bit of the book. </p> \n <hr> \n  <div> \n   <div class=\"article-incut -book-incut\"> \n    <div class=\"picture\"> \n     <a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/books/18887-to-hans\"></a> \n    </div> \n    <div class=\"title\">\n     to Hans\n     <br> </br>\n    </div> \n    <div class=\"author\">\n     by Vivian Keulards\n     <br> </br>\n    </div> \n    <div class=\"publisher\">\n     Publisher: Schilt Publishing\n     <br>ISBN: 9789053309384<br> </br></br>\n    </div> \n   </div> \n  </div>\n  <p>Enjoy Earth","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/lensculture-editors-65-amazing-photo-series-inspired-by-the-earth","description":"\n        <hgroup><h1>65 Amazing Photo Series Inspired by the Earth</h1><h3 class=\"fl-author\">LensCulture Editors</h3></hgroup><figure><img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/9fcbb7f1-9190-4bd5-bbd7-6fc60d7c08e9.jpg\"/><figcaption>The wonders and calamities of nature and life on Earth seem as endless as the cosmos themselves — Here are 65 amazing photo series that draw their inspiration from the beauty of nature, the cycles of life, changing weather and environments, and much more.</figcaption></figure><p>\n\tThe wonders and calamities of nature and life on Earth seem as endless as the cosmos themselves. Here are 65 amazing photo series that draw their inspiration from the beauty of nature, the cycles of life, changing weather and environments, and much more. The editors of LensCulture hope you find some inspiration from these 65 photographers whose work ranges from the poetic and sublime, to conservation, activism, documentary, reportage, landscape, wildlife, marco, micro, and humanity’s impact on the planet we call home.\n\t<br>\n\t<br>\n\tEnjoy!\n\t<br>\n\t<br>\n\t—Jim Casper and the editorial team at LensCulture\n\t<br>\n\t<br>\n\t<em>Click on each name below to see a full feature article about each of these 65 photographers:\n\t<br>\n\t</em><br>\n</p>\n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\">\n</div>Plastic tree #49 © Eduardo Leal<br><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/eduardo-leal-plastic-trees\">Eduardo Leal</a> - Plastic Trees\n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\">\n</div>A worker with a water hose tries to tame an iceberg of foam formed from chemical waste dumped by factories along the Yamuna River, one of the principal tributaries of the Ganges. © Giulio Di Sturco<br><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/giulio-di-sturco-living-entity-spirituality-industry-and-death-on-the-ganges\">Guilio Di Sturco</a><em> - Living Entity</em><span class=\"redactor-invisible-space\"></span>\n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\">\n</div>Andromeda © Beth Moon<br><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/beth-moon-diamond-nights\">Beth Moon</a> - Diamond Nights\n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\">\n</div>Stars, 8© Ellie Davies. NOA Noroeste Argentino \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\">\n</div>From the series Covered, 2009 © Peter Ainsworth<br><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/peter-ainsworth-covered-2009\">Peter Ainsworth</a> - d9.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ac0eb923-0329-416f-b00e-adf75ca3d8ff.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn92@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-56-358_0d4b381bbc886ffe.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d9f1665c-1b0a-451a-8999-33601c1a2781.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx12/cdn20@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-01-839_127e76427c0a3ddc.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a7993876-afe8-46b1-8fde-e3f88943eb95.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn28@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-09-481_2149dcf4e6cdeec6.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/24e23fec-a35d-4b6b-8ccf-89f226227044.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn76@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-09-582_64ecd7cb5f349124.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/36907e32-0f09-494a-bf65-3a21cc6ac53e.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx1/cdn36@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-04-828_f41cac3dc3564dce.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/76abd777-0981-4d45-bcd3-ab71a437cc97.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn92@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-53-770_175936d747de679d.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7a4f5492-e0d7-4fc3-acbf-caaaab156dc6.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx10/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-09-643_3913dc1acc466e1a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/8407b0cd-b3d9-40ac-a651-12e20965ddb2.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn96@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-52-148_2f17057070726634.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/ba9158f0-1c1f-4ad0-9da2-fc625a911e66.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx33/cdn7@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-56-395_f15546fc9bf02af3.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/6f556af8-6338-4db2-ae19-c267801b1882.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn52@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-11-492_31d5d90004e18fdb.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a82aa6db-48ab-42f1-811b-0a1a9133a203.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn88@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-38-15-800_43dc6d6de5871591.webp","https:// 6-b02d-48dd-b8f9-e907fb838079.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn68@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-52-297_95d9218182c50ad2.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7f86cb1b-9a08-4335-82c7-71b89e2dfdfb.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn84@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-14-330_ef7e45f637ed44d1.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/98313f69-a3e2-4ebb-b0a5-311b4230bafe.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx/cdn4@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-38-06-750_671b1d10e83a8cf6.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/dea193bb-9f73-44c8-8ce1-3b8a16bb9887.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx2/cdn24@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-38-08-208_d6cb3060b073f16d.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7340f6f0-7963-43c2-9e5e-f968cf97b226.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn96@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-01-045_dc3dd7abd526f06b.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7243f39c-2eee-4a85-9946-d428da5bdebd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx8/cdn20@2020_4/2020/08/25/02-37-59-679_298ec3406dcd8b62.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/4d2a039c-ee48-45c9-8a1e-1ec241426f65.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx25/cdn67@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-37-55-687_cd0bb361323f4af6.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/bc20d34e-7b61-4748-9bc6-e2cba0896c74.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn72@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-01-543_bdc957586ea10f27.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3cffa196-92ae-4b5f-8e32-96f857e35506.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx27/cdn20@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-05-389_98cad25eb4fb8bf5.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/7574970b-0fcb-45af-b842-adedc58fe3f3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx23/cdn40@2020_3/2020/08/25/02-37-58-447_a9520266dff64c6a.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/d254ad5a-ae48-4371-8313-c763b8d0afa3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx32/cdn4@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-06-010_15ba5348826eb34c.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/098f22fd-9ffc-4fb5-9332-69bf060fca66.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn8@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-03-060_ba1cecb9abae4b4e.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/3e879b54-1dfd-4949-9bb2-f6be1b1837ca.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx13/cdn40@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-38-02-148_c3ab80ea7bc03e81.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/0ffb7471-3594-42e3-a1ed-537cba1b1e76.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx4/cdn95@2020_1/2020/08/25/02-38-03-299_0828df1a5586a7dd.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/444fade8-cb37-4ac9-a0be-b018fd1f826d.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx30/cdn24@2020_2/2020/08/25/02-37-54-218_a799956af74df393.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/c57016c4-ee7b-4906-8962-d3184dab76b3.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx24/cdn86@2020_5/2020/08/25/02-38-00-165_6de47f0212744ffc.webp","https://photos.lensculture.com/large/a5e16ebe-244e-4a3e-bd7b-6dd6342d2ddd.jpg":"https://cdn.jsdelivr.net/gh/myreaderx18/cdn84@2020_6/2020/08/25/02-37-59-530_c21f1dfcd85a4399.webp"},"publishedOrCreatedDate":1598323066821},{"createdTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","updatedTime":"2020-08-25 10:37:46","title":"Adapting to Covid-19 in London’s Supermarkets","link":"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dougie-wallace-adapting-to-covid-19-in-london-s-supermarkets","description":"<hgroup>\n <h1>Adapting to Covid-19 in London’s Supermarkets</h1>\n <h3 class=\"fl-author\">Dougie Wallace</h3>\n</hgroup>\n<figure>\n <img src=\"https://photos.lensculture.com/flipcover/36fd8e43-5bb7-442f-9ba6-0a68c50b719d.jpg\" />\n <figcaption>\n  A London-based street photographer gives us an intimate look inside UK supermarkets during the coronavirus pandemic.\n </figcaption>\n</figure>\n<p>Adapting to new protocols demanded by the Covid-19 pandemic and lockdowns, even something as mundane as the “Saturday shop” — the weekly routine for most working individuals and families only a few weeks ago — feels like ancient history. As the new normal sets in, it has created a huge chasm between today’s reality and life BC (Before Corona). </p> \n<p>London-based street photographer Dougie Wallace has adapted his calling (to capture the zeitgeist in his uniquely droll style) as he sets out to document the “only show in town”. Supermarket shopping is now one of the only public activities that calls for live interactions, and Wallace catches the moods and fashions as winter turns to spring, and shoppers adapt to new routines. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>© Dougie Wallace\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dougie-wallace-adapting-to-covid-19-in-london-s-supermarkets#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>After early days of panic buying and empty shelves, life under lockdown has started to develop its own new ways. Shoppers patiently queue to get into a shop while killing time by staring into their mobiles or reading newspapers or books. White-collar workers dress down, as their professions allow them to work from the comfort of their homes. The rebels dress up, as if to defy the curfew on social gatherings. Supermarket workers keep it ticking for everyone, often at great personal risk over long hours. </p> \n<p>The mask continues to be the symbol of this crisis. There’s been a lot of polemic about the UK government’s unpreparedness for the pandemic and the resultant fear of stock depletion of medical masks for frontline workers. It seems that one of the wealthiest and most powerful countries in the world could not provide enough masks and protective equipment for those whose jobs involve saving lives, let alone for ordinary citizens. To substitute for the lack of availability, people got creative. Some homemade masks are simply functional, using advice circulating online on how to make your own mask. Others are more inventive – ranging from outlandish to plain bonkers. For the fashion-conscious, entrepreneurial makers are also beginning to oblige. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>© Dougie Wallace\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dougie-wallace-adapting-to-covid-19-in-london-s-supermarkets#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>While we are all in this together, the real heroes of this story are the supermarket staff and the other key workers. Uniformed security guards regulate the flow of shoppers on a “one-in-one-out” basis, as in nightclubs. Checkout staff, directly facing customers, each a potential carrier of this deadly threat, are on the front line. Shop floor staff are doing their utmost to go about their duties, servicing customers, whilst trying to observe the newly imposed two-trolley-width distancing rules – all but impossible when stocking shelves in the narrow aisles of a Tesco Metro. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>© Dougie Wallace\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dougie-wallace-adapting-to-covid-19-in-london-s-supermarkets#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>According to reports, some supermarket staff faced resistance from employers in relation to wearing protection, for fear that customers would find them unsettling, or worse, that the workers would demand “hazard pay” considering their greater level of exposure to the virus. Over time, employers, nevertheless, introduced a range of safety measures to create a new barricaded shopping landscape. These include plexiglass partitions for checkout lanes and branded uniforms, whether aprons or T-shirts, all blasted with slogans such as “Keep-2m-Apart”. However, unlike shoppers, who are encouraged to be expedient with their shopping trip, staff, if they are to work, have no choice but to spend eight hours or so a day trying to breathe damp, exhaled air through fabric. </p> \n<div class=\"article-photo-placeholder\"> \n</div>© Dougie Wallace\n<a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dougie-wallace-adapting-to-covid-19-in-london-s-supermarkets#\" class=\"add-to-collection-inline-photo\"><i class=\"fa fa-plus\"></i></a> \n<p>Street photography can be challenging at any time but navigating through the health warnings of 2m distance-keeping makes the challenge of getting a good shot even greater. Wallace shoots with an Olympus EM1 Mark 3, which is small, fast and light. Yet he says he’s still struggling with the professional hazard of holding a camera close to the face while trying not to touch one’s face and remembering to regularly sanitize hands and equipment to protect against the invisible enemy. “No matter how long I’ve been doing this, some of the new practices still feel counterintuitive. We’re all learning how to do this new thing together,” he says.<br> </br></p> \n<p>— Lida Hujic </p> \n<hr> \n <p><em>Dougie Wallace has published six photobooks. The newest, <a href=\"https://www.dewilewis.com/products/east-ended\">East Ended</a>, was just released by Dewi Lewis and is available for purchase online. And check his work daily on <a href=\"https://www.instagram.com/dougie_wallace/\">Instagram</a>.</em> </p>\n <p>Enjoy more great photography:</p>\n <ul>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/dawn-woolley-the-substitute\">The Substitute</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/the-photographers-gallery-elastic-forms-elastic-visions\">Elastic Forms, Elastic Visions</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/eamonn-doyle-end\">End.</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/hajime-inomata-ways-of-seeing-on-the-streets-or-from-your-kitchen-window\">Ways of Seeing: On the Streets or from Your Kitchen Window</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/demetris-koilalous-caesura-the-duration-of-a-sigh\">CAESURA: The Duration of a Sigh</a></li>\n  <li><a href=\"https://www.lensculture.com/articles/lensculture-design-call-for-entries-lensculture-journeys-2020\">Call for Entries!
